726 //
727 // THIS SECTION CONTAINS C++ INTERFACE

730 namespace alglib
731 {
732 
733 #if defined(AE_COMPILE_PCA) || !defined(AE_PARTIAL_BUILD)

740 
741 #if defined(AE_COMPILE_MLPBASE) || !defined(AE_PARTIAL_BUILD)
742 /*************************************************************************
743 Model's errors:
744  * RelCLSError - fraction of misclassified cases.
745  * AvgCE - acerage cross-entropy
746  * RMSError - root-mean-square error
747  * AvgError - average error
748  * AvgRelError - average relative error
749 
750 NOTE 1: RelCLSError/AvgCE are zero on regression problems.
751 
752 NOTE 2: on classification problems RMSError/AvgError/AvgRelError contain
753  errors in prediction of posterior probabilities
754 *************************************************************************/
755 class _modelerrors_owner
756 {
757 public:
762  _modelerrors_owner();
768  _modelerrors_owner(const _modelerrors_owner &rhs);
775  _modelerrors_owner& operator=(const _modelerrors_owner &rhs);
780  virtual ~_modelerrors_owner();
786  alglib_impl::modelerrors* c_ptr();
792  alglib_impl::modelerrors* c_ptr() const;
793 protected:
794  alglib_impl::modelerrors *p_struct;
795 };
800 class modelerrors : public _modelerrors_owner
801 {
802 public:
807  modelerrors();
813  modelerrors(const modelerrors &rhs);
820  modelerrors& operator=(const modelerrors &rhs);
825  virtual ~modelerrors();
826  double &relclserror;
827  double &avgce;
828  double &rmserror;
829  double &avgerror;
830  double &avgrelerror;
832 };
833 
834 
835 /*************************************************************************
836 
837 *************************************************************************/
838 class _multilayerperceptron_owner
839 {
840 public:
845  _multilayerperceptron_owner();
851  _multilayerperceptron_owner(const _multilayerperceptron_owner &rhs);
858  _multilayerperceptron_owner& operator=(const _multilayerperceptron_owner &rhs);
863  virtual ~_multilayerperceptron_owner();
869  alglib_impl::multilayerperceptron* c_ptr();
875  alglib_impl::multilayerperceptron* c_ptr() const;
876 protected:
877  alglib_impl::multilayerperceptron *p_struct;
878 };

909 
910 };

918 /*************************************************************************
919 This object stores state of the SSA model.
920 
921 You should use ALGLIB functions to work with this object.
922 *************************************************************************/
923 class _ssamodel_owner
924 {
925 public:
930  _ssamodel_owner();
936  _ssamodel_owner(const _ssamodel_owner &rhs);
943  _ssamodel_owner& operator=(const _ssamodel_owner &rhs);
948  virtual ~_ssamodel_owner();
954  alglib_impl::ssamodel* c_ptr();
960  alglib_impl::ssamodel* c_ptr() const;
961 protected:
962  alglib_impl::ssamodel *p_struct;
963 };

1048 {

1072  virtual ~linearmodel();

1075 
1076 
1077 /*************************************************************************
1078 LRReport structure contains additional information about linear model:
1079 * C - covariation matrix, array[0..NVars,0..NVars].
1080  C[i,j] = Cov(A[i],A[j])
1081 * RMSError - root mean square error on a training set
1082 * AvgError - average error on a training set
1083 * AvgRelError - average relative error on a training set (excluding
1084  observations with zero function value).
1085 * CVRMSError - leave-one-out cross-validation estimate of
1086  generalization error. Calculated using fast algorithm
1087  with O(NVars*NPoints) complexity.
1088 * CVAvgError - cross-validation estimate of average error
1089 * CVAvgRelError - cross-validation estimate of average relative error
1090 
1091 All other fields of the structure are intended for internal use and should
1092 not be used outside ALGLIB.
1093 *************************************************************************/
1094 class _lrreport_owner
1095 {
1096 public:
1101  _lrreport_owner();
1107  _lrreport_owner(const _lrreport_owner &rhs);
1114  _lrreport_owner& operator=(const _lrreport_owner &rhs);
1119  virtual ~_lrreport_owner();
1125  alglib_impl::lrreport* c_ptr();
1131  alglib_impl::lrreport* c_ptr() const;
1132 protected:
1133  alglib_impl::lrreport *p_struct;
1134 };
1139 class lrreport : public _lrreport_owner
1140 {
1141 public:
1146  lrreport();
1152  lrreport(const lrreport &rhs);
1159  lrreport& operator=(const lrreport &rhs);
1164  virtual ~lrreport();
1165  real_2d_array c;
1166  double &rmserror;
1167  double &avgerror;
1168  double &avgrelerror;
1169  double &cvrmserror;
1170  double &cvavgerror;
1171  double &cvavgrelerror;
1172  ae_int_t &ncvdefects;
1173  integer_1d_array cvdefects;
1175 };
1176 #endif

1180 #endif

1261 /*************************************************************************
1262 MNLReport structure contains information about training process:
1263 * NGrad - number of gradient calculations
1264 * NHess - number of Hessian calculations
1265 *************************************************************************/
1266 class _mnlreport_owner
1267 {
1268 public:
1273  _mnlreport_owner();
1279  _mnlreport_owner(const _mnlreport_owner &rhs);
1286  _mnlreport_owner& operator=(const _mnlreport_owner &rhs);
1291  virtual ~_mnlreport_owner();
1297  alglib_impl::mnlreport* c_ptr();
1303  alglib_impl::mnlreport* c_ptr() const;
1304 protected:
1305  alglib_impl::mnlreport *p_struct;
1306 };
1311 class mnlreport : public _mnlreport_owner
1312 {
1313 public:
1318  mnlreport();
1324  mnlreport(const mnlreport &rhs);
1331  mnlreport& operator=(const mnlreport &rhs);
1336  virtual ~mnlreport();

1338  ae_int_t &nhess;
1340 };
1341 #endif

1437  failure)

1601 /*************************************************************************
1602 Training report:
1603  * RelCLSError - fraction of misclassified cases.
1604  * AvgCE - acerage cross-entropy
1605  * RMSError - root-mean-square error

1609  * NHess - number of Hessian calculations

1611

1613

1615  errors in prediction of posterior probabilities

1874 class _clusterizerstate_owner

1919 class clusterizerstate : public _clusterizerstate_owner
1920 {
1921 public:

1932  clusterizerstate(const clusterizerstate &rhs);
1939  clusterizerstate& operator=(const clusterizerstate &rhs);
1944  virtual ~clusterizerstate();
1945 
1946 };
1947 
1948 
1949 /*************************************************************************
1950 This structure is used to store results of the agglomerative hierarchical
1951 clustering (AHC).
1952 
1953 Following information is returned:
1954 
1955 * TerminationType - completion code:
1956  * 1 for successful completion of algorithm
1957  * -5 inappropriate combination of clustering algorithm and distance
1958  function was used. As for now, it is possible only when Ward's
1959  method is called for dataset with non-Euclidean distance function.
1960  In case negative completion code is returned, other fields of report
1961  structure are invalid and should not be used.
1962 
1963 * NPoints contains number of points in the original dataset
1964 
1965 * Z contains information about merges performed (see below). Z contains
1966  indexes from the original (unsorted) dataset and it can be used when you
1967  need to know what points were merged. However, it is not convenient when
1968  you want to build a dendrograd (see below).
1969 
1970 * if you want to build dendrogram, you can use Z, but it is not good
1971  option, because Z contains indexes from unsorted dataset. Dendrogram
1972  built from such dataset is likely to have intersections. So, you have to
1973  reorder you points before building dendrogram.
1974  Permutation which reorders point is returned in P. Another representation
1975  of merges, which is more convenient for dendorgram construction, is
1976  returned in PM.
1977 
1978 * more information on format of Z, P and PM can be found below and in the
1979  examples from ALGLIB Reference Manual.
1980 
1981 FORMAL DESCRIPTION OF FIELDS:
1982  NPoints number of points
1983  Z array[NPoints-1,2], contains indexes of clusters
1984  linked in pairs to form clustering tree. I-th row
1985  corresponds to I-th merge:
1986  * Z[I,0] - index of the first cluster to merge
1987  * Z[I,1] - index of the second cluster to merge
1988  * Z[I,0]<Z[I,1]
1989  * clusters are numbered from 0 to 2*NPoints-2, with
1990  indexes from 0 to NPoints-1 corresponding to points
1991  of the original dataset, and indexes from NPoints to
1992  2*NPoints-2 correspond to clusters generated by
1993  subsequent merges (I-th row of Z creates cluster
1994  with index NPoints+I).
1995 
1996  IMPORTANT: indexes in Z[] are indexes in the ORIGINAL,
1997  unsorted dataset. In addition to Z algorithm outputs
1998  permutation which rearranges points in such way that
1999  subsequent merges are performed on adjacent points
2000  (such order is needed if you want to build dendrogram).
2001  However, indexes in Z are related to original,
2002  unrearranged sequence of points.
2003 
2004  P array[NPoints], permutation which reorders points for
2005  dendrogram construction. P[i] contains index of the
2006  position where we should move I-th point of the
2007  original dataset in order to apply merges PZ/PM.
2008 
2009  PZ same as Z, but for permutation of points given by P.
2010  The only thing which changed are indexes of the
2011  original points; indexes of clusters remained same.
2012 
2013  MergeDist array[NPoints-1], contains distances between clusters
2014  being merged (MergeDist[i] correspond to merge stored
2015  in Z[i,...]):
2016  * CLINK, SLINK and average linkage algorithms report
2017  "raw", unmodified distance metric.
2018  * Ward's method reports weighted intra-cluster
2019  variance, which is equal to ||Ca-Cb||^2 * Sa*Sb/(Sa+Sb).
2020  Here A and B are clusters being merged, Ca is a
2021  center of A, Cb is a center of B, Sa is a size of A,
2022  Sb is a size of B.
2023 
2024  PM array[NPoints-1,6], another representation of merges,
2025  which is suited for dendrogram construction. It deals
2026  with rearranged points (permutation P is applied) and
2027  represents merges in a form which different from one
2028  used by Z.
2029  For each I from 0 to NPoints-2, I-th row of PM represents
2030  merge performed on two clusters C0 and C1. Here:
2031  * C0 contains points with indexes PM[I,0]...PM[I,1]
2032  * C1 contains points with indexes PM[I,2]...PM[I,3]
2033  * indexes stored in PM are given for dataset sorted
2034  according to permutation P
2035  * PM[I,1]=PM[I,2]-1 (only adjacent clusters are merged)
2036  * PM[I,0]<=PM[I,1], PM[I,2]<=PM[I,3], i.e. both
2037  clusters contain at least one point
2038  * heights of "subdendrograms" corresponding to C0/C1
2039  are stored in PM[I,4] and PM[I,5]. Subdendrograms
2040  corresponding to single-point clusters have
2041  height=0. Dendrogram of the merge result has height
2042  H=max(H0,H1)+1.
2043 
2044 NOTE: there is one-to-one correspondence between merges described by Z and
2045  PM. I-th row of Z describes same merge of clusters as I-th row of PM,
2046  with "left" cluster from Z corresponding to the "left" one from PM.
2047 
2048  -- ALGLIB --
2049  Copyright 10.07.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
2050 *************************************************************************/
2051 class _ahcreport_owner
2052 {
2053 public:
2058  _ahcreport_owner();
2064  _ahcreport_owner(const _ahcreport_owner &rhs);
2071  _ahcreport_owner& operator=(const _ahcreport_owner &rhs);
2076  virtual ~_ahcreport_owner();
2082  alglib_impl::ahcreport* c_ptr();
2088  alglib_impl::ahcreport* c_ptr() const;
2089 protected:
2090  alglib_impl::ahcreport *p_struct;
2091 };
2096 class ahcreport : public _ahcreport_owner
2097 {
2098 public:
2103  ahcreport();
2109  ahcreport(const ahcreport &rhs);
2116  ahcreport& operator=(const ahcreport &rhs);
2121  virtual ~ahcreport();
2122  ae_int_t &terminationtype;
2123  ae_int_t &npoints;
2124  integer_1d_array p;
2125  integer_2d_array z;
2126  integer_2d_array pz;
2127  integer_2d_array pm;
2128  real_1d_array mergedist;
2130 };
2131 
2132 
2133 /*************************************************************************
2134 This structure is used to store results of the k-means clustering
2135 algorithm.
2136 
2137 Following information is always returned:
2138 * NPoints contains number of points in the original dataset
2139 * TerminationType contains completion code, negative on failure, positive
2140  on success
2141 * K contains number of clusters
2142 
2143 For positive TerminationType we return:
2144 * NFeatures contains number of variables in the original dataset
2145 * C, which contains centers found by algorithm
2146 * CIdx, which maps points of the original dataset to clusters
2147 
2148 FORMAL DESCRIPTION OF FIELDS:
2149  NPoints number of points, >=0
2150  NFeatures number of variables, >=1
2151  TerminationType completion code:
2152  * -5 if distance type is anything different from
2153  Euclidean metric
2154  * -3 for degenerate dataset: a) less than K distinct
2155  points, b) K=0 for non-empty dataset.
2156  * +1 for successful completion
2157  K number of clusters
2158  C array[K,NFeatures], rows of the array store centers
2159  CIdx array[NPoints], which contains cluster indexes
2160  IterationsCount actual number of iterations performed by clusterizer.
2161  If algorithm performed more than one random restart,
2162  total number of iterations is returned.
2163  Energy merit function, "energy", sum of squared deviations
2164  from cluster centers
2165 
2166  -- ALGLIB --
2167  Copyright 27.11.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
2168 *************************************************************************/
2169 class _kmeansreport_owner
2170 {
2171 public:
2176  _kmeansreport_owner();
2182  _kmeansreport_owner(const _kmeansreport_owner &rhs);
2189  _kmeansreport_owner& operator=(const _kmeansreport_owner &rhs);
2194  virtual ~_kmeansreport_owner();
2200  alglib_impl::kmeansreport* c_ptr();
2206  alglib_impl::kmeansreport* c_ptr() const;
2207 protected:
2208  alglib_impl::kmeansreport *p_struct;
2209 };
2214 class kmeansreport : public _kmeansreport_owner
2215 {
2216 public:
2221  kmeansreport();
2227  kmeansreport(const kmeansreport &rhs);
2234  kmeansreport& operator=(const kmeansreport &rhs);
2239  virtual ~kmeansreport();
2240  ae_int_t &npoints;
2241  ae_int_t &nfeatures;
2242  ae_int_t &terminationtype;
2243  ae_int_t &iterationscount;
2244  double &energy;
2245  ae_int_t &k;
2246  real_2d_array c;
2247  integer_1d_array cidx;
2249 };
2250 #endif

2410 
2411 /*************************************************************************
2412 Decision forest training report.
2413 
2414 Following fields store training set errors:
2415 * relclserror - fraction of misclassified cases, [0,1]
2416 * avgce - average cross-entropy in bits per symbol
2417 * rmserror - root-mean-square error
2418 * avgerror - average error
2419 * avgrelerror - average relative error
2420 
2421 Out-of-bag estimates are stored in fields with same names, but "oob" prefix.
2422 
2423 For classification problems:
2424 * RMS, AVG and AVGREL errors are calculated for posterior probabilities
2425 
2426 For regression problems:
2427 * RELCLS and AVGCE errors are zero
2428 *************************************************************************/
2429 class _dfreport_owner
2430 {
2431 public:
2436  _dfreport_owner();
2442  _dfreport_owner(const _dfreport_owner &rhs);
2449  _dfreport_owner& operator=(const _dfreport_owner &rhs);
2454  virtual ~_dfreport_owner();
2460  alglib_impl::dfreport* c_ptr();
2466  alglib_impl::dfreport* c_ptr() const;
2467 protected:
2468  alglib_impl::dfreport *p_struct;
2469 };
2474 class dfreport : public _dfreport_owner
2475 {
2476 public:
2481  dfreport();
2487  dfreport(const dfreport &rhs);
2494  dfreport& operator=(const dfreport &rhs);
2499  virtual ~dfreport();
2500  double &relclserror;
2501  double &avgce;
2502  double &rmserror;
2503  double &avgerror;
2504  double &avgrelerror;
2505  double &oobrelclserror;
2506  double &oobavgce;
2507  double &oobrmserror;
2508  double &oobavgerror;
2509  double &oobavgrelerror;
2511 };
2512 #endif
2513 
2514 #if defined(AE_COMPILE_DATACOMP) || !defined(AE_PARTIAL_BUILD)
2515 
2516 #endif
2517 
2518 #if defined(AE_COMPILE_PCA) || !defined(AE_PARTIAL_BUILD)
2519 /*************************************************************************
2520 Principal components analysis
2521 
2522 This function builds orthogonal basis where first axis corresponds to
2523 direction with maximum variance, second axis maximizes variance in the
2524 subspace orthogonal to first axis and so on.
2525 
2526 This function builds FULL basis, i.e. returns N vectors corresponding to
2527 ALL directions, no matter how informative. If you need just a few (say,
2528 10 or 50) of the most important directions, you may find it faster to use
2529 one of the reduced versions:
2530 * pcatruncatedsubspace() - for subspace iteration based method
2531 
2532 It should be noted that, unlike LDA, PCA does not use class labels.
2533 
2534  ! COMMERCIAL EDITION OF ALGLIB:
2535  !
2536  ! Commercial Edition of ALGLIB includes following important improvements
2537  ! of this function:
2538  ! * high-performance native backend with same C# interface (C# version)
2539  ! * multithreading support (C++ and C# versions)
2540  ! * hardware vendor (Intel) implementations of linear algebra primitives
2541  ! (C++ and C# versions, x86/x64 platform)
2542  !
2543  ! We recommend you to read 'Working with commercial version' section of
2544  ! ALGLIB Reference Manual in order to find out how to use performance-
2545  ! related features provided by commercial edition of ALGLIB.
2546 
2547 INPUT PARAMETERS:
2548  X - dataset, array[0..NPoints-1,0..NVars-1].
2549  matrix contains ONLY INDEPENDENT VARIABLES.
2550  NPoints - dataset size, NPoints>=0
2551  NVars - number of independent variables, NVars>=1
2552 
2553 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
2554  Info - return code:
2555  * -4, if SVD subroutine haven't converged
2556  * -1, if wrong parameters has been passed (NPoints<0,
2557  NVars<1)
2558  * 1, if task is solved
2559  S2 - array[0..NVars-1]. variance values corresponding
2560  to basis vectors.
2561  V - array[0..NVars-1,0..NVars-1]
2562  matrix, whose columns store basis vectors.
2563 
2564  -- ALGLIB --
2565  Copyright 25.08.2008 by Bochkanov Sergey
2566 *************************************************************************/
2567 void pcabuildbasis(const real_2d_array &x, const ae_int_t npoints, const ae_int_t nvars, ae_int_t &info, real_1d_array &s2, real_2d_array &v, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
2568 
2569 
2570 /*************************************************************************
2571 Principal components analysis
2572 
2573 This function performs truncated PCA, i.e. returns just a few most important
2574 directions.
2575 
2576 Internally it uses iterative eigensolver which is very efficient when only
2577 a minor fraction of full basis is required. Thus, if you need full basis,
2578 it is better to use pcabuildbasis() function.
2579 
2580 It should be noted that, unlike LDA, PCA does not use class labels.
2581 
2582  ! COMMERCIAL EDITION OF ALGLIB:
2583  !
2584  ! Commercial Edition of ALGLIB includes following important improvements
2585  ! of this function:
2586  ! * high-performance native backend with same C# interface (C# version)
2587  ! * multithreading support (C++ and C# versions)
2588  ! * hardware vendor (Intel) implementations of linear algebra primitives
2589  ! (C++ and C# versions, x86/x64 platform)
2590  !
2591  ! We recommend you to read 'Working with commercial version' section of
2592  ! ALGLIB Reference Manual in order to find out how to use performance-
2593  ! related features provided by commercial edition of ALGLIB.
2594 
2595 INPUT PARAMETERS:
2596  X - dataset, array[0..NPoints-1,0..NVars-1].
2597  matrix contains ONLY INDEPENDENT VARIABLES.
2598  NPoints - dataset size, NPoints>=0
2599  NVars - number of independent variables, NVars>=1
2600  NNeeded - number of requested components, in [1,NVars] range;
2601  this function is efficient only for NNeeded<<NVars.
2602  Eps - desired precision of vectors returned; underlying
2603  solver will stop iterations as soon as absolute error
2604  in corresponding singular values reduces to roughly
2605  eps*MAX(lambda[]), with lambda[] being array of eigen
2606  values.
2607  Zero value means that algorithm performs number of
2608  iterations specified by maxits parameter, without
2609  paying attention to precision.
2610  MaxIts - number of iterations performed by subspace iteration
2611  method. Zero value means that no limit on iteration
2612  count is placed (eps-based stopping condition is used).
2613 
2614 
2615 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
2616  S2 - array[NNeeded]. Variance values corresponding
2617  to basis vectors.
2618  V - array[NVars,NNeeded]
2619  matrix, whose columns store basis vectors.
2620 
2621 NOTE: passing eps=0 and maxits=0 results in small eps being selected as
2622 stopping condition. Exact value of automatically selected eps is version-
2623 -dependent.
2624 
2625  -- ALGLIB --
2626  Copyright 10.01.2017 by Bochkanov Sergey
2627 *************************************************************************/
2628 void pcatruncatedsubspace(const real_2d_array &x, const ae_int_t npoints, const ae_int_t nvars, const ae_int_t nneeded, const double eps, const ae_int_t maxits, real_1d_array &s2, real_2d_array &v, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
2629 
2630 
2631 /*************************************************************************
2632 Sparse truncated principal components analysis
2633 
2634 This function performs sparse truncated PCA, i.e. returns just a few most
2635 important principal components for a sparse input X.
2636 
2637 Internally it uses iterative eigensolver which is very efficient when only
2638 a minor fraction of full basis is required.
2639 
2640 It should be noted that, unlike LDA, PCA does not use class labels.
2641 
2642  ! COMMERCIAL EDITION OF ALGLIB:
2643  !
2644  ! Commercial Edition of ALGLIB includes following important improvements
2645  ! of this function:
2646  ! * high-performance native backend with same C# interface (C# version)
2647  ! * multithreading support (C++ and C# versions)
2648  ! * hardware vendor (Intel) implementations of linear algebra primitives
2649  ! (C++ and C# versions, x86/x64 platform)
2650  !
2651  ! We recommend you to read 'Working with commercial version' section of
2652  ! ALGLIB Reference Manual in order to find out how to use performance-
2653  ! related features provided by commercial edition of ALGLIB.
2654 
2655 INPUT PARAMETERS:
2656  X - sparse dataset, sparse npoints*nvars matrix. It is
2657  recommended to use CRS sparse storage format; non-CRS
2658  input will be internally converted to CRS.
2659  Matrix contains ONLY INDEPENDENT VARIABLES, and must
2660  be EXACTLY npoints*nvars.
2661  NPoints - dataset size, NPoints>=0
2662  NVars - number of independent variables, NVars>=1
2663  NNeeded - number of requested components, in [1,NVars] range;
2664  this function is efficient only for NNeeded<<NVars.
2665  Eps - desired precision of vectors returned; underlying
2666  solver will stop iterations as soon as absolute error
2667  in corresponding singular values reduces to roughly
2668  eps*MAX(lambda[]), with lambda[] being array of eigen
2669  values.
2670  Zero value means that algorithm performs number of
2671  iterations specified by maxits parameter, without
2672  paying attention to precision.
2673  MaxIts - number of iterations performed by subspace iteration
2674  method. Zero value means that no limit on iteration
2675  count is placed (eps-based stopping condition is used).
2676 
2677 
2678 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
2679  S2 - array[NNeeded]. Variance values corresponding
2680  to basis vectors.
2681  V - array[NVars,NNeeded]
2682  matrix, whose columns store basis vectors.
2683 
2684 NOTE: passing eps=0 and maxits=0 results in small eps being selected as
2685 stopping condition. Exact value of automatically selected eps is version-
2686 -dependent.
2687 
2688  -- ALGLIB --
2689  Copyright 10.01.2017 by Bochkanov Sergey
2690 *************************************************************************/
2691 void pcatruncatedsubspacesparse(const sparsematrix &x, const ae_int_t npoints, const ae_int_t nvars, const ae_int_t nneeded, const double eps, const ae_int_t maxits, real_1d_array &s2, real_2d_array &v, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
2692 #endif
2693 
2694 #if defined(AE_COMPILE_BDSS) || !defined(AE_PARTIAL_BUILD)
2695 /*************************************************************************
2696 Optimal binary classification
2697 
2698 Algorithms finds optimal (=with minimal cross-entropy) binary partition.
2699 Internal subroutine.
2700 
2701 INPUT PARAMETERS:
2702  A - array[0..N-1], variable
2703  C - array[0..N-1], class numbers (0 or 1).
2704  N - array size
2705 
2706 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
2707  Info - completetion code:
2708  * -3, all values of A[] are same (partition is impossible)
2709  * -2, one of C[] is incorrect (<0, >1)
2710  * -1, incorrect pararemets were passed (N<=0).
2711  * 1, OK
2712  Threshold- partiton boundary. Left part contains values which are
2713  strictly less than Threshold. Right part contains values
2714  which are greater than or equal to Threshold.
2715  PAL, PBL- probabilities P(0|v<Threshold) and P(1|v<Threshold)
2716  PAR, PBR- probabilities P(0|v>=Threshold) and P(1|v>=Threshold)
2717  CVE - cross-validation estimate of cross-entropy
2718 
2719  -- ALGLIB --
2720  Copyright 22.05.2008 by Bochkanov Sergey
2721 *************************************************************************/
2722 void dsoptimalsplit2(const real_1d_array &a, const integer_1d_array &c, const ae_int_t n, ae_int_t &info, double &threshold, double &pal, double &pbl, double &par, double &pbr, double &cve, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
2723 
2724 
2725 /*************************************************************************
2726 Optimal partition, internal subroutine. Fast version.
2727 
2728 Accepts:
2729  A array[0..N-1] array of attributes array[0..N-1]
2730  C array[0..N-1] array of class labels
2731  TiesBuf array[0..N] temporaries (ties)
2732  CntBuf array[0..2*NC-1] temporaries (counts)
2733  Alpha centering factor (0<=alpha<=1, recommended value - 0.05)
2734  BufR array[0..N-1] temporaries
2735  BufI array[0..N-1] temporaries
2736 
2737 Output:
2738  Info error code (">0"=OK, "<0"=bad)
2739  RMS training set RMS error
2740  CVRMS leave-one-out RMS error
2741 
2742 Note:
2743  content of all arrays is changed by subroutine;
2744  it doesn't allocate temporaries.
2745 
2746  -- ALGLIB --
2747  Copyright 11.12.2008 by Bochkanov Sergey
2748 *************************************************************************/
2749 void dsoptimalsplit2fast(real_1d_array &a, integer_1d_array &c, integer_1d_array &tiesbuf, integer_1d_array &cntbuf, real_1d_array &bufr, integer_1d_array &bufi, const ae_int_t n, const ae_int_t nc, const double alpha, ae_int_t &info, double &threshold, double &rms, double &cvrms, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
2750 #endif
2751 
2752 #if defined(AE_COMPILE_MLPBASE) || !defined(AE_PARTIAL_BUILD)
2753 /*************************************************************************
2754 This function serializes data structure to string.
2755 
2756 Important properties of s_out:
2757 * it contains alphanumeric characters, dots, underscores, minus signs
2758 * these symbols are grouped into words, which are separated by spaces
2759  and Windows-style (CR+LF) newlines
2760 * although serializer uses spaces and CR+LF as separators, you can
2761  replace any separator character by arbitrary combination of spaces,
2762  tabs, Windows or Unix newlines. It allows flexible reformatting of
2763  the string in case you want to include it into text or XML file.
2764  But you should not insert separators into the middle of the "words"
2765  nor you should change case of letters.
2766 * s_out can be freely moved between 32-bit and 64-bit systems, little
2767  and big endian machines, and so on. You can serialize structure on
2768  32-bit machine and unserialize it on 64-bit one (or vice versa), or
2769  serialize it on SPARC and unserialize on x86. You can also
2770  serialize it in C++ version of ALGLIB and unserialize in C# one,
2771  and vice versa.
2772 *************************************************************************/
2773 void mlpserialize(multilayerperceptron &obj, std::string &s_out);
2774 
2775 
2776 /*************************************************************************
2777 This function unserializes data structure from string.
2778 *************************************************************************/
2779 void mlpunserialize(const std::string &s_in, multilayerperceptron &obj);
2780 
2781 
2782 
2783 
2784 /*************************************************************************
2785 This function serializes data structure to C++ stream.
2786 
2787 Data stream generated by this function is same as string representation
2788 generated by string version of serializer - alphanumeric characters,
2789 dots, underscores, minus signs, which are grouped into words separated by
2790 spaces and CR+LF.
2791 
2792 We recommend you to read comments on string version of serializer to find
2793 out more about serialization of AlGLIB objects.
2794 *************************************************************************/
2795 void mlpserialize(multilayerperceptron &obj, std::ostream &s_out);
2796 
2797 
2798 /*************************************************************************
2799 This function unserializes data structure from stream.
2800 *************************************************************************/
2801 void mlpunserialize(const std::istream &s_in, multilayerperceptron &obj);

2804 /*************************************************************************
2805 Creates neural network with NIn inputs, NOut outputs, without hidden
2806 layers, with linear output layer. Network weights are filled with small
2807 random values.
2808 
2809  -- ALGLIB --
2810  Copyright 04.11.2007 by Bochkanov Sergey
2811 *************************************************************************/
2812 void mlpcreate0(const ae_int_t nin, const ae_int_t nout, multilayerperceptron &network, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
2813 
2814 
2815 /*************************************************************************
2816 Same as MLPCreate0, but with one hidden layer (NHid neurons) with
2817 non-linear activation function. Output layer is linear.
2818 
2819  -- ALGLIB --
2820  Copyright 04.11.2007 by Bochkanov Sergey
2821 *************************************************************************/
2822 void mlpcreate1(const ae_int_t nin, const ae_int_t nhid, const ae_int_t nout, multilayerperceptron &network, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
2823 
2824 
2825 /*************************************************************************
2826 Same as MLPCreate0, but with two hidden layers (NHid1 and NHid2 neurons)
2827 with non-linear activation function. Output layer is linear.
2828  $ALL
2829 
2830  -- ALGLIB --
2831  Copyright 04.11.2007 by Bochkanov Sergey
2832 *************************************************************************/
2833 void mlpcreate2(const ae_int_t nin, const ae_int_t nhid1, const ae_int_t nhid2, const ae_int_t nout, multilayerperceptron &network, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
2834 
2835 
2836 /*************************************************************************
2837 Creates neural network with NIn inputs, NOut outputs, without hidden
2838 layers with non-linear output layer. Network weights are filled with small
2839 random values.
2840 
2841 Activation function of the output layer takes values:
2842 
2843  (B, +INF), if D>=0
2844 
2845 or
2846 
2847  (-INF, B), if D<0.
2848 
2849 
2850  -- ALGLIB --
2851  Copyright 30.03.2008 by Bochkanov Sergey
2852 *************************************************************************/
2853 void mlpcreateb0(const ae_int_t nin, const ae_int_t nout, const double b, const double d, multilayerperceptron &network, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
2854 
2855

2857 Same as MLPCreateB0 but with non-linear hidden layer.
2858

2860  Copyright 30.03.2008 by Bochkanov Sergey
2861 *************************************************************************/
2862 void mlpcreateb1(const ae_int_t nin, const ae_int_t nhid, const ae_int_t nout, const double b, const double d, multilayerperceptron &network, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
2863 
2864 
2865 /*************************************************************************

2869  Copyright 30.03.2008 by Bochkanov Sergey
2870 *************************************************************************/
2871 void mlpcreateb2(const ae_int_t nin, const ae_int_t nhid1, const ae_int_t nhid2, const ae_int_t nout, const double b, const double d, multilayerperceptron &network, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
2872 
2873 
2874 /*************************************************************************

2902 
2903 /*************************************************************************
2904 Creates classifier network with NIn inputs and NOut possible classes.
2905 Network contains no hidden layers and linear output layer with SOFTMAX-
2906 normalization (so outputs sums up to 1.0 and converge to posterior
2907 probabilities).
2908 
2909  -- ALGLIB --
2910  Copyright 04.11.2007 by Bochkanov Sergey
2911 *************************************************************************/
2912 void mlpcreatec0(const ae_int_t nin, const ae_int_t nout, multilayerperceptron &network, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);

2938

2940  Network2 - copy
2941

2943  Copyright 04.11.2007 by Bochkanov Sergey

2945 void mlpcopy(const multilayerperceptron &network1, multilayerperceptron &network2, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);

2947 
2948 /*************************************************************************
2949 This function copies tunable parameters (weights/means/sigmas) from one
2950 network to another with same architecture. It performs some rudimentary
2951 checks that architectures are same, and throws exception if check fails.
2952 
2953 It is intended for fast copying of states between two network which are
2954 known to have same geometry.
2955 
2956 INPUT PARAMETERS:
2957  Network1 - source, must be correctly initialized
2958  Network2 - target, must have same architecture
2959 
2960 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
2961  Network2 - network state is copied from source to target
2962 
2963  -- ALGLIB --
2964  Copyright 20.06.2013 by Bochkanov Sergey
2965 *************************************************************************/
2966 void mlpcopytunableparameters(const multilayerperceptron &network1, const multilayerperceptron &network2, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
2967

3020 *************************************************************************/

3033 /*************************************************************************
3034 Tells whether network is SOFTMAX-normalized (i.e. classifier) or not.
3035 
3036  -- ALGLIB --
3037  Copyright 04.11.2007 by Bochkanov Sergey
3038 *************************************************************************/
3039 bool mlpissoftmax(const multilayerperceptron &network, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
3040 
3041 
3042 /*************************************************************************
3043 This function returns total number of layers (including input, hidden and
3044 output layers).
3045 
3046  -- ALGLIB --
3047  Copyright 25.03.2011 by Bochkanov Sergey
3048 *************************************************************************/
3049 ae_int_t mlpgetlayerscount(const multilayerperceptron &network, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
3050 
3051 
3052 /*************************************************************************
3053 This function returns size of K-th layer.
3054 
3055 K=0 corresponds to input layer, K=CNT-1 corresponds to output layer.
3056 
3057 Size of the output layer is always equal to the number of outputs, although
3058 when we have softmax-normalized network, last neuron doesn't have any
3059 connections - it is just zero.
3060 
3061  -- ALGLIB --
3062  Copyright 25.03.2011 by Bochkanov Sergey
3063 *************************************************************************/
3064 ae_int_t mlpgetlayersize(const multilayerperceptron &network, const ae_int_t k, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
3065 
3066 
3067 /*************************************************************************
3068 This function returns offset/scaling coefficients for I-th input of the
3069 network.
3070 
3071 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3072  Network - network
3073  I - input index
3074 
3075 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
3076  Mean - mean term
3077  Sigma - sigma term, guaranteed to be nonzero.
3078 
3079 I-th input is passed through linear transformation
3080  IN[i] = (IN[i]-Mean)/Sigma
3081 before feeding to the network
3082 
3083  -- ALGLIB --
3084  Copyright 25.03.2011 by Bochkanov Sergey
3085 *************************************************************************/
3086 void mlpgetinputscaling(const multilayerperceptron &network, const ae_int_t i, double &mean, double &sigma, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
3087 
3088 
3089 /*************************************************************************
3090 This function returns offset/scaling coefficients for I-th output of the
3091 network.
3092 
3093 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3094  Network - network
3095  I - input index
3096 
3097 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
3098  Mean - mean term
3099  Sigma - sigma term, guaranteed to be nonzero.
3100 
3101 I-th output is passed through linear transformation
3102  OUT[i] = OUT[i]*Sigma+Mean
3103 before returning it to user. In case we have SOFTMAX-normalized network,
3104 we return (Mean,Sigma)=(0.0,1.0).
3105 
3106  -- ALGLIB --
3107  Copyright 25.03.2011 by Bochkanov Sergey
3108 *************************************************************************/
3109 void mlpgetoutputscaling(const multilayerperceptron &network, const ae_int_t i, double &mean, double &sigma, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
3110 
3111 
3112 /*************************************************************************
3113 This function returns information about Ith neuron of Kth layer
3114 
3115 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3116  Network - network
3117  K - layer index
3118  I - neuron index (within layer)
3119 
3120 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
3121  FKind - activation function type (used by MLPActivationFunction())
3122  this value is zero for input or linear neurons
3123  Threshold - also called offset, bias
3124  zero for input neurons
3125 
3126 NOTE: this function throws exception if layer or neuron with given index
3127 do not exists.
3128 
3129  -- ALGLIB --
3130  Copyright 25.03.2011 by Bochkanov Sergey
3131 *************************************************************************/
3132 void mlpgetneuroninfo(const multilayerperceptron &network, const ae_int_t k, const ae_int_t i, ae_int_t &fkind, double &threshold, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
3133 
3134 
3135 /*************************************************************************
3136 This function returns information about connection from I0-th neuron of
3137 K0-th layer to I1-th neuron of K1-th layer.
3138 
3139 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3140  Network - network
3141  K0 - layer index
3142  I0 - neuron index (within layer)
3143  K1 - layer index
3144  I1 - neuron index (within layer)
3145 
3146 RESULT:
3147  connection weight (zero for non-existent connections)
3148 
3149 This function:
3150 1. throws exception if layer or neuron with given index do not exists.
3151 2. returns zero if neurons exist, but there is no connection between them
3152 
3153  -- ALGLIB --
3154  Copyright 25.03.2011 by Bochkanov Sergey
3155 *************************************************************************/
3156 double mlpgetweight(const multilayerperceptron &network, const ae_int_t k0, const ae_int_t i0, const ae_int_t k1, const ae_int_t i1, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
3157 
3158 
3159 /*************************************************************************
3160 This function sets offset/scaling coefficients for I-th input of the
3161 network.
3162 
3163 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3164  Network - network
3165  I - input index
3166  Mean - mean term
3167  Sigma - sigma term (if zero, will be replaced by 1.0)
3168 
3169 NTE: I-th input is passed through linear transformation
3170  IN[i] = (IN[i]-Mean)/Sigma
3171 before feeding to the network. This function sets Mean and Sigma.
3172 
3173  -- ALGLIB --
3174  Copyright 25.03.2011 by Bochkanov Sergey
3175 *************************************************************************/
3176 void mlpsetinputscaling(const multilayerperceptron &network, const ae_int_t i, const double mean, const double sigma, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
3177 
3178 
3179 /*************************************************************************
3180 This function sets offset/scaling coefficients for I-th output of the
3181 network.
3182 
3183 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3184  Network - network
3185  I - input index
3186  Mean - mean term
3187  Sigma - sigma term (if zero, will be replaced by 1.0)
3188 
3189 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
3190 
3191 NOTE: I-th output is passed through linear transformation
3192  OUT[i] = OUT[i]*Sigma+Mean
3193 before returning it to user. This function sets Sigma/Mean. In case we
3194 have SOFTMAX-normalized network, you can not set (Sigma,Mean) to anything
3195 other than(0.0,1.0) - this function will throw exception.
3196 
3197  -- ALGLIB --
3198  Copyright 25.03.2011 by Bochkanov Sergey
3199 *************************************************************************/
3200 void mlpsetoutputscaling(const multilayerperceptron &network, const ae_int_t i, const double mean, const double sigma, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
3201 
3202 
3203 /*************************************************************************
3204 This function modifies information about Ith neuron of Kth layer
3205 
3206 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3207  Network - network
3208  K - layer index
3209  I - neuron index (within layer)
3210  FKind - activation function type (used by MLPActivationFunction())
3211  this value must be zero for input neurons
3212  (you can not set activation function for input neurons)
3213  Threshold - also called offset, bias
3214  this value must be zero for input neurons
3215  (you can not set threshold for input neurons)
3216 
3217 NOTES:
3218 1. this function throws exception if layer or neuron with given index do
3219  not exists.
3220 2. this function also throws exception when you try to set non-linear
3221  activation function for input neurons (any kind of network) or for output
3222  neurons of classifier network.
3223 3. this function throws exception when you try to set non-zero threshold for
3224  input neurons (any kind of network).
3225 
3226  -- ALGLIB --
3227  Copyright 25.03.2011 by Bochkanov Sergey
3228 *************************************************************************/
3229 void mlpsetneuroninfo(const multilayerperceptron &network, const ae_int_t k, const ae_int_t i, const ae_int_t fkind, const double threshold, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
3230 
3231 
3232 /*************************************************************************
3233 This function modifies information about connection from I0-th neuron of
3234 K0-th layer to I1-th neuron of K1-th layer.
3235 
3236 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3237  Network - network
3238  K0 - layer index
3239  I0 - neuron index (within layer)
3240  K1 - layer index
3241  I1 - neuron index (within layer)
3242  W - connection weight (must be zero for non-existent
3243  connections)
3244 
3245 This function:
3246 1. throws exception if layer or neuron with given index do not exists.
3247 2. throws exception if you try to set non-zero weight for non-existent
3248  connection
3249 
3250  -- ALGLIB --
3251  Copyright 25.03.2011 by Bochkanov Sergey
3252 *************************************************************************/
3253 void mlpsetweight(const multilayerperceptron &network, const ae_int_t k0, const ae_int_t i0, const ae_int_t k1, const ae_int_t i1, const double w, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
3254 
3255 
3256 /*************************************************************************
3257 Neural network activation function
3258 
3259 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3260  NET - neuron input
3261  K - function index (zero for linear function)
3262 
3263 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
3264  F - function
3265  DF - its derivative
3266  D2F - its second derivative
3267 
3268  -- ALGLIB --
3269  Copyright 04.11.2007 by Bochkanov Sergey
3270 *************************************************************************/
3271 void mlpactivationfunction(const double net, const ae_int_t k, double &f, double &df, double &d2f, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
3272 
3273 
3274 /*************************************************************************
3275 Procesing
3276 
3277 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3278  Network - neural network
3279  X - input vector, array[0..NIn-1].
3280 
3281 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
3282  Y - result. Regression estimate when solving regression task,
3283  vector of posterior probabilities for classification task.
3284 
3285 See also MLPProcessI
3286 
3287  -- ALGLIB --
3288  Copyright 04.11.2007 by Bochkanov Sergey
3289 *************************************************************************/
3290 void mlpprocess(const multilayerperceptron &network, const real_1d_array &x, real_1d_array &y, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
3291 
3292 
3293 /*************************************************************************
3294 'interactive' variant of MLPProcess for languages like Python which
3295 support constructs like "Y = MLPProcess(NN,X)" and interactive mode of the
3296 interpreter
3297 
3298 This function allocates new array on each call, so it is significantly
3299 slower than its 'non-interactive' counterpart, but it is more convenient
3300 when you call it from command line.
3301 
3302  -- ALGLIB --
3303  Copyright 21.09.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
3304 *************************************************************************/
3305 void mlpprocessi(const multilayerperceptron &network, const real_1d_array &x, real_1d_array &y, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
3306 
3307 
3308 /*************************************************************************
3309 Error of the neural network on dataset.
3310 
3311  ! COMMERCIAL EDITION OF ALGLIB:
3312  !
3313  ! Commercial Edition of ALGLIB includes following important improvements
3314  ! of this function:
3315  ! * high-performance native backend with same C# interface (C# version)
3316  ! * multithreading support (C++ and C# versions)
3317  !
3318  ! We recommend you to read 'Working with commercial version' section of
3319  ! ALGLIB Reference Manual in order to find out how to use performance-
3320  ! related features provided by commercial edition of ALGLIB.
3321 
3322 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3323  Network - neural network;
3324  XY - training set, see below for information on the
3325  training set format;
3326  NPoints - points count.
3327 
3328 RESULT:
3329  sum-of-squares error, SUM(sqr(y[i]-desired_y[i])/2)
3330 
3331 DATASET FORMAT:
3332 
3333 This function uses two different dataset formats - one for regression
3334 networks, another one for classification networks.
3335 
3336 For regression networks with NIn inputs and NOut outputs following dataset
3337 format is used:
3338 * dataset is given by NPoints*(NIn+NOut) matrix
3339 * each row corresponds to one example
3340 * first NIn columns are inputs, next NOut columns are outputs
3341 
3342 For classification networks with NIn inputs and NClasses clases following
3343 dataset format is used:
3344 * dataset is given by NPoints*(NIn+1) matrix
3345 * each row corresponds to one example
3346 * first NIn columns are inputs, last column stores class number (from 0 to
3347  NClasses-1).
3348 
3349  -- ALGLIB --
3350  Copyright 04.11.2007 by Bochkanov Sergey
3351 *************************************************************************/
3352 double mlperror(const multilayerperceptron &network, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
3353 
3354 
3355 /*************************************************************************
3356 Error of the neural network on dataset given by sparse matrix.
3357 
3358  ! COMMERCIAL EDITION OF ALGLIB:
3359  !
3360  ! Commercial Edition of ALGLIB includes following important improvements
3361  ! of this function:
3362  ! * high-performance native backend with same C# interface (C# version)
3363  ! * multithreading support (C++ and C# versions)
3364  !
3365  ! We recommend you to read 'Working with commercial version' section of
3366  ! ALGLIB Reference Manual in order to find out how to use performance-
3367  ! related features provided by commercial edition of ALGLIB.
3368 
3369 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3370  Network - neural network
3371  XY - training set, see below for information on the
3372  training set format. This function checks correctness
3373  of the dataset (no NANs/INFs, class numbers are
3374  correct) and throws exception when incorrect dataset
3375  is passed. Sparse matrix must use CRS format for
3376  storage.
3377  NPoints - points count, >=0
3378 
3379 RESULT:
3380  sum-of-squares error, SUM(sqr(y[i]-desired_y[i])/2)
3381 
3382 DATASET FORMAT:
3383 
3384 This function uses two different dataset formats - one for regression
3385 networks, another one for classification networks.
3386 
3387 For regression networks with NIn inputs and NOut outputs following dataset
3388 format is used:
3389 * dataset is given by NPoints*(NIn+NOut) matrix
3390 * each row corresponds to one example
3391 * first NIn columns are inputs, next NOut columns are outputs
3392 
3393 For classification networks with NIn inputs and NClasses clases following
3394 dataset format is used:
3395 * dataset is given by NPoints*(NIn+1) matrix
3396 * each row corresponds to one example
3397 * first NIn columns are inputs, last column stores class number (from 0 to
3398  NClasses-1).
3399 
3400  -- ALGLIB --
3401  Copyright 23.07.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
3402 *************************************************************************/
3403 double mlperrorsparse(const multilayerperceptron &network, const sparsematrix &xy, const ae_int_t npoints, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
3404 
3405 
3406 /*************************************************************************
3407 Natural error function for neural network, internal subroutine.
3408 
3409 NOTE: this function is single-threaded. Unlike other error function, it
3410 receives no speed-up from being executed in SMP mode.
3411 
3412  -- ALGLIB --
3413  Copyright 04.11.2007 by Bochkanov Sergey
3414 *************************************************************************/
3415 double mlperrorn(const multilayerperceptron &network, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t ssize, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
3416 
3417 
3418 /*************************************************************************
3419 Classification error of the neural network on dataset.
3420 
3421  ! COMMERCIAL EDITION OF ALGLIB:
3422  !
3423  ! Commercial Edition of ALGLIB includes following important improvements
3424  ! of this function:
3425  ! * high-performance native backend with same C# interface (C# version)
3426  ! * multithreading support (C++ and C# versions)
3427  !
3428  ! We recommend you to read 'Working with commercial version' section of
3429  ! ALGLIB Reference Manual in order to find out how to use performance-
3430  ! related features provided by commercial edition of ALGLIB.
3431 
3432 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3433  Network - neural network;
3434  XY - training set, see below for information on the
3435  training set format;
3436  NPoints - points count.
3437 
3438 RESULT:
3439  classification error (number of misclassified cases)
3440 
3441 DATASET FORMAT:
3442 
3443 This function uses two different dataset formats - one for regression
3444 networks, another one for classification networks.
3445 
3446 For regression networks with NIn inputs and NOut outputs following dataset
3447 format is used:
3448 * dataset is given by NPoints*(NIn+NOut) matrix
3449 * each row corresponds to one example
3450 * first NIn columns are inputs, next NOut columns are outputs
3451 
3452 For classification networks with NIn inputs and NClasses clases following
3453 dataset format is used:
3454 * dataset is given by NPoints*(NIn+1) matrix
3455 * each row corresponds to one example
3456 * first NIn columns are inputs, last column stores class number (from 0 to
3457  NClasses-1).
3458 
3459  -- ALGLIB --
3460  Copyright 04.11.2007 by Bochkanov Sergey
3461 *************************************************************************/
3462 ae_int_t mlpclserror(const multilayerperceptron &network, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
3463 
3464 
3465 /*************************************************************************
3466 Relative classification error on the test set.
3467 
3468  ! COMMERCIAL EDITION OF ALGLIB:
3469  !
3470  ! Commercial Edition of ALGLIB includes following important improvements
3471  ! of this function:
3472  ! * high-performance native backend with same C# interface (C# version)
3473  ! * multithreading support (C++ and C# versions)
3474  !
3475  ! We recommend you to read 'Working with commercial version' section of
3476  ! ALGLIB Reference Manual in order to find out how to use performance-
3477  ! related features provided by commercial edition of ALGLIB.
3478 
3479 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3480  Network - neural network;
3481  XY - training set, see below for information on the
3482  training set format;
3483  NPoints - points count.
3484 
3485 RESULT:
3486 Percent of incorrectly classified cases. Works both for classifier
3487 networks and general purpose networks used as classifiers.
3488 
3489 DATASET FORMAT:
3490 
3491 This function uses two different dataset formats - one for regression
3492 networks, another one for classification networks.
3493 
3494 For regression networks with NIn inputs and NOut outputs following dataset
3495 format is used:
3496 * dataset is given by NPoints*(NIn+NOut) matrix
3497 * each row corresponds to one example
3498 * first NIn columns are inputs, next NOut columns are outputs
3499 
3500 For classification networks with NIn inputs and NClasses clases following
3501 dataset format is used:
3502 * dataset is given by NPoints*(NIn+1) matrix
3503 * each row corresponds to one example
3504 * first NIn columns are inputs, last column stores class number (from 0 to
3505  NClasses-1).
3506 
3507  -- ALGLIB --
3508  Copyright 25.12.2008 by Bochkanov Sergey
3509 *************************************************************************/
3510 double mlprelclserror(const multilayerperceptron &network, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
3511 
3512 
3513 /*************************************************************************
3514 Relative classification error on the test set given by sparse matrix.
3515 
3516  ! COMMERCIAL EDITION OF ALGLIB:
3517  !
3518  ! Commercial Edition of ALGLIB includes following important improvements
3519  ! of this function:
3520  ! * high-performance native backend with same C# interface (C# version)
3521  ! * multithreading support (C++ and C# versions)
3522  !
3523  ! We recommend you to read 'Working with commercial version' section of
3524  ! ALGLIB Reference Manual in order to find out how to use performance-
3525  ! related features provided by commercial edition of ALGLIB.
3526 
3527 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3528  Network - neural network;
3529  XY - training set, see below for information on the
3530  training set format. Sparse matrix must use CRS format
3531  for storage.
3532  NPoints - points count, >=0.
3533 
3534 RESULT:
3535 Percent of incorrectly classified cases. Works both for classifier
3536 networks and general purpose networks used as classifiers.
3537 
3538 DATASET FORMAT:
3539 
3540 This function uses two different dataset formats - one for regression
3541 networks, another one for classification networks.
3542 
3543 For regression networks with NIn inputs and NOut outputs following dataset
3544 format is used:
3545 * dataset is given by NPoints*(NIn+NOut) matrix
3546 * each row corresponds to one example
3547 * first NIn columns are inputs, next NOut columns are outputs
3548

3550 dataset format is used:
3551 * dataset is given by NPoints*(NIn+1) matrix
3552 * each row corresponds to one example
3553 * first NIn columns are inputs, last column stores class number (from 0 to
3554  NClasses-1).
3555 
3556  -- ALGLIB --
3557  Copyright 09.08.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
3558 *************************************************************************/
3559 double mlprelclserrorsparse(const multilayerperceptron &network, const sparsematrix &xy, const ae_int_t npoints, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
3560 
3561 
3562 /*************************************************************************
3563 Average cross-entropy (in bits per element) on the test set.
3564 
3565  ! COMMERCIAL EDITION OF ALGLIB:
3566  !
3567  ! Commercial Edition of ALGLIB includes following important improvements
3568  ! of this function:
3569  ! * high-performance native backend with same C# interface (C# version)
3570  ! * multithreading support (C++ and C# versions)
3571  !
3572  ! We recommend you to read 'Working with commercial version' section of
3573  ! ALGLIB Reference Manual in order to find out how to use performance-
3574  ! related features provided by commercial edition of ALGLIB.
3575 
3576 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3577  Network - neural network;
3578  XY - training set, see below for information on the
3579  training set format;
3580  NPoints - points count.
3581 
3582 RESULT:
3583 CrossEntropy/(NPoints*LN(2)).
3584 Zero if network solves regression task.
3585 
3586 DATASET FORMAT:
3587 
3588 This function uses two different dataset formats - one for regression
3589 networks, another one for classification networks.
3590 
3591 For regression networks with NIn inputs and NOut outputs following dataset
3592 format is used:
3593 * dataset is given by NPoints*(NIn+NOut) matrix
3594 * each row corresponds to one example
3595 * first NIn columns are inputs, next NOut columns are outputs
3596 
3597 For classification networks with NIn inputs and NClasses clases following
3598 dataset format is used:
3599 * dataset is given by NPoints*(NIn+1) matrix
3600 * each row corresponds to one example
3601 * first NIn columns are inputs, last column stores class number (from 0 to
3602  NClasses-1).
3603 
3604  -- ALGLIB --
3605  Copyright 08.01.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
3606 *************************************************************************/
3607 double mlpavgce(const multilayerperceptron &network, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
3608 
3609 
3610 /*************************************************************************
3611 Average cross-entropy (in bits per element) on the test set given by
3612 sparse matrix.
3613 
3614  ! COMMERCIAL EDITION OF ALGLIB:
3615  !
3616  ! Commercial Edition of ALGLIB includes following important improvements
3617  ! of this function:
3618  ! * high-performance native backend with same C# interface (C# version)
3619  ! * multithreading support (C++ and C# versions)
3620  !
3621  ! We recommend you to read 'Working with commercial version' section of
3622  ! ALGLIB Reference Manual in order to find out how to use performance-
3623  ! related features provided by commercial edition of ALGLIB.
3624 
3625 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3626  Network - neural network;
3627  XY - training set, see below for information on the
3628  training set format. This function checks correctness
3629  of the dataset (no NANs/INFs, class numbers are
3630  correct) and throws exception when incorrect dataset
3631  is passed. Sparse matrix must use CRS format for
3632  storage.
3633  NPoints - points count, >=0.
3634 
3635 RESULT:
3636 CrossEntropy/(NPoints*LN(2)).
3637 Zero if network solves regression task.
3638 
3639 DATASET FORMAT:
3640 
3641 This function uses two different dataset formats - one for regression
3642 networks, another one for classification networks.
3643 
3644 For regression networks with NIn inputs and NOut outputs following dataset
3645 format is used:
3646 * dataset is given by NPoints*(NIn+NOut) matrix
3647 * each row corresponds to one example
3648 * first NIn columns are inputs, next NOut columns are outputs
3649 
3650 For classification networks with NIn inputs and NClasses clases following
3651 dataset format is used:
3652 * dataset is given by NPoints*(NIn+1) matrix
3653 * each row corresponds to one example
3654 * first NIn columns are inputs, last column stores class number (from 0 to
3655  NClasses-1).
3656 
3657  -- ALGLIB --
3658  Copyright 9.08.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
3659 *************************************************************************/
3660 double mlpavgcesparse(const multilayerperceptron &network, const sparsematrix &xy, const ae_int_t npoints, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
3661 
3662 
3663 /*************************************************************************
3664 RMS error on the test set given.
3665 
3666  ! COMMERCIAL EDITION OF ALGLIB:
3667  !
3668  ! Commercial Edition of ALGLIB includes following important improvements
3669  ! of this function:
3670  ! * high-performance native backend with same C# interface (C# version)
3671  ! * multithreading support (C++ and C# versions)
3672  !
3673  ! We recommend you to read 'Working with commercial version' section of
3674  ! ALGLIB Reference Manual in order to find out how to use performance-
3675  ! related features provided by commercial edition of ALGLIB.
3676 
3677 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3678  Network - neural network;
3679  XY - training set, see below for information on the
3680  training set format;
3681  NPoints - points count.
3682 
3683 RESULT:
3684 Root mean square error. Its meaning for regression task is obvious. As for
3685 classification task, RMS error means error when estimating posterior
3686 probabilities.
3687 
3688 DATASET FORMAT:
3689 
3690 This function uses two different dataset formats - one for regression
3691 networks, another one for classification networks.
3692 
3693 For regression networks with NIn inputs and NOut outputs following dataset
3694 format is used:
3695 * dataset is given by NPoints*(NIn+NOut) matrix
3696 * each row corresponds to one example
3697 * first NIn columns are inputs, next NOut columns are outputs
3698 
3699 For classification networks with NIn inputs and NClasses clases following
3700 dataset format is used:
3701 * dataset is given by NPoints*(NIn+1) matrix
3702 * each row corresponds to one example
3703 * first NIn columns are inputs, last column stores class number (from 0 to
3704  NClasses-1).
3705 
3706  -- ALGLIB --
3707  Copyright 04.11.2007 by Bochkanov Sergey
3708 *************************************************************************/
3709 double mlprmserror(const multilayerperceptron &network, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
3710 
3711 
3712 /*************************************************************************
3713 RMS error on the test set given by sparse matrix.
3714 
3715  ! COMMERCIAL EDITION OF ALGLIB:
3716  !
3717  ! Commercial Edition of ALGLIB includes following important improvements
3718  ! of this function:
3719  ! * high-performance native backend with same C# interface (C# version)
3720  ! * multithreading support (C++ and C# versions)
3721  !
3722  ! We recommend you to read 'Working with commercial version' section of
3723  ! ALGLIB Reference Manual in order to find out how to use performance-
3724  ! related features provided by commercial edition of ALGLIB.
3725 
3726 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3727  Network - neural network;
3728  XY - training set, see below for information on the
3729  training set format. This function checks correctness
3730  of the dataset (no NANs/INFs, class numbers are
3731  correct) and throws exception when incorrect dataset
3732  is passed. Sparse matrix must use CRS format for
3733  storage.
3734  NPoints - points count, >=0.
3735 
3736 RESULT:
3737 Root mean square error. Its meaning for regression task is obvious. As for
3738 classification task, RMS error means error when estimating posterior
3739 probabilities.
3740 
3741 DATASET FORMAT:
3742 
3743 This function uses two different dataset formats - one for regression
3744 networks, another one for classification networks.
3745 
3746 For regression networks with NIn inputs and NOut outputs following dataset
3747 format is used:
3748 * dataset is given by NPoints*(NIn+NOut) matrix
3749 * each row corresponds to one example
3750 * first NIn columns are inputs, next NOut columns are outputs
3751 
3752 For classification networks with NIn inputs and NClasses clases following
3753 dataset format is used:
3754 * dataset is given by NPoints*(NIn+1) matrix
3755 * each row corresponds to one example
3756 * first NIn columns are inputs, last column stores class number (from 0 to
3757  NClasses-1).
3758 
3759  -- ALGLIB --
3760  Copyright 09.08.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
3761 *************************************************************************/
3762 double mlprmserrorsparse(const multilayerperceptron &network, const sparsematrix &xy, const ae_int_t npoints, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
3763 
3764 
3765 /*************************************************************************
3766 Average absolute error on the test set.
3767 
3768  ! COMMERCIAL EDITION OF ALGLIB:
3769  !
3770  ! Commercial Edition of ALGLIB includes following important improvements
3771  ! of this function:
3772  ! * high-performance native backend with same C# interface (C# version)
3773  ! * multithreading support (C++ and C# versions)
3774  !
3775  ! We recommend you to read 'Working with commercial version' section of
3776  ! ALGLIB Reference Manual in order to find out how to use performance-
3777  ! related features provided by commercial edition of ALGLIB.
3778 
3779 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3780  Network - neural network;
3781  XY - training set, see below for information on the
3782  training set format;
3783  NPoints - points count.
3784 
3785 RESULT:
3786 Its meaning for regression task is obvious. As for classification task, it
3787 means average error when estimating posterior probabilities.
3788 
3789 DATASET FORMAT:
3790 
3791 This function uses two different dataset formats - one for regression
3792 networks, another one for classification networks.
3793 
3794 For regression networks with NIn inputs and NOut outputs following dataset
3795 format is used:
3796 * dataset is given by NPoints*(NIn+NOut) matrix
3797 * each row corresponds to one example
3798 * first NIn columns are inputs, next NOut columns are outputs
3799 
3800 For classification networks with NIn inputs and NClasses clases following
3801 dataset format is used:
3802 * dataset is given by NPoints*(NIn+1) matrix
3803 * each row corresponds to one example
3804 * first NIn columns are inputs, last column stores class number (from 0 to
3805  NClasses-1).
3806 
3807  -- ALGLIB --
3808  Copyright 11.03.2008 by Bochkanov Sergey
3809 *************************************************************************/
3810 double mlpavgerror(const multilayerperceptron &network, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
3811 
3812 
3813 /*************************************************************************
3814 Average absolute error on the test set given by sparse matrix.
3815 
3816  ! COMMERCIAL EDITION OF ALGLIB:
3817  !
3818  ! Commercial Edition of ALGLIB includes following important improvements
3819  ! of this function:
3820  ! * high-performance native backend with same C# interface (C# version)
3821  ! * multithreading support (C++ and C# versions)
3822  !
3823  ! We recommend you to read 'Working with commercial version' section of
3824  ! ALGLIB Reference Manual in order to find out how to use performance-
3825  ! related features provided by commercial edition of ALGLIB.
3826 
3827 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3828  Network - neural network;
3829  XY - training set, see below for information on the
3830  training set format. This function checks correctness
3831  of the dataset (no NANs/INFs, class numbers are
3832  correct) and throws exception when incorrect dataset
3833  is passed. Sparse matrix must use CRS format for
3834  storage.
3835  NPoints - points count, >=0.
3836 
3837 RESULT:
3838 Its meaning for regression task is obvious. As for classification task, it
3839 means average error when estimating posterior probabilities.
3840 
3841 DATASET FORMAT:
3842 
3843 This function uses two different dataset formats - one for regression
3844 networks, another one for classification networks.
3845 
3846 For regression networks with NIn inputs and NOut outputs following dataset
3847 format is used:
3848 * dataset is given by NPoints*(NIn+NOut) matrix
3849 * each row corresponds to one example
3850 * first NIn columns are inputs, next NOut columns are outputs
3851 
3852 For classification networks with NIn inputs and NClasses clases following
3853 dataset format is used:
3854 * dataset is given by NPoints*(NIn+1) matrix
3855 * each row corresponds to one example
3856 * first NIn columns are inputs, last column stores class number (from 0 to
3857  NClasses-1).
3858 
3859  -- ALGLIB --
3860  Copyright 09.08.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
3861 *************************************************************************/
3862 double mlpavgerrorsparse(const multilayerperceptron &network, const sparsematrix &xy, const ae_int_t npoints, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
3863 
3864 
3865 /*************************************************************************
3866 Average relative error on the test set.
3867 
3868  ! COMMERCIAL EDITION OF ALGLIB:
3869  !
3870  ! Commercial Edition of ALGLIB includes following important improvements
3871  ! of this function:
3872  ! * high-performance native backend with same C# interface (C# version)
3873  ! * multithreading support (C++ and C# versions)
3874  !
3875  ! We recommend you to read 'Working with commercial version' section of
3876  ! ALGLIB Reference Manual in order to find out how to use performance-
3877  ! related features provided by commercial edition of ALGLIB.
3878 
3879 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3880  Network - neural network;
3881  XY - training set, see below for information on the
3882  training set format;
3883  NPoints - points count.
3884 
3885 RESULT:
3886 Its meaning for regression task is obvious. As for classification task, it
3887 means average relative error when estimating posterior probability of
3888 belonging to the correct class.
3889 
3890 DATASET FORMAT:
3891 
3892 This function uses two different dataset formats - one for regression
3893 networks, another one for classification networks.
3894 
3895 For regression networks with NIn inputs and NOut outputs following dataset
3896 format is used:
3897 * dataset is given by NPoints*(NIn+NOut) matrix
3898 * each row corresponds to one example
3899 * first NIn columns are inputs, next NOut columns are outputs
3900 
3901 For classification networks with NIn inputs and NClasses clases following
3902 dataset format is used:
3903 * dataset is given by NPoints*(NIn+1) matrix
3904 * each row corresponds to one example
3905 * first NIn columns are inputs, last column stores class number (from 0 to
3906  NClasses-1).
3907 
3908  -- ALGLIB --
3909  Copyright 11.03.2008 by Bochkanov Sergey
3910 *************************************************************************/
3911 double mlpavgrelerror(const multilayerperceptron &network, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
3912 
3913 
3914 /*************************************************************************
3915 Average relative error on the test set given by sparse matrix.
3916 
3917  ! COMMERCIAL EDITION OF ALGLIB:
3918  !
3919  ! Commercial Edition of ALGLIB includes following important improvements
3920  ! of this function:
3921  ! * high-performance native backend with same C# interface (C# version)
3922  ! * multithreading support (C++ and C# versions)
3923  !
3924  ! We recommend you to read 'Working with commercial version' section of
3925  ! ALGLIB Reference Manual in order to find out how to use performance-
3926  ! related features provided by commercial edition of ALGLIB.
3927 
3928 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3929  Network - neural network;
3930  XY - training set, see below for information on the
3931  training set format. This function checks correctness
3932  of the dataset (no NANs/INFs, class numbers are
3933  correct) and throws exception when incorrect dataset
3934  is passed. Sparse matrix must use CRS format for
3935  storage.
3936  NPoints - points count, >=0.
3937 
3938 RESULT:
3939 Its meaning for regression task is obvious. As for classification task, it
3940 means average relative error when estimating posterior probability of
3941 belonging to the correct class.
3942 
3943 DATASET FORMAT:
3944 
3945 This function uses two different dataset formats - one for regression
3946 networks, another one for classification networks.
3947 
3948 For regression networks with NIn inputs and NOut outputs following dataset
3949 format is used:
3950 * dataset is given by NPoints*(NIn+NOut) matrix
3951 * each row corresponds to one example
3952 * first NIn columns are inputs, next NOut columns are outputs
3953 
3954 For classification networks with NIn inputs and NClasses clases following
3955 dataset format is used:
3956 * dataset is given by NPoints*(NIn+1) matrix
3957 * each row corresponds to one example
3958 * first NIn columns are inputs, last column stores class number (from 0 to
3959  NClasses-1).
3960 
3961  -- ALGLIB --
3962  Copyright 09.08.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
3963 *************************************************************************/
3964 double mlpavgrelerrorsparse(const multilayerperceptron &network, const sparsematrix &xy, const ae_int_t npoints, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
3965 
3966 
3967 /*************************************************************************
3968 Gradient calculation
3969 
3970 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3971  Network - network initialized with one of the network creation funcs
3972  X - input vector, length of array must be at least NIn
3973  DesiredY- desired outputs, length of array must be at least NOut
3974  Grad - possibly preallocated array. If size of array is smaller
3975  than WCount, it will be reallocated. It is recommended to
3976  reuse previously allocated array to reduce allocation
3977  overhead.
3978 
3979 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
3980  E - error function, SUM(sqr(y[i]-desiredy[i])/2,i)
3981  Grad - gradient of E with respect to weights of network, array[WCount]
3982 
3983  -- ALGLIB --
3984  Copyright 04.11.2007 by Bochkanov Sergey
3985 *************************************************************************/
3986 void mlpgrad(const multilayerperceptron &network, const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &desiredy, double &e, real_1d_array &grad, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
3987 
3988 
3989 /*************************************************************************
3990 Gradient calculation (natural error function is used)
3991 
3992 INPUT PARAMETERS:
3993  Network - network initialized with one of the network creation funcs
3994  X - input vector, length of array must be at least NIn
3995  DesiredY- desired outputs, length of array must be at least NOut
3996  Grad - possibly preallocated array. If size of array is smaller
3997  than WCount, it will be reallocated. It is recommended to
3998  reuse previously allocated array to reduce allocation
3999  overhead.
4000 
4001 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
4002  E - error function, sum-of-squares for regression networks,
4003  cross-entropy for classification networks.
4004  Grad - gradient of E with respect to weights of network, array[WCount]
4005 
4006  -- ALGLIB --
4007  Copyright 04.11.2007 by Bochkanov Sergey
4008 *************************************************************************/
4009 void mlpgradn(const multilayerperceptron &network, const real_1d_array &x, const real_1d_array &desiredy, double &e, real_1d_array &grad, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
4010 
4011 
4012 /*************************************************************************
4013 Batch gradient calculation for a set of inputs/outputs
4014 
4015  ! COMMERCIAL EDITION OF ALGLIB:
4016  !
4017  ! Commercial Edition of ALGLIB includes following important improvements
4018  ! of this function:
4019  ! * high-performance native backend with same C# interface (C# version)
4020  ! * multithreading support (C++ and C# versions)
4021  !
4022  ! We recommend you to read 'Working with commercial version' section of
4023  ! ALGLIB Reference Manual in order to find out how to use performance-
4024  ! related features provided by commercial edition of ALGLIB.
4025 
4026 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4027  Network - network initialized with one of the network creation funcs
4028  XY - original dataset in dense format; one sample = one row:
4029  * first NIn columns contain inputs,
4030  * for regression problem, next NOut columns store
4031  desired outputs.
4032  * for classification problem, next column (just one!)
4033  stores class number.
4034  SSize - number of elements in XY
4035  Grad - possibly preallocated array. If size of array is smaller
4036  than WCount, it will be reallocated. It is recommended to
4037  reuse previously allocated array to reduce allocation
4038  overhead.
4039 
4040 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
4041  E - error function, SUM(sqr(y[i]-desiredy[i])/2,i)
4042  Grad - gradient of E with respect to weights of network, array[WCount]
4043 
4044  -- ALGLIB --
4045  Copyright 04.11.2007 by Bochkanov Sergey
4046 *************************************************************************/
4047 void mlpgradbatch(const multilayerperceptron &network, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t ssize, double &e, real_1d_array &grad, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
4048 
4049 
4050 /*************************************************************************
4051 Batch gradient calculation for a set of inputs/outputs given by sparse
4052 matrices
4053 
4054  ! COMMERCIAL EDITION OF ALGLIB:
4055  !
4056  ! Commercial Edition of ALGLIB includes following important improvements
4057  ! of this function:
4058  ! * high-performance native backend with same C# interface (C# version)
4059  ! * multithreading support (C++ and C# versions)
4060  !
4061  ! We recommend you to read 'Working with commercial version' section of
4062  ! ALGLIB Reference Manual in order to find out how to use performance-
4063  ! related features provided by commercial edition of ALGLIB.
4064 
4065 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4066  Network - network initialized with one of the network creation funcs
4067  XY - original dataset in sparse format; one sample = one row:
4068  * MATRIX MUST BE STORED IN CRS FORMAT
4069  * first NIn columns contain inputs.
4070  * for regression problem, next NOut columns store
4071  desired outputs.
