4072  * for classification problem, next column (just one!)
4073  stores class number.
4074  SSize - number of elements in XY
4075  Grad - possibly preallocated array. If size of array is smaller
4076  than WCount, it will be reallocated. It is recommended to
4077  reuse previously allocated array to reduce allocation
4078  overhead.
4079 
4080 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
4081  E - error function, SUM(sqr(y[i]-desiredy[i])/2,i)
4082  Grad - gradient of E with respect to weights of network, array[WCount]
4083 
4084  -- ALGLIB --
4085  Copyright 26.07.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
4086 *************************************************************************/
4087 void mlpgradbatchsparse(const multilayerperceptron &network, const sparsematrix &xy, const ae_int_t ssize, double &e, real_1d_array &grad, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
4088 
4089 
4090 /*************************************************************************
4091 Batch gradient calculation for a subset of dataset
4092 
4093  ! COMMERCIAL EDITION OF ALGLIB:
4094  !
4095  ! Commercial Edition of ALGLIB includes following important improvements
4096  ! of this function:
4097  ! * high-performance native backend with same C# interface (C# version)
4098  ! * multithreading support (C++ and C# versions)
4099  !
4100  ! We recommend you to read 'Working with commercial version' section of
4101  ! ALGLIB Reference Manual in order to find out how to use performance-
4102  ! related features provided by commercial edition of ALGLIB.
4103 
4104 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4105  Network - network initialized with one of the network creation funcs
4106  XY - original dataset in dense format; one sample = one row:
4107  * first NIn columns contain inputs,
4108  * for regression problem, next NOut columns store
4109  desired outputs.
4110  * for classification problem, next column (just one!)
4111  stores class number.
4112  SetSize - real size of XY, SetSize>=0;
4113  Idx - subset of SubsetSize elements, array[SubsetSize]:
4114  * Idx[I] stores row index in the original dataset which is
4115  given by XY. Gradient is calculated with respect to rows
4116  whose indexes are stored in Idx[].
4117  * Idx[] must store correct indexes; this function throws
4118  an exception in case incorrect index (less than 0 or
4119  larger than rows(XY)) is given
4120  * Idx[] may store indexes in any order and even with
4121  repetitions.
4122  SubsetSize- number of elements in Idx[] array:
4123  * positive value means that subset given by Idx[] is processed
4124  * zero value results in zero gradient
4125  * negative value means that full dataset is processed
4126  Grad - possibly preallocated array. If size of array is smaller
4127  than WCount, it will be reallocated. It is recommended to
4128  reuse previously allocated array to reduce allocation
4129  overhead.
4130 
4131 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
4132  E - error function, SUM(sqr(y[i]-desiredy[i])/2,i)
4133  Grad - gradient of E with respect to weights of network,
4134  array[WCount]
4135 
4136  -- ALGLIB --
4137  Copyright 26.07.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
4138 *************************************************************************/
4139 void mlpgradbatchsubset(const multilayerperceptron &network, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t setsize, const integer_1d_array &idx, const ae_int_t subsetsize, double &e, real_1d_array &grad, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
4140 
4141 
4142 /*************************************************************************
4143 Batch gradient calculation for a set of inputs/outputs for a subset of
4144 dataset given by set of indexes.
4145 
4146  ! COMMERCIAL EDITION OF ALGLIB:
4147  !
4148  ! Commercial Edition of ALGLIB includes following important improvements
4149  ! of this function:
4150  ! * high-performance native backend with same C# interface (C# version)
4151  ! * multithreading support (C++ and C# versions)
4152  !
4153  ! We recommend you to read 'Working with commercial version' section of
4154  ! ALGLIB Reference Manual in order to find out how to use performance-
4155  ! related features provided by commercial edition of ALGLIB.
4156 
4157 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4158  Network - network initialized with one of the network creation funcs
4159  XY - original dataset in sparse format; one sample = one row:
4160  * MATRIX MUST BE STORED IN CRS FORMAT
4161  * first NIn columns contain inputs,
4162  * for regression problem, next NOut columns store
4163  desired outputs.
4164  * for classification problem, next column (just one!)
4165  stores class number.
4166  SetSize - real size of XY, SetSize>=0;
4167  Idx - subset of SubsetSize elements, array[SubsetSize]:
4168  * Idx[I] stores row index in the original dataset which is
4169  given by XY. Gradient is calculated with respect to rows
4170  whose indexes are stored in Idx[].
4171  * Idx[] must store correct indexes; this function throws
4172  an exception in case incorrect index (less than 0 or
4173  larger than rows(XY)) is given
4174  * Idx[] may store indexes in any order and even with
4175  repetitions.
4176  SubsetSize- number of elements in Idx[] array:
4177  * positive value means that subset given by Idx[] is processed
4178  * zero value results in zero gradient
4179  * negative value means that full dataset is processed
4180  Grad - possibly preallocated array. If size of array is smaller
4181  than WCount, it will be reallocated. It is recommended to
4182  reuse previously allocated array to reduce allocation
4183  overhead.
4184 
4185 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
4186  E - error function, SUM(sqr(y[i]-desiredy[i])/2,i)
4187  Grad - gradient of E with respect to weights of network,
4188  array[WCount]
4189 
4190 NOTE: when SubsetSize<0 is used full dataset by call MLPGradBatchSparse
4191  function.
4192 
4193  -- ALGLIB --
4194  Copyright 26.07.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
4195 *************************************************************************/
4196 void mlpgradbatchsparsesubset(const multilayerperceptron &network, const sparsematrix &xy, const ae_int_t setsize, const integer_1d_array &idx, const ae_int_t subsetsize, double &e, real_1d_array &grad, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
4197 
4198 
4199 /*************************************************************************
4200 Batch gradient calculation for a set of inputs/outputs
4201 (natural error function is used)
4202 
4203 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4204  Network - network initialized with one of the network creation funcs
4205  XY - set of inputs/outputs; one sample = one row;
4206  first NIn columns contain inputs,
4207  next NOut columns - desired outputs.
4208  SSize - number of elements in XY
4209  Grad - possibly preallocated array. If size of array is smaller
4210  than WCount, it will be reallocated. It is recommended to
4211  reuse previously allocated array to reduce allocation
4212  overhead.
4213 
4214 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
4215  E - error function, sum-of-squares for regression networks,
4216  cross-entropy for classification networks.
4217  Grad - gradient of E with respect to weights of network, array[WCount]
4218 
4219  -- ALGLIB --
4220  Copyright 04.11.2007 by Bochkanov Sergey
4221 *************************************************************************/
4222 void mlpgradnbatch(const multilayerperceptron &network, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t ssize, double &e, real_1d_array &grad, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
4223 
4224 
4225 /*************************************************************************
4226 Batch Hessian calculation (natural error function) using R-algorithm.
4227 Internal subroutine.
4228 
4229  -- ALGLIB --
4230  Copyright 26.01.2008 by Bochkanov Sergey.
4231 
4232  Hessian calculation based on R-algorithm described in
4233  "Fast Exact Multiplication by the Hessian",
4234  B. A. Pearlmutter,
4235  Neural Computation, 1994.
4236 *************************************************************************/
4237 void mlphessiannbatch(const multilayerperceptron &network, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t ssize, double &e, real_1d_array &grad, real_2d_array &h, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
4238 
4239 
4240 /*************************************************************************
4241 Batch Hessian calculation using R-algorithm.
4242 Internal subroutine.
4243 
4244  -- ALGLIB --
4245  Copyright 26.01.2008 by Bochkanov Sergey.
4246 
4247  Hessian calculation based on R-algorithm described in
4248  "Fast Exact Multiplication by the Hessian",
4249  B. A. Pearlmutter,
4250  Neural Computation, 1994.
4251 *************************************************************************/
4252 void mlphessianbatch(const multilayerperceptron &network, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t ssize, double &e, real_1d_array &grad, real_2d_array &h, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
4253 
4254 
4255 /*************************************************************************
4256 Calculation of all types of errors on subset of dataset.
4257 
4258  ! COMMERCIAL EDITION OF ALGLIB:
4259  !
4260  ! Commercial Edition of ALGLIB includes following important improvements
4261  ! of this function:
4262  ! * high-performance native backend with same C# interface (C# version)
4263  ! * multithreading support (C++ and C# versions)
4264  !
4265  ! We recommend you to read 'Working with commercial version' section of
4266  ! ALGLIB Reference Manual in order to find out how to use performance-
4267  ! related features provided by commercial edition of ALGLIB.
4268 
4269 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4270  Network - network initialized with one of the network creation funcs
4271  XY - original dataset; one sample = one row;
4272  first NIn columns contain inputs,
4273  next NOut columns - desired outputs.
4274  SetSize - real size of XY, SetSize>=0;
4275  Subset - subset of SubsetSize elements, array[SubsetSize];
4276  SubsetSize- number of elements in Subset[] array:
4277  * if SubsetSize>0, rows of XY with indices Subset[0]...
4278  ...Subset[SubsetSize-1] are processed
4279  * if SubsetSize=0, zeros are returned
4280  * if SubsetSize<0, entire dataset is processed; Subset[]
4281  array is ignored in this case.
4282 
4283 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
4284  Rep - it contains all type of errors.
4285 
4286  -- ALGLIB --
4287  Copyright 04.09.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
4288 *************************************************************************/
4289 void mlpallerrorssubset(const multilayerperceptron &network, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t setsize, const integer_1d_array &subset, const ae_int_t subsetsize, modelerrors &rep, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
4290 
4291 
4292 /*************************************************************************
4293 Calculation of all types of errors on subset of dataset.
4294 
4295  ! COMMERCIAL EDITION OF ALGLIB:
4296  !
4297  ! Commercial Edition of ALGLIB includes following important improvements
4298  ! of this function:
4299  ! * high-performance native backend with same C# interface (C# version)
4300  ! * multithreading support (C++ and C# versions)
4301  !
4302  ! We recommend you to read 'Working with commercial version' section of
4303  ! ALGLIB Reference Manual in order to find out how to use performance-
4304  ! related features provided by commercial edition of ALGLIB.
4305 
4306 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4307  Network - network initialized with one of the network creation funcs
4308  XY - original dataset given by sparse matrix;
4309  one sample = one row;
4310  first NIn columns contain inputs,
4311  next NOut columns - desired outputs.
4312  SetSize - real size of XY, SetSize>=0;
4313  Subset - subset of SubsetSize elements, array[SubsetSize];
4314  SubsetSize- number of elements in Subset[] array:
4315  * if SubsetSize>0, rows of XY with indices Subset[0]...
4316  ...Subset[SubsetSize-1] are processed
4317  * if SubsetSize=0, zeros are returned
4318  * if SubsetSize<0, entire dataset is processed; Subset[]
4319  array is ignored in this case.
4320 
4321 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
4322  Rep - it contains all type of errors.
4323 
4324 
4325  -- ALGLIB --
4326  Copyright 04.09.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
4327 *************************************************************************/
4328 void mlpallerrorssparsesubset(const multilayerperceptron &network, const sparsematrix &xy, const ae_int_t setsize, const integer_1d_array &subset, const ae_int_t subsetsize, modelerrors &rep, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
4329 
4330 
4331 /*************************************************************************
4332 Error of the neural network on subset of dataset.
4333 
4334  ! COMMERCIAL EDITION OF ALGLIB:
4335  !
4336  ! Commercial Edition of ALGLIB includes following important improvements
4337  ! of this function:
4338  ! * high-performance native backend with same C# interface (C# version)
4339  ! * multithreading support (C++ and C# versions)
4340  !
4341  ! We recommend you to read 'Working with commercial version' section of
4342  ! ALGLIB Reference Manual in order to find out how to use performance-
4343  ! related features provided by commercial edition of ALGLIB.
4344 
4345 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4346  Network - neural network;
4347  XY - training set, see below for information on the
4348  training set format;
4349  SetSize - real size of XY, SetSize>=0;
4350  Subset - subset of SubsetSize elements, array[SubsetSize];
4351  SubsetSize- number of elements in Subset[] array:
4352  * if SubsetSize>0, rows of XY with indices Subset[0]...
4353  ...Subset[SubsetSize-1] are processed
4354  * if SubsetSize=0, zeros are returned
4355  * if SubsetSize<0, entire dataset is processed; Subset[]
4356  array is ignored in this case.
4357 
4358 RESULT:
4359  sum-of-squares error, SUM(sqr(y[i]-desired_y[i])/2)
4360 
4361 DATASET FORMAT:
4362 
4363 This function uses two different dataset formats - one for regression
4364 networks, another one for classification networks.
4365 
4366 For regression networks with NIn inputs and NOut outputs following dataset
4367 format is used:
4368 * dataset is given by NPoints*(NIn+NOut) matrix
4369 * each row corresponds to one example
4370 * first NIn columns are inputs, next NOut columns are outputs
4371 
4372 For classification networks with NIn inputs and NClasses clases following
4373 dataset format is used:
4374 * dataset is given by NPoints*(NIn+1) matrix
4375 * each row corresponds to one example
4376 * first NIn columns are inputs, last column stores class number (from 0 to
4377  NClasses-1).
4378 
4379  -- ALGLIB --
4380  Copyright 04.09.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
4381 *************************************************************************/
4382 double mlperrorsubset(const multilayerperceptron &network, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t setsize, const integer_1d_array &subset, const ae_int_t subsetsize, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
4383 
4384 
4385 /*************************************************************************
4386 Error of the neural network on subset of sparse dataset.
4387 
4388  ! COMMERCIAL EDITION OF ALGLIB:
4389  !
4390  ! Commercial Edition of ALGLIB includes following important improvements
4391  ! of this function:
4392  ! * high-performance native backend with same C# interface (C# version)
4393  ! * multithreading support (C++ and C# versions)
4394  !
4395  ! We recommend you to read 'Working with commercial version' section of
4396  ! ALGLIB Reference Manual in order to find out how to use performance-
4397  ! related features provided by commercial edition of ALGLIB.
4398 
4399 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4400  Network - neural network;
4401  XY - training set, see below for information on the
4402  training set format. This function checks correctness
4403  of the dataset (no NANs/INFs, class numbers are
4404  correct) and throws exception when incorrect dataset
4405  is passed. Sparse matrix must use CRS format for
4406  storage.
4407  SetSize - real size of XY, SetSize>=0;
4408  it is used when SubsetSize<0;
4409  Subset - subset of SubsetSize elements, array[SubsetSize];
4410  SubsetSize- number of elements in Subset[] array:
4411  * if SubsetSize>0, rows of XY with indices Subset[0]...
4412  ...Subset[SubsetSize-1] are processed
4413  * if SubsetSize=0, zeros are returned
4414  * if SubsetSize<0, entire dataset is processed; Subset[]
4415  array is ignored in this case.
4416 
4417 RESULT:
4418  sum-of-squares error, SUM(sqr(y[i]-desired_y[i])/2)
4419 
4420 DATASET FORMAT:
4421 
4422 This function uses two different dataset formats - one for regression
4423 networks, another one for classification networks.
4424 
4425 For regression networks with NIn inputs and NOut outputs following dataset
4426 format is used:
4427 * dataset is given by NPoints*(NIn+NOut) matrix
4428 * each row corresponds to one example
4429 * first NIn columns are inputs, next NOut columns are outputs
4430 
4431 For classification networks with NIn inputs and NClasses clases following
4432 dataset format is used:
4433 * dataset is given by NPoints*(NIn+1) matrix
4434 * each row corresponds to one example
4435 * first NIn columns are inputs, last column stores class number (from 0 to
4436  NClasses-1).
4437 
4438  -- ALGLIB --
4439  Copyright 04.09.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
4440 *************************************************************************/
4441 double mlperrorsparsesubset(const multilayerperceptron &network, const sparsematrix &xy, const ae_int_t setsize, const integer_1d_array &subset, const ae_int_t subsetsize, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
4442 #endif
4443 
4444 #if defined(AE_COMPILE_LDA) || !defined(AE_PARTIAL_BUILD)
4445 /*************************************************************************
4446 Multiclass Fisher LDA
4447 
4448 Subroutine finds coefficients of linear combination which optimally separates
4449 training set on classes.
4450 
4451 COMMERCIAL EDITION OF ALGLIB:
4452 
4453  ! Commercial version of ALGLIB includes two important improvements of
4454  ! this function, which can be used from C++ and C#:
4455  ! * Intel MKL support (lightweight Intel MKL is shipped with ALGLIB)
4456  ! * multithreading support
4457  !
4458  ! Intel MKL gives approximately constant (with respect to number of
4459  ! worker threads) acceleration factor which depends on CPU being used,
4460  ! problem size and "baseline" ALGLIB edition which is used for
4461  ! comparison. Best results are achieved for high-dimensional problems
4462  ! (NVars is at least 256).
4463  !
4464  ! Multithreading is used to accelerate initial phase of LDA, which
4465  ! includes calculation of products of large matrices. Again, for best
4466  ! efficiency problem must be high-dimensional.
4467  !
4468  ! Generally, commercial ALGLIB is several times faster than open-source
4469  ! generic C edition, and many times faster than open-source C# edition.
4470  !
4471  ! We recommend you to read 'Working with commercial version' section of
4472  ! ALGLIB Reference Manual in order to find out how to use performance-
4473  ! related features provided by commercial edition of ALGLIB.
4474 
4475 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4476  XY - training set, array[0..NPoints-1,0..NVars].
4477  First NVars columns store values of independent
4478  variables, next column stores number of class (from 0
4479  to NClasses-1) which dataset element belongs to. Fractional
4480  values are rounded to nearest integer.
4481  NPoints - training set size, NPoints>=0
4482  NVars - number of independent variables, NVars>=1
4483  NClasses - number of classes, NClasses>=2
4484 
4485 
4486 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
4487  Info - return code:
4488  * -4, if internal EVD subroutine hasn't converged
4489  * -2, if there is a point with class number
4490  outside of [0..NClasses-1].
4491  * -1, if incorrect parameters was passed (NPoints<0,
4492  NVars<1, NClasses<2)
4493  * 1, if task has been solved
4494  * 2, if there was a multicollinearity in training set,
4495  but task has been solved.
4496  W - linear combination coefficients, array[0..NVars-1]
4497 
4498  -- ALGLIB --
4499  Copyright 31.05.2008 by Bochkanov Sergey
4500 *************************************************************************/
4501 void fisherlda(const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints, const ae_int_t nvars, const ae_int_t nclasses, ae_int_t &info, real_1d_array &w, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
4502 
4503 
4504 /*************************************************************************
4505 N-dimensional multiclass Fisher LDA
4506 
4507 Subroutine finds coefficients of linear combinations which optimally separates
4508 training set on classes. It returns N-dimensional basis whose vector are sorted
4509 by quality of training set separation (in descending order).
4510 
4511  ! COMMERCIAL EDITION OF ALGLIB:
4512  !
4513  ! Commercial Edition of ALGLIB includes following important improvements
4514  ! of this function:
4515  ! * high-performance native backend with same C# interface (C# version)
4516  ! * multithreading support (C++ and C# versions)
4517  ! * hardware vendor (Intel) implementations of linear algebra primitives
4518  ! (C++ and C# versions, x86/x64 platform)
4519  !
4520  ! We recommend you to read 'Working with commercial version' section of
4521  ! ALGLIB Reference Manual in order to find out how to use performance-
4522  ! related features provided by commercial edition of ALGLIB.
4523 
4524 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4525  XY - training set, array[0..NPoints-1,0..NVars].
4526  First NVars columns store values of independent
4527  variables, next column stores number of class (from 0
4528  to NClasses-1) which dataset element belongs to. Fractional
4529  values are rounded to nearest integer.
4530  NPoints - training set size, NPoints>=0
4531  NVars - number of independent variables, NVars>=1
4532  NClasses - number of classes, NClasses>=2
4533 
4534 
4535 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
4536  Info - return code:
4537  * -4, if internal EVD subroutine hasn't converged
4538  * -2, if there is a point with class number
4539  outside of [0..NClasses-1].
4540  * -1, if incorrect parameters was passed (NPoints<0,
4541  NVars<1, NClasses<2)
4542  * 1, if task has been solved
4543  * 2, if there was a multicollinearity in training set,
4544  but task has been solved.
4545  W - basis, array[0..NVars-1,0..NVars-1]
4546  columns of matrix stores basis vectors, sorted by
4547  quality of training set separation (in descending order)
4548 
4549  -- ALGLIB --
4550  Copyright 31.05.2008 by Bochkanov Sergey
4551 *************************************************************************/
4552 void fisherldan(const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints, const ae_int_t nvars, const ae_int_t nclasses, ae_int_t &info, real_2d_array &w, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
4553 #endif
4554 
4555 #if defined(AE_COMPILE_SSA) || !defined(AE_PARTIAL_BUILD)
4556 /*************************************************************************
4557 This function creates SSA model object. Right after creation model is in
4558 "dummy" mode - you can add data, but analyzing/prediction will return
4559 just zeros (it assumes that basis is empty).
4560 
4561 HOW TO USE SSA MODEL:
4562 
4563 1. create model with ssacreate()
4564 2. add data with one/many ssaaddsequence() calls
4565 3. choose SSA algorithm with one of ssasetalgo...() functions:
4566  * ssasetalgotopkdirect() for direct one-run analysis
4567  * ssasetalgotopkrealtime() for algorithm optimized for many subsequent
4568  runs with warm-start capabilities
4569  * ssasetalgoprecomputed() for user-supplied basis
4570 4. set window width with ssasetwindow()
4571 5. perform one of the analysis-related activities:
4572  a) call ssagetbasis() to get basis
4573  b) call ssaanalyzelast() ssaanalyzesequence() or ssaanalyzelastwindow()
4574  to perform analysis (trend/noise separation)
4575  c) call one of the forecasting functions (ssaforecastlast() or
4576  ssaforecastsequence()) to perform prediction; alternatively, you can
4577  extract linear recurrence coefficients with ssagetlrr().
4578  SSA analysis will be performed during first call to analysis-related
4579  function. SSA model is smart enough to track all changes in the dataset
4580  and model settings, to cache previously computed basis and to
4581  re-evaluate basis only when necessary.
4582 
4583 Additionally, if your setting involves constant stream of incoming data,
4584 you can perform quick update already calculated model with one of the
4585 incremental append-and-update functions: ssaappendpointandupdate() or
4586 ssaappendsequenceandupdate().
4587 
4588 NOTE: steps (2), (3), (4) can be performed in arbitrary order.
4589 
4590 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4591  none
4592 
4593 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
4594  S - structure which stores model state
4595 
4596  -- ALGLIB --
4597  Copyright 30.10.2017 by Bochkanov Sergey
4598 *************************************************************************/
4599 void ssacreate(ssamodel &s, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
4600 
4601 
4602 /*************************************************************************
4603 This function sets window width for SSA model. You should call it before
4604 analysis phase. Default window width is 1 (not for real use).
4605 
4606 Special notes:
4607 * this function call can be performed at any moment before first call to
4608  analysis-related functions
4609 * changing window width invalidates internally stored basis; if you change
4610  window width AFTER you call analysis-related function, next analysis
4611  phase will require re-calculation of the basis according to current
4612  algorithm.
4613 * calling this function with exactly same window width as current one has
4614  no effect
4615 * if you specify window width larger than any data sequence stored in the
4616  model, analysis will return zero basis.
4617 
4618 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4619  S - SSA model created with ssacreate()
4620  WindowWidth - >=1, new window width
4621 
4622 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
4623  S - SSA model, updated
4624 
4625  -- ALGLIB --
4626  Copyright 30.10.2017 by Bochkanov Sergey
4627 *************************************************************************/
4628 void ssasetwindow(const ssamodel &s, const ae_int_t windowwidth, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
4629 
4630 
4631 /*************************************************************************
4632 This function sets seed which is used to initialize internal RNG when
4633 we make pseudorandom decisions on model updates.
4634 
4635 By default, deterministic seed is used - which results in same sequence of
4636 pseudorandom decisions every time you run SSA model. If you specify non-
4637 deterministic seed value, then SSA model may return slightly different
4638 results after each run.
4639 
4640 This function can be useful when you have several SSA models updated with
4641 sseappendpointandupdate() called with 0<UpdateIts<1 (fractional value) and
4642 due to performance limitations want them to perform updates at different
4643 moments.
4644 
4645 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4646  S - SSA model
4647  Seed - seed:
4648  * positive values = use deterministic seed for each run of
4649  algorithms which depend on random initialization
4650  * zero or negative values = use non-deterministic seed
4651 
4652  -- ALGLIB --
4653  Copyright 03.11.2017 by Bochkanov Sergey
4654 *************************************************************************/
4655 void ssasetseed(const ssamodel &s, const ae_int_t seed, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
4656 
4657 
4658 /*************************************************************************
4659 This function sets length of power-up cycle for real-time algorithm.
4660 
4661 By default, this algorithm performs costly O(N*WindowWidth^2) init phase
4662 followed by full run of truncated EVD. However, if you are ready to
4663 live with a bit lower-quality basis during first few iterations, you can
4664 split this O(N*WindowWidth^2) initialization between several subsequent
4665 append-and-update rounds. It results in better latency of the algorithm.
4666 
4667 This function invalidates basis/solver, next analysis call will result in
4668 full recalculation of everything.
4669 
4670 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4671  S - SSA model
4672  PWLen - length of the power-up stage:
4673  * 0 means that no power-up is requested
4674  * 1 is the same as 0
4675  * >1 means that delayed power-up is performed
4676 
4677  -- ALGLIB --
4678  Copyright 03.11.2017 by Bochkanov Sergey
4679 *************************************************************************/
4680 void ssasetpoweruplength(const ssamodel &s, const ae_int_t pwlen, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
4681 
4682 
4683 /*************************************************************************
4684 This function sets memory limit of SSA analysis.
4685 
4686 Straightforward SSA with sequence length T and window width W needs O(T*W)
4687 memory. It is possible to reduce memory consumption by splitting task into
4688 smaller chunks.
4689 
4690 Thus function allows you to specify approximate memory limit (measured in
4691 double precision numbers used for buffers). Actual memory consumption will
4692 be comparable to the number specified by you.
4693 
4694 Default memory limit is 50.000.000 (400Mbytes) in current version.
4695 
4696 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4697  S - SSA model
4698  MemLimit- memory limit, >=0. Zero value means no limit.
4699 
4700  -- ALGLIB --
4701  Copyright 20.12.2017 by Bochkanov Sergey
4702 *************************************************************************/
4703 void ssasetmemorylimit(const ssamodel &s, const ae_int_t memlimit, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
4704 
4705 
4706 /*************************************************************************
4707 This function adds data sequence to SSA model. Only single-dimensional
4708 sequences are supported.
4709 
4710 What is a sequences? Following definitions/requirements apply:
4711 * a sequence is an array of values measured in subsequent, equally
4712  separated time moments (ticks).
4713 * you may have many sequences in your dataset; say, one sequence may
4714  correspond to one trading session.
4715 * sequence length should be larger than current window length (shorter
4716  sequences will be ignored during analysis).
4717 * analysis is performed within a sequence; different sequences are NOT
4718  stacked together to produce one large contiguous stream of data.
4719 * analysis is performed for all sequences at once, i.e. same set of basis
4720  vectors is computed for all sequences
4721 
4722 INCREMENTAL ANALYSIS
4723 
4724 This function is non intended for incremental updates of previously found
4725 SSA basis. Calling it invalidates all previous analysis results (basis is
4726 reset and will be recalculated from zero during next analysis).
4727 
4728 If you want to perform incremental/real-time SSA, consider using
4729 following functions:
4730 * ssaappendpointandupdate() for appending one point
4731 * ssaappendsequenceandupdate() for appending new sequence
4732 
4733 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4734  S - SSA model created with ssacreate()
4735  X - array[N], data, can be larger (additional values
4736  are ignored)
4737  N - data length, can be automatically determined from
4738  the array length. N>=0.
4739 
4740 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
4741  S - SSA model, updated
4742 
4743 NOTE: you can clear dataset with ssacleardata()
4744 
4745  -- ALGLIB --
4746  Copyright 30.10.2017 by Bochkanov Sergey
4747 *************************************************************************/
4748 void ssaaddsequence(const ssamodel &s, const real_1d_array &x, const ae_int_t n, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
4749 void ssaaddsequence(const ssamodel &s, const real_1d_array &x, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
4750 
4751 
4752 /*************************************************************************
4753 This function appends single point to last data sequence stored in the SSA
4754 model and tries to update model in the incremental manner (if possible
4755 with current algorithm).
4756 
4757 If you want to add more than one point at once:
4758 * if you want to add M points to the same sequence, perform M-1 calls with
4759  UpdateIts parameter set to 0.0, and last call with non-zero UpdateIts.
4760 * if you want to add new sequence, use ssaappendsequenceandupdate()
4761 
4762 Running time of this function does NOT depend on dataset size, only on
4763 window width and number of singular vectors. Depending on algorithm being
4764 used, incremental update has complexity:
4765 * for top-K real time - O(UpdateIts*K*Width^2), with fractional UpdateIts
4766 * for top-K direct - O(Width^3) for any non-zero UpdateIts
4767 * for precomputed basis - O(1), no update is performed
4768 
4769 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4770  S - SSA model created with ssacreate()
4771  X - new point
4772  UpdateIts - >=0, floating point (!) value, desired update
4773  frequency:
4774  * zero value means that point is stored, but no
4775  update is performed
4776  * integer part of the value means that specified
4777  number of iterations is always performed
4778  * fractional part of the value means that one
4779  iteration is performed with this probability.
4780 
4781  Recommended value: 0<UpdateIts<=1. Values larger
4782  than 1 are VERY seldom needed. If your dataset
4783  changes slowly, you can set it to 0.1 and skip
4784  90% of updates.
4785 
4786  In any case, no information is lost even with zero
4787  value of UpdateIts! It will be incorporated into
4788  model, sooner or later.
4789 
4790 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
4791  S - SSA model, updated
4792 
4793 NOTE: this function uses internal RNG to handle fractional values of
4794  UpdateIts. By default it is initialized with fixed seed during
4795  initial calculation of basis. Thus subsequent calls to this function
4796  will result in the same sequence of pseudorandom decisions.
4797 
4798  However, if you have several SSA models which are calculated
4799  simultaneously, and if you want to reduce computational bottlenecks
4800  by performing random updates at random moments, then fixed seed is
4801  not an option - all updates will fire at same moments.
4802 
4803  You may change it with ssasetseed() function.
4804 
4805 NOTE: this function throws an exception if called for empty dataset (there
4806  is no "last" sequence to modify).
4807 
4808  -- ALGLIB --
4809  Copyright 30.10.2017 by Bochkanov Sergey
4810 *************************************************************************/
4811 void ssaappendpointandupdate(const ssamodel &s, const double x, const double updateits, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
4812 
4813 
4814 /*************************************************************************
4815 This function appends new sequence to dataset stored in the SSA model and
4816 tries to update model in the incremental manner (if possible with current
4817 algorithm).
4818 
4819 Notes:
4820 * if you want to add M sequences at once, perform M-1 calls with UpdateIts
4821  parameter set to 0.0, and last call with non-zero UpdateIts.
4822 * if you want to add just one point, use ssaappendpointandupdate()
4823 
4824 Running time of this function does NOT depend on dataset size, only on
4825 sequence length, window width and number of singular vectors. Depending on
4826 algorithm being used, incremental update has complexity:
4827 * for top-K real time - O(UpdateIts*K*Width^2+(NTicks-Width)*Width^2)
4828 * for top-K direct - O(Width^3+(NTicks-Width)*Width^2)
4829 * for precomputed basis - O(1), no update is performed
4830 
4831 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4832  S - SSA model created with ssacreate()
4833  X - new sequence, array[NTicks] or larget
4834  NTicks - >=1, number of ticks in the sequence
4835  UpdateIts - >=0, floating point (!) value, desired update
4836  frequency:
4837  * zero value means that point is stored, but no
4838  update is performed
4839  * integer part of the value means that specified
4840  number of iterations is always performed
4841  * fractional part of the value means that one
4842  iteration is performed with this probability.
4843 
4844  Recommended value: 0<UpdateIts<=1. Values larger
4845  than 1 are VERY seldom needed. If your dataset
4846  changes slowly, you can set it to 0.1 and skip
4847  90% of updates.
4848 
4849  In any case, no information is lost even with zero
4850  value of UpdateIts! It will be incorporated into
4851  model, sooner or later.
4852 
4853 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
4854  S - SSA model, updated
4855 
4856 NOTE: this function uses internal RNG to handle fractional values of
4857  UpdateIts. By default it is initialized with fixed seed during
4858  initial calculation of basis. Thus subsequent calls to this function
4859  will result in the same sequence of pseudorandom decisions.
4860 
4861  However, if you have several SSA models which are calculated
4862  simultaneously, and if you want to reduce computational bottlenecks
4863  by performing random updates at random moments, then fixed seed is
4864  not an option - all updates will fire at same moments.
4865 
4866  You may change it with ssasetseed() function.
4867 
4868  -- ALGLIB --
4869  Copyright 30.10.2017 by Bochkanov Sergey
4870 *************************************************************************/
4871 void ssaappendsequenceandupdate(const ssamodel &s, const real_1d_array &x, const ae_int_t nticks, const double updateits, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
4872 void ssaappendsequenceandupdate(const ssamodel &s, const real_1d_array &x, const double updateits, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
4873 
4874 
4875 /*************************************************************************
4876 This function sets SSA algorithm to "precomputed vectors" algorithm.
4877 
4878 This algorithm uses precomputed set of orthonormal (orthogonal AND
4879 normalized) basis vectors supplied by user. Thus, basis calculation phase
4880 is not performed - we already have our basis - and only analysis/
4881 forecasting phase requires actual calculations.
4882 
4883 This algorithm may handle "append" requests which add just one/few ticks
4884 to the end of the last sequence in O(1) time.
4885 
4886 NOTE: this algorithm accepts both basis and window width, because these
4887  two parameters are naturally aligned. Calling this function sets
4888  window width; if you call ssasetwindow() with other window width,
4889  then during analysis stage algorithm will detect conflict and reset
4890  to zero basis.
4891 
4892 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4893  S - SSA model
4894  A - array[WindowWidth,NBasis], orthonormalized basis;
4895  this function does NOT control orthogonality and
4896  does NOT perform any kind of renormalization. It
4897  is your responsibility to provide it with correct
4898  basis.
4899  WindowWidth - window width, >=1
4900  NBasis - number of basis vectors, 1<=NBasis<=WindowWidth
4901 
4902 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
4903  S - updated model
4904 
4905 NOTE: calling this function invalidates basis in all cases.
4906 
4907  -- ALGLIB --
4908  Copyright 30.10.2017 by Bochkanov Sergey
4909 *************************************************************************/
4910 void ssasetalgoprecomputed(const ssamodel &s, const real_2d_array &a, const ae_int_t windowwidth, const ae_int_t nbasis, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
4911 void ssasetalgoprecomputed(const ssamodel &s, const real_2d_array &a, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
4912 
4913 
4914 /*************************************************************************
4915 This function sets SSA algorithm to "direct top-K" algorithm.
4916 
4917 "Direct top-K" algorithm performs full SVD of the N*WINDOW trajectory
4918 matrix (hence its name - direct solver is used), then extracts top K
4919 components. Overall running time is O(N*WINDOW^2), where N is a number of
4920 ticks in the dataset, WINDOW is window width.
4921 
4922 This algorithm may handle "append" requests which add just one/few ticks
4923 to the end of the last sequence in O(WINDOW^3) time, which is ~N/WINDOW
4924 times faster than re-computing everything from scratch.
4925 
4926 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4927  S - SSA model
4928  TopK - number of components to analyze; TopK>=1.
4929 
4930 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
4931  S - updated model
4932 
4933 
4934 NOTE: TopK>WindowWidth is silently decreased to WindowWidth during analysis
4935  phase
4936 
4937 NOTE: calling this function invalidates basis, except for the situation
4938  when this algorithm was already set with same parameters.
4939 
4940  -- ALGLIB --
4941  Copyright 30.10.2017 by Bochkanov Sergey
4942 *************************************************************************/
4943 void ssasetalgotopkdirect(const ssamodel &s, const ae_int_t topk, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
4944 
4945 
4946 /*************************************************************************
4947 This function sets SSA algorithm to "top-K real time algorithm". This algo
4948 extracts K components with largest singular values.
4949 
4950 It is real-time version of top-K algorithm which is optimized for
4951 incremental processing and fast start-up. Internally it uses subspace
4952 eigensolver for truncated SVD. It results in ability to perform quick
4953 updates of the basis when only a few points/sequences is added to dataset.
4954 
4955 Performance profile of the algorithm is given below:
4956 * O(K*WindowWidth^2) running time for incremental update of the dataset
4957  with one of the "append-and-update" functions (ssaappendpointandupdate()
4958  or ssaappendsequenceandupdate()).
4959 * O(N*WindowWidth^2) running time for initial basis evaluation (N=size of
4960  dataset)
4961 * ability to split costly initialization across several incremental
4962  updates of the basis (so called "Power-Up" functionality, activated by
4963  ssasetpoweruplength() function)
4964 
4965 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4966  S - SSA model
4967  TopK - number of components to analyze; TopK>=1.
4968 
4969 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
4970  S - updated model
4971 
4972 NOTE: this algorithm is optimized for large-scale tasks with large
4973  datasets. On toy problems with just 5-10 points it can return basis
4974  which is slightly different from that returned by direct algorithm
4975  (ssasetalgotopkdirect() function). However, the difference becomes
4976  negligible as dataset grows.
4977 
4978 NOTE: TopK>WindowWidth is silently decreased to WindowWidth during analysis
4979  phase
4980 
4981 NOTE: calling this function invalidates basis, except for the situation
4982  when this algorithm was already set with same parameters.
4983 
4984  -- ALGLIB --
4985  Copyright 30.10.2017 by Bochkanov Sergey
4986 *************************************************************************/
4987 void ssasetalgotopkrealtime(const ssamodel &s, const ae_int_t topk, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
4988 
4989 
4990 /*************************************************************************
4991 This function clears all data stored in the model and invalidates all
4992 basis components found so far.
4993 
4994 INPUT PARAMETERS:
4995  S - SSA model created with ssacreate()
4996 
4997 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
4998  S - SSA model, updated
4999 
5000  -- ALGLIB --
5001  Copyright 30.10.2017 by Bochkanov Sergey
5002 *************************************************************************/
5003 void ssacleardata(const ssamodel &s, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
5004 
5005 
5006 /*************************************************************************
5007 This function executes SSA on internally stored dataset and returns basis
5008 found by current method.
5009 
5010 INPUT PARAMETERS:
5011  S - SSA model
5012 
5013 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
5014  A - array[WindowWidth,NBasis], basis; vectors are
5015  stored in matrix columns, by descreasing variance
5016  SV - array[NBasis]:
5017  * zeros - for model initialized with SSASetAlgoPrecomputed()
5018  * singular values - for other algorithms
5019  WindowWidth - current window
5020  NBasis - basis size
5021 
5022 
5023 CACHING/REUSE OF THE BASIS
5024 
5025 Caching/reuse of previous results is performed:
5026 * first call performs full run of SSA; basis is stored in the cache
5027 * subsequent calls reuse previously cached basis
5028 * if you call any function which changes model properties (window length,
5029  algorithm, dataset), internal basis will be invalidated.
5030 * the only calls which do NOT invalidate basis are listed below:
5031  a) ssasetwindow() with same window length
5032  b) ssaappendpointandupdate()
5033  c) ssaappendsequenceandupdate()
5034  d) ssasetalgotopk...() with exactly same K
5035  Calling these functions will result in reuse of previously found basis.
5036 
5037 
5038 HANDLING OF DEGENERATE CASES
5039 
5040 Calling this function in degenerate cases (no data or all data are
5041 shorter than window size; no algorithm is specified) returns basis with
5042 just one zero vector.
5043 
5044  -- ALGLIB --
5045  Copyright 30.10.2017 by Bochkanov Sergey
5046 *************************************************************************/
5047 void ssagetbasis(const ssamodel &s, real_2d_array &a, real_1d_array &sv, ae_int_t &windowwidth, ae_int_t &nbasis, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
5048 
5049 
5050 /*************************************************************************
5051 This function returns linear recurrence relation (LRR) coefficients found
5052 by current SSA algorithm.
5053 
5054 INPUT PARAMETERS:
5055  S - SSA model
5056 
5057 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
5058  A - array[WindowWidth-1]. Coefficients of the
5059  linear recurrence of the form:
5060  X[W-1] = X[W-2]*A[W-2] + X[W-3]*A[W-3] + ... + X[0]*A[0].
5061  Empty array for WindowWidth=1.
5062  WindowWidth - current window width
5063 
5064 
5065 CACHING/REUSE OF THE BASIS
5066 
5067 Caching/reuse of previous results is performed:
5068 * first call performs full run of SSA; basis is stored in the cache
5069 * subsequent calls reuse previously cached basis
5070 * if you call any function which changes model properties (window length,
5071  algorithm, dataset), internal basis will be invalidated.
5072 * the only calls which do NOT invalidate basis are listed below:
5073  a) ssasetwindow() with same window length
5074  b) ssaappendpointandupdate()
5075  c) ssaappendsequenceandupdate()
5076  d) ssasetalgotopk...() with exactly same K
5077  Calling these functions will result in reuse of previously found basis.
5078 
5079 
5080 HANDLING OF DEGENERATE CASES
5081 
5082 Calling this function in degenerate cases (no data or all data are
5083 shorter than window size; no algorithm is specified) returns zeros.
5084 
5085  -- ALGLIB --
5086  Copyright 30.10.2017 by Bochkanov Sergey
5087 *************************************************************************/
5088 void ssagetlrr(const ssamodel &s, real_1d_array &a, ae_int_t &windowwidth, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
5089 
5090 
5091 /*************************************************************************
5092 This function executes SSA on internally stored dataset and returns
5093 analysis for the last window of the last sequence. Such analysis is
5094 an lightweight alternative for full scale reconstruction (see below).
5095 
5096 Typical use case for this function is real-time setting, when you are
5097 interested in quick-and-dirty (very quick and very dirty) processing of
5098 just a few last ticks of the trend.
5099 
5100 IMPORTANT: full scale SSA involves analysis of the ENTIRE dataset,
5101  with reconstruction being done for all positions of sliding
5102  window with subsequent hankelization (diagonal averaging) of
5103  the resulting matrix.
5104 
5105  Such analysis requires O((DataLen-Window)*Window*NBasis) FLOPs
5106  and can be quite costly. However, it has nice noise-canceling
5107  effects due to averaging.
5108 
5109  This function performs REDUCED analysis of the last window. It
5110  is much faster - just O(Window*NBasis), but its results are
5111  DIFFERENT from that of ssaanalyzelast(). In particular, first
5112  few points of the trend are much more prone to noise.
5113 
5114 INPUT PARAMETERS:
5115  S - SSA model
5116 
5117 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
5118  Trend - array[WindowSize], reconstructed trend line
5119  Noise - array[WindowSize], the rest of the signal;
5120  it holds that ActualData = Trend+Noise.
5121  NTicks - current WindowSize
5122 
5123 
5124 CACHING/REUSE OF THE BASIS
5125 
5126 Caching/reuse of previous results is performed:
5127 * first call performs full run of SSA; basis is stored in the cache
5128 * subsequent calls reuse previously cached basis
5129 * if you call any function which changes model properties (window length,
5130  algorithm, dataset), internal basis will be invalidated.
5131 * the only calls which do NOT invalidate basis are listed below:
5132  a) ssasetwindow() with same window length
5133  b) ssaappendpointandupdate()
5134  c) ssaappendsequenceandupdate()
5135  d) ssasetalgotopk...() with exactly same K
5136  Calling these functions will result in reuse of previously found basis.
5137 
5138 In any case, only basis is reused. Reconstruction is performed from
5139 scratch every time you call this function.
5140 
5141 
5142 HANDLING OF DEGENERATE CASES
5143 
5144 Following degenerate cases may happen:
5145 * dataset is empty (no analysis can be done)
5146 * all sequences are shorter than the window length,no analysis can be done
5147 * no algorithm is specified (no analysis can be done)
5148 * last sequence is shorter than the window length (analysis can be done,
5149  but we can not perform reconstruction on the last sequence)
5150 
5151 Calling this function in degenerate cases returns following result:
5152 * in any case, WindowWidth ticks is returned
5153 * trend is assumed to be zero
5154 * noise is initialized by the last sequence; if last sequence is shorter
5155  than the window size, it is moved to the end of the array, and the
5156  beginning of the noise array is filled by zeros
5157 
5158 No analysis is performed in degenerate cases (we immediately return dummy
5159 values, no basis is constructed).
5160 
5161  -- ALGLIB --
5162  Copyright 30.10.2017 by Bochkanov Sergey
5163 *************************************************************************/
5164 void ssaanalyzelastwindow(const ssamodel &s, real_1d_array &trend, real_1d_array &noise, ae_int_t &nticks, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
5165 
5166 
5167 /*************************************************************************
5168 This function:
5169 * builds SSA basis using internally stored (entire) dataset
5170 * returns reconstruction for the last NTicks of the last sequence
5171 
5172 If you want to analyze some other sequence, use ssaanalyzesequence().
5173 
5174 Reconstruction phase involves generation of NTicks-WindowWidth sliding
5175 windows, their decomposition using empirical orthogonal functions found by
5176 SSA, followed by averaging of each data point across several overlapping
5177 windows. Thus, every point in the output trend is reconstructed using up
5178 to WindowWidth overlapping windows (WindowWidth windows exactly in the
5179 inner points, just one window at the extremal points).
5180 
5181 IMPORTANT: due to averaging this function returns different results for
5182  different values of NTicks. It is expected and not a bug.
5183 
5184  For example:
5185  * Trend[NTicks-1] is always same because it is not averaged in
5186  any case (same applies to Trend[0]).
5187  * Trend[NTicks-2] has different values for NTicks=WindowWidth
5188  and NTicks=WindowWidth+1 because former case means that no
5189  averaging is performed, and latter case means that averaging
5190  using two sliding windows is performed. Larger values of
5191  NTicks produce same results as NTicks=WindowWidth+1.
5192  * ...and so on...
5193 
5194 PERFORMANCE: this function has O((NTicks-WindowWidth)*WindowWidth*NBasis)
5195  running time. If you work in time-constrained setting and
5196  have to analyze just a few last ticks, choosing NTicks equal
5197  to WindowWidth+SmoothingLen, with SmoothingLen=1...WindowWidth
5198  will result in good compromise between noise cancellation and
5199  analysis speed.
5200 
5201 INPUT PARAMETERS:
5202  S - SSA model
5203  NTicks - number of ticks to analyze, Nticks>=1.
5204  * special case of NTicks<=WindowWidth is handled
5205  by analyzing last window and returning NTicks
5206  last ticks.
5207  * special case NTicks>LastSequenceLen is handled
5208  by prepending result with NTicks-LastSequenceLen
5209  zeros.
5210 
5211 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
5212  Trend - array[NTicks], reconstructed trend line
5213  Noise - array[NTicks], the rest of the signal;
5214  it holds that ActualData = Trend+Noise.
5215 
5216 
5217 CACHING/REUSE OF THE BASIS
5218 
5219 Caching/reuse of previous results is performed:
5220 * first call performs full run of SSA; basis is stored in the cache
5221 * subsequent calls reuse previously cached basis
5222 * if you call any function which changes model properties (window length,
5223  algorithm, dataset), internal basis will be invalidated.
5224 * the only calls which do NOT invalidate basis are listed below:
5225  a) ssasetwindow() with same window length
5226  b) ssaappendpointandupdate()
5227  c) ssaappendsequenceandupdate()
5228  d) ssasetalgotopk...() with exactly same K
5229  Calling these functions will result in reuse of previously found basis.
5230 
5231 In any case, only basis is reused. Reconstruction is performed from
5232 scratch every time you call this function.
5233 
5234 
5235 HANDLING OF DEGENERATE CASES
5236 
5237 Following degenerate cases may happen:
5238 * dataset is empty (no analysis can be done)
5239 * all sequences are shorter than the window length,no analysis can be done
5240 * no algorithm is specified (no analysis can be done)
5241 * last sequence is shorter than the window length (analysis can be done,
5242  but we can not perform reconstruction on the last sequence)
5243 
5244 Calling this function in degenerate cases returns following result:
5245 * in any case, NTicks ticks is returned
5246 * trend is assumed to be zero
5247 * noise is initialized by the last sequence; if last sequence is shorter
5248  than the window size, it is moved to the end of the array, and the
5249  beginning of the noise array is filled by zeros
5250 
5251 No analysis is performed in degenerate cases (we immediately return dummy
5252 values, no basis is constructed).
5253 
5254  -- ALGLIB --
5255  Copyright 30.10.2017 by Bochkanov Sergey
5256 *************************************************************************/
5257 void ssaanalyzelast(const ssamodel &s, const ae_int_t nticks, real_1d_array &trend, real_1d_array &noise, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
5258 
5259 
5260 /*************************************************************************
5261 This function:
5262 * builds SSA basis using internally stored (entire) dataset
5263 * returns reconstruction for the sequence being passed to this function
5264 
5265 If you want to analyze last sequence stored in the model, use
5266 ssaanalyzelast().
5267 
5268 Reconstruction phase involves generation of NTicks-WindowWidth sliding
5269 windows, their decomposition using empirical orthogonal functions found by
5270 SSA, followed by averaging of each data point across several overlapping
5271 windows. Thus, every point in the output trend is reconstructed using up
5272 to WindowWidth overlapping windows (WindowWidth windows exactly in the
5273 inner points, just one window at the extremal points).
5274 
5275 PERFORMANCE: this function has O((NTicks-WindowWidth)*WindowWidth*NBasis)
5276  running time. If you work in time-constrained setting and
5277  have to analyze just a few last ticks, choosing NTicks equal
5278  to WindowWidth+SmoothingLen, with SmoothingLen=1...WindowWidth
5279  will result in good compromise between noise cancellation and
5280  analysis speed.
5281 
5282 INPUT PARAMETERS:
5283  S - SSA model
5284  Data - array[NTicks], can be larger (only NTicks leading
5285  elements will be used)
5286  NTicks - number of ticks to analyze, Nticks>=1.
5287  * special case of NTicks<WindowWidth is handled
5288  by returning zeros as trend, and signal as noise
5289 
5290 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
5291  Trend - array[NTicks], reconstructed trend line
5292  Noise - array[NTicks], the rest of the signal;
5293  it holds that ActualData = Trend+Noise.
5294 
5295 
5296 CACHING/REUSE OF THE BASIS
5297 
5298 Caching/reuse of previous results is performed:
5299 * first call performs full run of SSA; basis is stored in the cache
5300 * subsequent calls reuse previously cached basis
5301 * if you call any function which changes model properties (window length,
5302  algorithm, dataset), internal basis will be invalidated.
5303 * the only calls which do NOT invalidate basis are listed below:
5304  a) ssasetwindow() with same window length
5305  b) ssaappendpointandupdate()
5306  c) ssaappendsequenceandupdate()
5307  d) ssasetalgotopk...() with exactly same K
5308  Calling these functions will result in reuse of previously found basis.
5309 
5310 In any case, only basis is reused. Reconstruction is performed from
5311 scratch every time you call this function.
5312 
5313 
5314 HANDLING OF DEGENERATE CASES
5315 
5316 Following degenerate cases may happen:
5317 * dataset is empty (no analysis can be done)
5318 * all sequences are shorter than the window length,no analysis can be done
5319 * no algorithm is specified (no analysis can be done)
5320 * sequence being passed is shorter than the window length
5321 
5322 Calling this function in degenerate cases returns following result:
5323 * in any case, NTicks ticks is returned
5324 * trend is assumed to be zero
5325 * noise is initialized by the sequence.
5326 
5327 No analysis is performed in degenerate cases (we immediately return dummy
5328 values, no basis is constructed).
5329 
5330  -- ALGLIB --
5331  Copyright 30.10.2017 by Bochkanov Sergey
5332 *************************************************************************/
5333 void ssaanalyzesequence(const ssamodel &s, const real_1d_array &data, const ae_int_t nticks, real_1d_array &trend, real_1d_array &noise, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
5334 void ssaanalyzesequence(const ssamodel &s, const real_1d_array &data, real_1d_array &trend, real_1d_array &noise, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
5335 
5336 
5337 /*************************************************************************
5338 This function builds SSA basis and performs forecasting for a specified
5339 number of ticks, returning value of trend.
5340 
5341 Forecast is performed as follows:
5342 * SSA trend extraction is applied to last WindowWidth elements of the
5343  internally stored dataset; this step is basically a noise reduction.
5344 * linear recurrence relation is applied to extracted trend
5345 
5346 This function has following running time:
5347 * O(NBasis*WindowWidth) for trend extraction phase (always performed)
5348 * O(WindowWidth*NTicks) for forecast phase
5349 
5350 NOTE: noise reduction is ALWAYS applied by this algorithm; if you want to
5351  apply recurrence relation to raw unprocessed data, use another
5352  function - ssaforecastsequence() which allows to turn on and off
5353  noise reduction phase.
5354 
5355 NOTE: this algorithm performs prediction using only one - last - sliding
5356  window. Predictions produced by such approach are smooth
5357  continuations of the reconstructed trend line, but they can be
5358  easily corrupted by noise. If you need noise-resistant prediction,
5359  use ssaforecastavglast() function, which averages predictions built
5360  using several sliding windows.
5361 
5362 INPUT PARAMETERS:
5363  S - SSA model
5364  NTicks - number of ticks to forecast, NTicks>=1
5365 
5366 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
5367  Trend - array[NTicks], predicted trend line
5368 
5369 
5370 CACHING/REUSE OF THE BASIS
5371 
5372 Caching/reuse of previous results is performed:
5373 * first call performs full run of SSA; basis is stored in the cache
5374 * subsequent calls reuse previously cached basis
5375 * if you call any function which changes model properties (window length,
5376  algorithm, dataset), internal basis will be invalidated.
5377 * the only calls which do NOT invalidate basis are listed below:
5378  a) ssasetwindow() with same window length
5379  b) ssaappendpointandupdate()
5380  c) ssaappendsequenceandupdate()
5381  d) ssasetalgotopk...() with exactly same K
5382  Calling these functions will result in reuse of previously found basis.
5383 
5384 
5385 HANDLING OF DEGENERATE CASES
5386 
5387 Following degenerate cases may happen:
5388 * dataset is empty (no analysis can be done)
5389 * all sequences are shorter than the window length,no analysis can be done
5390 * no algorithm is specified (no analysis can be done)
5391 * last sequence is shorter than the WindowWidth (analysis can be done,
5392  but we can not perform forecasting on the last sequence)
5393 * window lentgh is 1 (impossible to use for forecasting)
5394 * SSA analysis algorithm is configured to extract basis whose size is
5395  equal to window length (impossible to use for forecasting; only basis
5396  whose size is less than window length can be used).
5397 
5398 Calling this function in degenerate cases returns following result:
5399 * NTicks copies of the last value is returned for non-empty task with
5400  large enough dataset, but with overcomplete basis (window width=1 or
5401  basis size is equal to window width)
5402 * zero trend with length=NTicks is returned for empty task
5403 
5404 No analysis is performed in degenerate cases (we immediately return dummy
5405 values, no basis is ever constructed).
5406 
5407  -- ALGLIB --
5408  Copyright 30.10.2017 by Bochkanov Sergey
5409 *************************************************************************/
5410 void ssaforecastlast(const ssamodel &s, const ae_int_t nticks, real_1d_array &trend, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
5411 
5412 
5413 /*************************************************************************
5414 This function builds SSA basis and performs forecasting for a user-
5415 specified sequence, returning value of trend.
5416 
5417 Forecasting is done in two stages:
5418 * first, we extract trend from the WindowWidth last elements of the
5419  sequence. This stage is optional, you can turn it off if you pass
5420  data which are already processed with SSA. Of course, you can turn it
5421  off even for raw data, but it is not recommended - noise suppression is
5422  very important for correct prediction.
5423 * then, we apply LRR for last WindowWidth-1 elements of the extracted
5424  trend.
5425 
5426 This function has following running time:
5427 * O(NBasis*WindowWidth) for trend extraction phase
5428 * O(WindowWidth*NTicks) for forecast phase
5429 
5430 NOTE: this algorithm performs prediction using only one - last - sliding
5431  window. Predictions produced by such approach are smooth
5432  continuations of the reconstructed trend line, but they can be
5433  easily corrupted by noise. If you need noise-resistant prediction,
5434  use ssaforecastavgsequence() function, which averages predictions
5435  built using several sliding windows.
5436 
5437 INPUT PARAMETERS:
5438  S - SSA model
5439  Data - array[NTicks], data to forecast
5440  DataLen - number of ticks in the data, DataLen>=1
5441  ForecastLen - number of ticks to predict, ForecastLen>=1
5442  ApplySmoothing - whether to apply smoothing trend extraction or not;
5443  if you do not know what to specify, pass True.
5444 
5445 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
5446  Trend - array[ForecastLen], forecasted trend
5447 
5448 
5449 CACHING/REUSE OF THE BASIS
5450 
5451 Caching/reuse of previous results is performed:
5452 * first call performs full run of SSA; basis is stored in the cache
5453 * subsequent calls reuse previously cached basis
5454 * if you call any function which changes model properties (window length,
5455  algorithm, dataset), internal basis will be invalidated.
5456 * the only calls which do NOT invalidate basis are listed below:
5457  a) ssasetwindow() with same window length
5458  b) ssaappendpointandupdate()
5459  c) ssaappendsequenceandupdate()
5460  d) ssasetalgotopk...() with exactly same K
5461  Calling these functions will result in reuse of previously found basis.
5462 
5463 
5464 HANDLING OF DEGENERATE CASES
5465 
5466 Following degenerate cases may happen:
5467 * dataset is empty (no analysis can be done)
5468 * all sequences are shorter than the window length,no analysis can be done
5469 * no algorithm is specified (no analysis can be done)
5470 * data sequence is shorter than the WindowWidth (analysis can be done,
5471  but we can not perform forecasting on the last sequence)
5472 * window lentgh is 1 (impossible to use for forecasting)
5473 * SSA analysis algorithm is configured to extract basis whose size is
5474  equal to window length (impossible to use for forecasting; only basis
5475  whose size is less than window length can be used).
5476 
5477 Calling this function in degenerate cases returns following result:
5478 * ForecastLen copies of the last value is returned for non-empty task with
5479  large enough dataset, but with overcomplete basis (window width=1 or
5480  basis size is equal to window width)
5481 * zero trend with length=ForecastLen is returned for empty task
5482 
5483 No analysis is performed in degenerate cases (we immediately return dummy
5484 values, no basis is ever constructed).
5485 
5486  -- ALGLIB --
5487  Copyright 30.10.2017 by Bochkanov Sergey
5488 *************************************************************************/
5489 void ssaforecastsequence(const ssamodel &s, const real_1d_array &data, const ae_int_t datalen, const ae_int_t forecastlen, const bool applysmoothing, real_1d_array &trend, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
5490 void ssaforecastsequence(const ssamodel &s, const real_1d_array &data, const ae_int_t forecastlen, real_1d_array &trend, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
5491 
5492 
5493 /*************************************************************************
5494 This function builds SSA basis and performs forecasting for a specified
5495 number of ticks, returning value of trend.
5496 
5497 Forecast is performed as follows:
5498 * SSA trend extraction is applied to last M sliding windows of the
5499  internally stored dataset
5500 * for each of M sliding windows, M predictions are built
5501 * average value of M predictions is returned
5502 
5503 This function has following running time:
5504 * O(NBasis*WindowWidth*M) for trend extraction phase (always performed)
5505 * O(WindowWidth*NTicks*M) for forecast phase
5506 
5507 NOTE: noise reduction is ALWAYS applied by this algorithm; if you want to
5508  apply recurrence relation to raw unprocessed data, use another
5509  function - ssaforecastsequence() which allows to turn on and off
5510  noise reduction phase.
5511 
5512 NOTE: combination of several predictions results in lesser sensitivity to
5513  noise, but it may produce undesirable discontinuities between last
5514  point of the trend and first point of the prediction. The reason is
5515  that last point of the trend is usually corrupted by noise, but
5516  average value of several predictions is less sensitive to noise,
5517  thus discontinuity appears. It is not a bug.
5518 
5519 INPUT PARAMETERS:
5520  S - SSA model
5521  M - number of sliding windows to combine, M>=1. If
5522  your dataset has less than M sliding windows, this
5523  parameter will be silently reduced.
5524  NTicks - number of ticks to forecast, NTicks>=1
5525 
5526 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
5527  Trend - array[NTicks], predicted trend line
5528 
5529 
5530 CACHING/REUSE OF THE BASIS
5531 
5532 Caching/reuse of previous results is performed:
5533 * first call performs full run of SSA; basis is stored in the cache
5534 * subsequent calls reuse previously cached basis
5535 * if you call any function which changes model properties (window length,
5536  algorithm, dataset), internal basis will be invalidated.
5537 * the only calls which do NOT invalidate basis are listed below:
5538  a) ssasetwindow() with same window length
5539  b) ssaappendpointandupdate()
5540  c) ssaappendsequenceandupdate()
5541  d) ssasetalgotopk...() with exactly same K
5542  Calling these functions will result in reuse of previously found basis.
5543 
5544 
5545 HANDLING OF DEGENERATE CASES
5546 
5547 Following degenerate cases may happen:
5548 * dataset is empty (no analysis can be done)
5549 * all sequences are shorter than the window length,no analysis can be done
5550 * no algorithm is specified (no analysis can be done)
5551 * last sequence is shorter than the WindowWidth (analysis can be done,
5552  but we can not perform forecasting on the last sequence)
5553 * window lentgh is 1 (impossible to use for forecasting)
5554 * SSA analysis algorithm is configured to extract basis whose size is
5555  equal to window length (impossible to use for forecasting; only basis
5556  whose size is less than window length can be used).
5557 
5558 Calling this function in degenerate cases returns following result:
5559 * NTicks copies of the last value is returned for non-empty task with
5560  large enough dataset, but with overcomplete basis (window width=1 or
5561  basis size is equal to window width)
5562 * zero trend with length=NTicks is returned for empty task
5563 
5564 No analysis is performed in degenerate cases (we immediately return dummy
5565 values, no basis is ever constructed).
5566 
5567  -- ALGLIB --
5568  Copyright 30.10.2017 by Bochkanov Sergey
5569 *************************************************************************/
5570 void ssaforecastavglast(const ssamodel &s, const ae_int_t m, const ae_int_t nticks, real_1d_array &trend, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
5571 
5572 
5573 /*************************************************************************
5574 This function builds SSA basis and performs forecasting for a user-
5575 specified sequence, returning value of trend.
5576 
5577 Forecasting is done in two stages:
5578 * first, we extract trend from M last sliding windows of the sequence.
5579  This stage is optional, you can turn it off if you pass data which
5580  are already processed with SSA. Of course, you can turn it off even
5581  for raw data, but it is not recommended - noise suppression is very
5582  important for correct prediction.
5583 * then, we apply LRR independently for M sliding windows
5584 * average of M predictions is returned
5585 
5586 This function has following running time:
5587 * O(NBasis*WindowWidth*M) for trend extraction phase
5588 * O(WindowWidth*NTicks*M) for forecast phase
5589 
5590 NOTE: combination of several predictions results in lesser sensitivity to
5591  noise, but it may produce undesirable discontinuities between last
5592  point of the trend and first point of the prediction. The reason is
5593  that last point of the trend is usually corrupted by noise, but
5594  average value of several predictions is less sensitive to noise,
5595  thus discontinuity appears. It is not a bug.
5596 
5597 INPUT PARAMETERS:
5598  S - SSA model
5599  Data - array[NTicks], data to forecast
5600  DataLen - number of ticks in the data, DataLen>=1
5601  M - number of sliding windows to combine, M>=1. If
5602  your dataset has less than M sliding windows, this
5603  parameter will be silently reduced.
5604  ForecastLen - number of ticks to predict, ForecastLen>=1
5605  ApplySmoothing - whether to apply smoothing trend extraction or not.
5606  if you do not know what to specify, pass true.
5607 
5608 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
5609  Trend - array[ForecastLen], forecasted trend
5610 
5611 
5612 CACHING/REUSE OF THE BASIS
5613 
5614 Caching/reuse of previous results is performed:
5615 * first call performs full run of SSA; basis is stored in the cache
5616 * subsequent calls reuse previously cached basis
5617 * if you call any function which changes model properties (window length,
5618  algorithm, dataset), internal basis will be invalidated.
5619 * the only calls which do NOT invalidate basis are listed below:
5620  a) ssasetwindow() with same window length
5621  b) ssaappendpointandupdate()
5622  c) ssaappendsequenceandupdate()
5623  d) ssasetalgotopk...() with exactly same K
5624  Calling these functions will result in reuse of previously found basis.
5625 
5626 
5627 HANDLING OF DEGENERATE CASES
5628 
5629 Following degenerate cases may happen:
5630 * dataset is empty (no analysis can be done)
5631 * all sequences are shorter than the window length,no analysis can be done
5632 * no algorithm is specified (no analysis can be done)
5633 * data sequence is shorter than the WindowWidth (analysis can be done,
5634  but we can not perform forecasting on the last sequence)
5635 * window lentgh is 1 (impossible to use for forecasting)
5636 * SSA analysis algorithm is configured to extract basis whose size is
5637  equal to window length (impossible to use for forecasting; only basis
5638  whose size is less than window length can be used).
5639 
5640 Calling this function in degenerate cases returns following result:
5641 * ForecastLen copies of the last value is returned for non-empty task with
5642  large enough dataset, but with overcomplete basis (window width=1 or
5643  basis size is equal to window width)
5644 * zero trend with length=ForecastLen is returned for empty task
5645 
5646 No analysis is performed in degenerate cases (we immediately return dummy
5647 values, no basis is ever constructed).
5648 
5649  -- ALGLIB --
5650  Copyright 30.10.2017 by Bochkanov Sergey
5651 *************************************************************************/
5652 void ssaforecastavgsequence(const ssamodel &s, const real_1d_array &data, const ae_int_t datalen, const ae_int_t m, const ae_int_t forecastlen, const bool applysmoothing, real_1d_array &trend, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
5653 void ssaforecastavgsequence(const ssamodel &s, const real_1d_array &data, const ae_int_t m, const ae_int_t forecastlen, real_1d_array &trend, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
5654 #endif
5655 
5656 #if defined(AE_COMPILE_LINREG) || !defined(AE_PARTIAL_BUILD)
5657 /*************************************************************************
5658 Linear regression
5659 
5660 Subroutine builds model:
5661 
5662  Y = A(0)*X[0] + ... + A(N-1)*X[N-1] + A(N)
5663 
5664 and model found in ALGLIB format, covariation matrix, training set errors
5665 (rms, average, average relative) and leave-one-out cross-validation
5666 estimate of the generalization error. CV estimate calculated using fast
5667 algorithm with O(NPoints*NVars) complexity.
5668 
5669 When covariation matrix is calculated standard deviations of function
5670 values are assumed to be equal to RMS error on the training set.
5671 
5672 INPUT PARAMETERS:
5673  XY - training set, array [0..NPoints-1,0..NVars]:
5674  * NVars columns - independent variables
5675  * last column - dependent variable
5676  NPoints - training set size, NPoints>NVars+1
5677  NVars - number of independent variables
5678 
5679 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
5680  Info - return code:
5681  * -255, in case of unknown internal error
5682  * -4, if internal SVD subroutine haven't converged
5683  * -1, if incorrect parameters was passed (NPoints<NVars+2, NVars<1).
5684  * 1, if subroutine successfully finished
5685  LM - linear model in the ALGLIB format. Use subroutines of
5686  this unit to work with the model.
5687  AR - additional results
5688 
5689 
5690  -- ALGLIB --
5691  Copyright 02.08.2008 by Bochkanov Sergey
5692 *************************************************************************/
5693 void lrbuild(const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints, const ae_int_t nvars, ae_int_t &info, linearmodel &lm, lrreport &ar, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
5694 
5695 
5696 /*************************************************************************
5697 Linear regression
5698 
5699 Variant of LRBuild which uses vector of standatd deviations (errors in
5700 function values).
5701 
5702 INPUT PARAMETERS:
5703  XY - training set, array [0..NPoints-1,0..NVars]:
5704  * NVars columns - independent variables
5705  * last column - dependent variable
5706  S - standard deviations (errors in function values)
5707  array[0..NPoints-1], S[i]>0.
5708  NPoints - training set size, NPoints>NVars+1
5709  NVars - number of independent variables
5710 
5711 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
5712  Info - return code:
5713  * -255, in case of unknown internal error
5714  * -4, if internal SVD subroutine haven't converged
5715  * -1, if incorrect parameters was passed (NPoints<NVars+2, NVars<1).
5716  * -2, if S[I]<=0
5717  * 1, if subroutine successfully finished
5718  LM - linear model in the ALGLIB format. Use subroutines of
5719  this unit to work with the model.
5720  AR - additional results
5721 
5722 
5723  -- ALGLIB --
5724  Copyright 02.08.2008 by Bochkanov Sergey
5725 *************************************************************************/
5726 void lrbuilds(const real_2d_array &xy, const real_1d_array &s, const ae_int_t npoints, const ae_int_t nvars, ae_int_t &info, linearmodel &lm, lrreport &ar, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
5727 
5728 
5729 /*************************************************************************
5730 Like LRBuildS, but builds model
5731 
5732  Y = A(0)*X[0] + ... + A(N-1)*X[N-1]
5733 
5734 i.e. with zero constant term.
5735 
5736  -- ALGLIB --
5737  Copyright 30.10.2008 by Bochkanov Sergey
5738 *************************************************************************/
5739 void lrbuildzs(const real_2d_array &xy, const real_1d_array &s, const ae_int_t npoints, const ae_int_t nvars, ae_int_t &info, linearmodel &lm, lrreport &ar, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
5740 
5741 
5742 /*************************************************************************
5743 Like LRBuild but builds model
5744 
5745  Y = A(0)*X[0] + ... + A(N-1)*X[N-1]
5746 
5747 i.e. with zero constant term.
5748 
5749  -- ALGLIB --
5750  Copyright 30.10.2008 by Bochkanov Sergey
5751 *************************************************************************/
5752 void lrbuildz(const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints, const ae_int_t nvars, ae_int_t &info, linearmodel &lm, lrreport &ar, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
5753 
5754 
5755 /*************************************************************************
5756 Unpacks coefficients of linear model.
5757 
5758 INPUT PARAMETERS:
5759  LM - linear model in ALGLIB format
5760 
5761 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
5762  V - coefficients, array[0..NVars]
5763  constant term (intercept) is stored in the V[NVars].
5764  NVars - number of independent variables (one less than number
5765  of coefficients)
5766 
5767  -- ALGLIB --
5768  Copyright 30.08.2008 by Bochkanov Sergey
5769 *************************************************************************/
5770 void lrunpack(const linearmodel &lm, real_1d_array &v, ae_int_t &nvars, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
5771 
5772 
5773 /*************************************************************************
5774 "Packs" coefficients and creates linear model in ALGLIB format (LRUnpack
5775 reversed).
5776 
5777 INPUT PARAMETERS:
5778  V - coefficients, array[0..NVars]
5779  NVars - number of independent variables
5780 
5781 OUTPUT PAREMETERS:
5782  LM - linear model.
5783 
5784  -- ALGLIB --
5785  Copyright 30.08.2008 by Bochkanov Sergey
5786 *************************************************************************/
