5787 void lrpack(const real_1d_array &v, const ae_int_t nvars, linearmodel &lm, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
5788 
5789 
5790 /*************************************************************************
5791 Procesing
5792 
5793 INPUT PARAMETERS:
5794  LM - linear model
5795  X - input vector, array[0..NVars-1].
5796 
5797 Result:
5798  value of linear model regression estimate
5799 
5800  -- ALGLIB --
5801  Copyright 03.09.2008 by Bochkanov Sergey
5802 *************************************************************************/
5803 double lrprocess(const linearmodel &lm, const real_1d_array &x, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
5804 
5805 
5806 /*************************************************************************
5807 RMS error on the test set
5808 
5809 INPUT PARAMETERS:
5810  LM - linear model
5811  XY - test set
5812  NPoints - test set size
5813 
5814 RESULT:
5815  root mean square error.
5816 
5817  -- ALGLIB --
5818  Copyright 30.08.2008 by Bochkanov Sergey
5819 *************************************************************************/
5820 double lrrmserror(const linearmodel &lm, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
5821 
5822 
5823 /*************************************************************************
5824 Average error on the test set
5825 
5826 INPUT PARAMETERS:
5827  LM - linear model
5828  XY - test set
5829  NPoints - test set size
5830 
5831 RESULT:
5832  average error.
5833 
5834  -- ALGLIB --
5835  Copyright 30.08.2008 by Bochkanov Sergey
5836 *************************************************************************/
5837 double lravgerror(const linearmodel &lm, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
5838 
5839 
5840 /*************************************************************************
5841 RMS error on the test set
5842 
5843 INPUT PARAMETERS:
5844  LM - linear model
5845  XY - test set
5846  NPoints - test set size
5847 
5848 RESULT:
5849  average relative error.
5850 
5851  -- ALGLIB --
5852  Copyright 30.08.2008 by Bochkanov Sergey
5853 *************************************************************************/
5854 double lravgrelerror(const linearmodel &lm, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
5855 #endif
5856 
5857 #if defined(AE_COMPILE_FILTERS) || !defined(AE_PARTIAL_BUILD)
5858 /*************************************************************************
5859 Filters: simple moving averages (unsymmetric).
5860 
5861 This filter replaces array by results of SMA(K) filter. SMA(K) is defined
5862 as filter which averages at most K previous points (previous - not points
5863 AROUND central point) - or less, in case of the first K-1 points.
5864 
5865 INPUT PARAMETERS:
5866  X - array[N], array to process. It can be larger than N,
5867  in this case only first N points are processed.
5868  N - points count, N>=0
5869  K - K>=1 (K can be larger than N , such cases will be
5870  correctly handled). Window width. K=1 corresponds to
5871  identity transformation (nothing changes).
5872 
5873 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
5874  X - array, whose first N elements were processed with SMA(K)
5875 
5876 NOTE 1: this function uses efficient in-place algorithm which does not
5877  allocate temporary arrays.
5878 
5879 NOTE 2: this algorithm makes only one pass through array and uses running
5880  sum to speed-up calculation of the averages. Additional measures
5881  are taken to ensure that running sum on a long sequence of zero
5882  elements will be correctly reset to zero even in the presence of
5883  round-off error.
5884 
5885 NOTE 3: this is unsymmetric version of the algorithm, which does NOT
5886  averages points after the current one. Only X[i], X[i-1], ... are
5887  used when calculating new value of X[i]. We should also note that
5888  this algorithm uses BOTH previous points and current one, i.e.
5889  new value of X[i] depends on BOTH previous point and X[i] itself.
5890 
5891  -- ALGLIB --
5892  Copyright 25.10.2011 by Bochkanov Sergey
5893 *************************************************************************/
5894 void filtersma(real_1d_array &x, const ae_int_t n, const ae_int_t k, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
5895 void filtersma(real_1d_array &x, const ae_int_t k, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
5896 
5897 
5898 /*************************************************************************
5899 Filters: exponential moving averages.
5900 
5901 This filter replaces array by results of EMA(alpha) filter. EMA(alpha) is
5902 defined as filter which replaces X[] by S[]:
5903  S[0] = X[0]
5904  S[t] = alpha*X[t] + (1-alpha)*S[t-1]
5905 
5906 INPUT PARAMETERS:
5907  X - array[N], array to process. It can be larger than N,
5908  in this case only first N points are processed.
5909  N - points count, N>=0
5910  alpha - 0<alpha<=1, smoothing parameter.
5911 
5912 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
5913  X - array, whose first N elements were processed
5914  with EMA(alpha)
5915 
5916 NOTE 1: this function uses efficient in-place algorithm which does not
5917  allocate temporary arrays.
5918 
5919 NOTE 2: this algorithm uses BOTH previous points and current one, i.e.
5920  new value of X[i] depends on BOTH previous point and X[i] itself.
5921 
5922 NOTE 3: technical analytis users quite often work with EMA coefficient
5923  expressed in DAYS instead of fractions. If you want to calculate
5924  EMA(N), where N is a number of days, you can use alpha=2/(N+1).
5925 
5926  -- ALGLIB --
5927  Copyright 25.10.2011 by Bochkanov Sergey
5928 *************************************************************************/
5929 void filterema(real_1d_array &x, const ae_int_t n, const double alpha, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
5930 void filterema(real_1d_array &x, const double alpha, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
5931 
5932 
5933 /*************************************************************************
5934 Filters: linear regression moving averages.
5935 
5936 This filter replaces array by results of LRMA(K) filter.
5937 
5938 LRMA(K) is defined as filter which, for each data point, builds linear
5939 regression model using K prevous points (point itself is included in
5940 these K points) and calculates value of this linear model at the point in
5941 question.
5942 
5943 INPUT PARAMETERS:
5944  X - array[N], array to process. It can be larger than N,
5945  in this case only first N points are processed.
5946  N - points count, N>=0
5947  K - K>=1 (K can be larger than N , such cases will be
5948  correctly handled). Window width. K=1 corresponds to
5949  identity transformation (nothing changes).
5950 
5951 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
5952  X - array, whose first N elements were processed with SMA(K)
5953 
5954 NOTE 1: this function uses efficient in-place algorithm which does not
5955  allocate temporary arrays.
5956 
5957 NOTE 2: this algorithm makes only one pass through array and uses running
5958  sum to speed-up calculation of the averages. Additional measures
5959  are taken to ensure that running sum on a long sequence of zero
5960  elements will be correctly reset to zero even in the presence of
5961  round-off error.
5962 
5963 NOTE 3: this is unsymmetric version of the algorithm, which does NOT
5964  averages points after the current one. Only X[i], X[i-1], ... are
5965  used when calculating new value of X[i]. We should also note that
5966  this algorithm uses BOTH previous points and current one, i.e.
5967  new value of X[i] depends on BOTH previous point and X[i] itself.
5968 
5969  -- ALGLIB --
5970  Copyright 25.10.2011 by Bochkanov Sergey
5971 *************************************************************************/
5972 void filterlrma(real_1d_array &x, const ae_int_t n, const ae_int_t k, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
5973 void filterlrma(real_1d_array &x, const ae_int_t k, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
5974 #endif
5975 
5976 #if defined(AE_COMPILE_LOGIT) || !defined(AE_PARTIAL_BUILD)
5977 /*************************************************************************
5978 This subroutine trains logit model.
5979 
5980 INPUT PARAMETERS:
5981  XY - training set, array[0..NPoints-1,0..NVars]
5982  First NVars columns store values of independent
5983  variables, next column stores number of class (from 0
5984  to NClasses-1) which dataset element belongs to. Fractional
5985  values are rounded to nearest integer.
5986  NPoints - training set size, NPoints>=1
5987  NVars - number of independent variables, NVars>=1
5988  NClasses - number of classes, NClasses>=2
5989 
5990 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
5991  Info - return code:
5992  * -2, if there is a point with class number
5993  outside of [0..NClasses-1].
5994  * -1, if incorrect parameters was passed
5995  (NPoints<NVars+2, NVars<1, NClasses<2).
5996  * 1, if task has been solved
5997  LM - model built
5998  Rep - training report
5999 
6000  -- ALGLIB --
6001  Copyright 10.09.2008 by Bochkanov Sergey
6002 *************************************************************************/
6003 void mnltrainh(const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints, const ae_int_t nvars, const ae_int_t nclasses, ae_int_t &info, logitmodel &lm, mnlreport &rep, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
6004 
6005 
6006 /*************************************************************************
6007 Procesing
6008 
6009 INPUT PARAMETERS:
6010  LM - logit model, passed by non-constant reference
6011  (some fields of structure are used as temporaries
6012  when calculating model output).
6013  X - input vector, array[0..NVars-1].
6014  Y - (possibly) preallocated buffer; if size of Y is less than
6015  NClasses, it will be reallocated.If it is large enough, it
6016  is NOT reallocated, so we can save some time on reallocation.
6017 
6018 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
6019  Y - result, array[0..NClasses-1]
6020  Vector of posterior probabilities for classification task.
6021 
6022  -- ALGLIB --
6023  Copyright 10.09.2008 by Bochkanov Sergey
6024 *************************************************************************/
6025 void mnlprocess(const logitmodel &lm, const real_1d_array &x, real_1d_array &y, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
6026 
6027 
6028 /*************************************************************************
6029 'interactive' variant of MNLProcess for languages like Python which
6030 support constructs like "Y = MNLProcess(LM,X)" and interactive mode of the
6031 interpreter
6032 
6033 This function allocates new array on each call, so it is significantly
6034 slower than its 'non-interactive' counterpart, but it is more convenient
6035 when you call it from command line.
6036 
6037  -- ALGLIB --
6038  Copyright 10.09.2008 by Bochkanov Sergey
6039 *************************************************************************/
6040 void mnlprocessi(const logitmodel &lm, const real_1d_array &x, real_1d_array &y, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
6041 
6042 
6043 /*************************************************************************
6044 Unpacks coefficients of logit model. Logit model have form:
6045 
6046  P(class=i) = S(i) / (S(0) + S(1) + ... +S(M-1))
6047  S(i) = Exp(A[i,0]*X[0] + ... + A[i,N-1]*X[N-1] + A[i,N]), when i<M-1
6048  S(M-1) = 1
6049 
6050 INPUT PARAMETERS:
6051  LM - logit model in ALGLIB format
6052 
6053 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
6054  V - coefficients, array[0..NClasses-2,0..NVars]
6055  NVars - number of independent variables
6056  NClasses - number of classes
6057 
6058  -- ALGLIB --
6059  Copyright 10.09.2008 by Bochkanov Sergey
6060 *************************************************************************/
6061 void mnlunpack(const logitmodel &lm, real_2d_array &a, ae_int_t &nvars, ae_int_t &nclasses, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
6062 
6063 
6064 /*************************************************************************
6065 "Packs" coefficients and creates logit model in ALGLIB format (MNLUnpack
6066 reversed).
6067 
6068 INPUT PARAMETERS:
6069  A - model (see MNLUnpack)
6070  NVars - number of independent variables
6071  NClasses - number of classes
6072 
6073 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
6074  LM - logit model.
6075 
6076  -- ALGLIB --
6077  Copyright 10.09.2008 by Bochkanov Sergey
6078 *************************************************************************/
6079 void mnlpack(const real_2d_array &a, const ae_int_t nvars, const ae_int_t nclasses, logitmodel &lm, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
6080 
6081 
6082 /*************************************************************************
6083 Average cross-entropy (in bits per element) on the test set
6084 
6085 INPUT PARAMETERS:
6086  LM - logit model
6087  XY - test set
6088  NPoints - test set size
6089 
6090 RESULT:
6091  CrossEntropy/(NPoints*ln(2)).
6092 
6093  -- ALGLIB --
6094  Copyright 10.09.2008 by Bochkanov Sergey
6095 *************************************************************************/
6096 double mnlavgce(const logitmodel &lm, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
6097 
6098 
6099 /*************************************************************************
6100 Relative classification error on the test set
6101 
6102 INPUT PARAMETERS:
6103  LM - logit model
6104  XY - test set
6105  NPoints - test set size
6106 
6107 RESULT:
6108  percent of incorrectly classified cases.
6109 
6110  -- ALGLIB --
6111  Copyright 10.09.2008 by Bochkanov Sergey
6112 *************************************************************************/
6113 double mnlrelclserror(const logitmodel &lm, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
6114 
6115 
6116 /*************************************************************************
6117 RMS error on the test set
6118 
6119 INPUT PARAMETERS:
6120  LM - logit model
6121  XY - test set
6122  NPoints - test set size
6123 
6124 RESULT:
6125  root mean square error (error when estimating posterior probabilities).
6126 
6127  -- ALGLIB --
6128  Copyright 30.08.2008 by Bochkanov Sergey
6129 *************************************************************************/
6130 double mnlrmserror(const logitmodel &lm, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
6131 
6132 
6133 /*************************************************************************
6134 Average error on the test set
6135 
6136 INPUT PARAMETERS:
6137  LM - logit model
6138  XY - test set
6139  NPoints - test set size
6140 
6141 RESULT:
6142  average error (error when estimating posterior probabilities).
6143 
6144  -- ALGLIB --
6145  Copyright 30.08.2008 by Bochkanov Sergey
6146 *************************************************************************/
6147 double mnlavgerror(const logitmodel &lm, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
6148 
6149 
6150 /*************************************************************************
6151 Average relative error on the test set
6152 
6153 INPUT PARAMETERS:
6154  LM - logit model
6155  XY - test set
6156  NPoints - test set size
6157 
6158 RESULT:
6159  average relative error (error when estimating posterior probabilities).
6160 
6161  -- ALGLIB --
6162  Copyright 30.08.2008 by Bochkanov Sergey
6163 *************************************************************************/
6164 double mnlavgrelerror(const logitmodel &lm, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t ssize, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
6165 
6166 
6167 /*************************************************************************
6168 Classification error on test set = MNLRelClsError*NPoints
6169 
6170  -- ALGLIB --
6171  Copyright 10.09.2008 by Bochkanov Sergey
6172 *************************************************************************/
6173 ae_int_t mnlclserror(const logitmodel &lm, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
6174 #endif
6175 
6176 #if defined(AE_COMPILE_MCPD) || !defined(AE_PARTIAL_BUILD)
6177 /*************************************************************************
6178 DESCRIPTION:
6179 
6180 This function creates MCPD (Markov Chains for Population Data) solver.
6181 
6182 This solver can be used to find transition matrix P for N-dimensional
6183 prediction problem where transition from X[i] to X[i+1] is modelled as
6184  X[i+1] = P*X[i]
6185 where X[i] and X[i+1] are N-dimensional population vectors (components of
6186 each X are non-negative), and P is a N*N transition matrix (elements of P
6187 are non-negative, each column sums to 1.0).
6188 
6189 Such models arise when when:
6190 * there is some population of individuals
6191 * individuals can have different states
6192 * individuals can transit from one state to another
6193 * population size is constant, i.e. there is no new individuals and no one
6194  leaves population
6195 * you want to model transitions of individuals from one state into another
6196 
6197 USAGE:
6198 
6199 Here we give very brief outline of the MCPD. We strongly recommend you to
6200 read examples in the ALGLIB Reference Manual and to read ALGLIB User Guide
6201 on data analysis which is available at http://www.alglib.net/dataanalysis/
6202 
6203 1. User initializes algorithm state with MCPDCreate() call
6204 
6205 2. User adds one or more tracks - sequences of states which describe
6206  evolution of a system being modelled from different starting conditions
6207 
6208 3. User may add optional boundary, equality and/or linear constraints on
6209  the coefficients of P by calling one of the following functions:
6210  * MCPDSetEC() to set equality constraints
6211  * MCPDSetBC() to set bound constraints
6212  * MCPDSetLC() to set linear constraints
6213 
6214 4. Optionally, user may set custom weights for prediction errors (by
6215  default, algorithm assigns non-equal, automatically chosen weights for
6216  errors in the prediction of different components of X). It can be done
6217  with a call of MCPDSetPredictionWeights() function.
6218 
6219 5. User calls MCPDSolve() function which takes algorithm state and
6220  pointer (delegate, etc.) to callback function which calculates F/G.
6221 
6222 6. User calls MCPDResults() to get solution
6223 
6224 INPUT PARAMETERS:
6225  N - problem dimension, N>=1
6226 
6227 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
6228  State - structure stores algorithm state
6229 
6230  -- ALGLIB --
6231  Copyright 23.05.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
6232 *************************************************************************/
6233 void mcpdcreate(const ae_int_t n, mcpdstate &s, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
6234 
6235 
6236 /*************************************************************************
6237 DESCRIPTION:
6238 
6239 This function is a specialized version of MCPDCreate() function, and we
6240 recommend you to read comments for this function for general information
6241 about MCPD solver.
6242 
6243 This function creates MCPD (Markov Chains for Population Data) solver
6244 for "Entry-state" model, i.e. model where transition from X[i] to X[i+1]
6245 is modelled as
6246  X[i+1] = P*X[i]
6247 where
6248  X[i] and X[i+1] are N-dimensional state vectors
6249  P is a N*N transition matrix
6250 and one selected component of X[] is called "entry" state and is treated
6251 in a special way:
6252  system state always transits from "entry" state to some another state
6253  system state can not transit from any state into "entry" state
6254 Such conditions basically mean that row of P which corresponds to "entry"
6255 state is zero.
6256 
6257 Such models arise when:
6258 * there is some population of individuals
6259 * individuals can have different states
6260 * individuals can transit from one state to another
6261 * population size is NOT constant - at every moment of time there is some
6262  (unpredictable) amount of "new" individuals, which can transit into one
6263  of the states at the next turn, but still no one leaves population
6264 * you want to model transitions of individuals from one state into another
6265 * but you do NOT want to predict amount of "new" individuals because it
6266  does not depends on individuals already present (hence system can not
6267  transit INTO entry state - it can only transit FROM it).
6268 
6269 This model is discussed in more details in the ALGLIB User Guide (see
6270 http://www.alglib.net/dataanalysis/ for more data).
6271 
6272 INPUT PARAMETERS:
6273  N - problem dimension, N>=2
6274  EntryState- index of entry state, in 0..N-1
6275 
6276 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
6277  State - structure stores algorithm state
6278 
6279  -- ALGLIB --
6280  Copyright 23.05.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
6281 *************************************************************************/
6282 void mcpdcreateentry(const ae_int_t n, const ae_int_t entrystate, mcpdstate &s, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
6283 
6284 
6285 /*************************************************************************
6286 DESCRIPTION:
6287 
6288 This function is a specialized version of MCPDCreate() function, and we
6289 recommend you to read comments for this function for general information
6290 about MCPD solver.
6291 
6292 This function creates MCPD (Markov Chains for Population Data) solver
6293 for "Exit-state" model, i.e. model where transition from X[i] to X[i+1]
6294 is modelled as
6295  X[i+1] = P*X[i]
6296 where
6297  X[i] and X[i+1] are N-dimensional state vectors
6298  P is a N*N transition matrix
6299 and one selected component of X[] is called "exit" state and is treated
6300 in a special way:
6301  system state can transit from any state into "exit" state
6302  system state can not transit from "exit" state into any other state
6303  transition operator discards "exit" state (makes it zero at each turn)
6304 Such conditions basically mean that column of P which corresponds to
6305 "exit" state is zero. Multiplication by such P may decrease sum of vector
6306 components.
6307 
6308 Such models arise when:
6309 * there is some population of individuals
6310 * individuals can have different states
6311 * individuals can transit from one state to another
6312 * population size is NOT constant - individuals can move into "exit" state
6313  and leave population at the next turn, but there are no new individuals
6314 * amount of individuals which leave population can be predicted
6315 * you want to model transitions of individuals from one state into another
6316  (including transitions into the "exit" state)
6317 
6318 This model is discussed in more details in the ALGLIB User Guide (see
6319 http://www.alglib.net/dataanalysis/ for more data).
6320 
6321 INPUT PARAMETERS:
6322  N - problem dimension, N>=2
6323  ExitState- index of exit state, in 0..N-1
6324 
6325 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
6326  State - structure stores algorithm state
6327 
6328  -- ALGLIB --
6329  Copyright 23.05.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
6330 *************************************************************************/
6331 void mcpdcreateexit(const ae_int_t n, const ae_int_t exitstate, mcpdstate &s, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
6332 
6333 
6334 /*************************************************************************
6335 DESCRIPTION:
6336 
6337 This function is a specialized version of MCPDCreate() function, and we
6338 recommend you to read comments for this function for general information
6339 about MCPD solver.
6340 
6341 This function creates MCPD (Markov Chains for Population Data) solver
6342 for "Entry-Exit-states" model, i.e. model where transition from X[i] to
6343 X[i+1] is modelled as
6344  X[i+1] = P*X[i]
6345 where
6346  X[i] and X[i+1] are N-dimensional state vectors
6347  P is a N*N transition matrix
6348 one selected component of X[] is called "entry" state and is treated in a
6349 special way:
6350  system state always transits from "entry" state to some another state
6351  system state can not transit from any state into "entry" state
6352 and another one component of X[] is called "exit" state and is treated in
6353 a special way too:
6354  system state can transit from any state into "exit" state
6355  system state can not transit from "exit" state into any other state
6356  transition operator discards "exit" state (makes it zero at each turn)
6357 Such conditions basically mean that:
6358  row of P which corresponds to "entry" state is zero
6359  column of P which corresponds to "exit" state is zero
6360 Multiplication by such P may decrease sum of vector components.
6361 
6362 Such models arise when:
6363 * there is some population of individuals
6364 * individuals can have different states
6365 * individuals can transit from one state to another
6366 * population size is NOT constant
6367 * at every moment of time there is some (unpredictable) amount of "new"
6368  individuals, which can transit into one of the states at the next turn
6369 * some individuals can move (predictably) into "exit" state and leave
6370  population at the next turn
6371 * you want to model transitions of individuals from one state into another,
6372  including transitions from the "entry" state and into the "exit" state.
6373 * but you do NOT want to predict amount of "new" individuals because it
6374  does not depends on individuals already present (hence system can not
6375  transit INTO entry state - it can only transit FROM it).
6376 
6377 This model is discussed in more details in the ALGLIB User Guide (see
6378 http://www.alglib.net/dataanalysis/ for more data).
6379 
6380 INPUT PARAMETERS:
6381  N - problem dimension, N>=2
6382  EntryState- index of entry state, in 0..N-1
6383  ExitState- index of exit state, in 0..N-1
6384 
6385 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
6386  State - structure stores algorithm state
6387 
6388  -- ALGLIB --
6389  Copyright 23.05.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
6390 *************************************************************************/
6391 void mcpdcreateentryexit(const ae_int_t n, const ae_int_t entrystate, const ae_int_t exitstate, mcpdstate &s, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
6392 
6393 
6394 /*************************************************************************
6395 This function is used to add a track - sequence of system states at the
6396 different moments of its evolution.
6397 
6398 You may add one or several tracks to the MCPD solver. In case you have
6399 several tracks, they won't overwrite each other. For example, if you pass
6400 two tracks, A1-A2-A3 (system at t=A+1, t=A+2 and t=A+3) and B1-B2-B3, then
6401 solver will try to model transitions from t=A+1 to t=A+2, t=A+2 to t=A+3,
6402 t=B+1 to t=B+2, t=B+2 to t=B+3. But it WONT mix these two tracks - i.e. it
6403 wont try to model transition from t=A+3 to t=B+1.
6404 
6405 INPUT PARAMETERS:
6406  S - solver
6407  XY - track, array[K,N]:
6408  * I-th row is a state at t=I
6409  * elements of XY must be non-negative (exception will be
6410  thrown on negative elements)
6411  K - number of points in a track
6412  * if given, only leading K rows of XY are used
6413  * if not given, automatically determined from size of XY
6414 
6415 NOTES:
6416 
6417 1. Track may contain either proportional or population data:
6418  * with proportional data all rows of XY must sum to 1.0, i.e. we have
6419  proportions instead of absolute population values
6420  * with population data rows of XY contain population counts and generally
6421  do not sum to 1.0 (although they still must be non-negative)
6422 
6423  -- ALGLIB --
6424  Copyright 23.05.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
6425 *************************************************************************/
6426 void mcpdaddtrack(const mcpdstate &s, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t k, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
6427 void mcpdaddtrack(const mcpdstate &s, const real_2d_array &xy, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
6428 
6429 
6430 /*************************************************************************
6431 This function is used to add equality constraints on the elements of the
6432 transition matrix P.
6433 
6434 MCPD solver has four types of constraints which can be placed on P:
6435 * user-specified equality constraints (optional)
6436 * user-specified bound constraints (optional)
6437 * user-specified general linear constraints (optional)
6438 * basic constraints (always present):
6439  * non-negativity: P[i,j]>=0
6440  * consistency: every column of P sums to 1.0
6441 
6442 Final constraints which are passed to the underlying optimizer are
6443 calculated as intersection of all present constraints. For example, you
6444 may specify boundary constraint on P[0,0] and equality one:
6445  0.1<=P[0,0]<=0.9
6446  P[0,0]=0.5
6447 Such combination of constraints will be silently reduced to their
6448 intersection, which is P[0,0]=0.5.
6449 
6450 This function can be used to place equality constraints on arbitrary
6451 subset of elements of P. Set of constraints is specified by EC, which may
6452 contain either NAN's or finite numbers from [0,1]. NAN denotes absence of
6453 constraint, finite number denotes equality constraint on specific element
6454 of P.
6455 
6456 You can also use MCPDAddEC() function which allows to ADD equality
6457 constraint for one element of P without changing constraints for other
6458 elements.
6459 
6460 These functions (MCPDSetEC and MCPDAddEC) interact as follows:
6461 * there is internal matrix of equality constraints which is stored in the
6462  MCPD solver
6463 * MCPDSetEC() replaces this matrix by another one (SET)
6464 * MCPDAddEC() modifies one element of this matrix and leaves other ones
6465  unchanged (ADD)
6466 * thus MCPDAddEC() call preserves all modifications done by previous
6467  calls, while MCPDSetEC() completely discards all changes done to the
6468  equality constraints.
6469 
6470 INPUT PARAMETERS:
6471  S - solver
6472  EC - equality constraints, array[N,N]. Elements of EC can be
6473  either NAN's or finite numbers from [0,1]. NAN denotes
6474  absence of constraints, while finite value denotes
6475  equality constraint on the corresponding element of P.
6476 
6477 NOTES:
6478 
6479 1. infinite values of EC will lead to exception being thrown. Values less
6480 than 0.0 or greater than 1.0 will lead to error code being returned after
6481 call to MCPDSolve().
6482 
6483  -- ALGLIB --
6484  Copyright 23.05.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
6485 *************************************************************************/
6486 void mcpdsetec(const mcpdstate &s, const real_2d_array &ec, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
6487 
6488 
6489 /*************************************************************************
6490 This function is used to add equality constraints on the elements of the
6491 transition matrix P.
6492 
6493 MCPD solver has four types of constraints which can be placed on P:
6494 * user-specified equality constraints (optional)
6495 * user-specified bound constraints (optional)
6496 * user-specified general linear constraints (optional)
6497 * basic constraints (always present):
6498  * non-negativity: P[i,j]>=0
6499  * consistency: every column of P sums to 1.0
6500 
6501 Final constraints which are passed to the underlying optimizer are
6502 calculated as intersection of all present constraints. For example, you
6503 may specify boundary constraint on P[0,0] and equality one:
6504  0.1<=P[0,0]<=0.9
6505  P[0,0]=0.5
6506 Such combination of constraints will be silently reduced to their
6507 intersection, which is P[0,0]=0.5.
6508 
6509 This function can be used to ADD equality constraint for one element of P
6510 without changing constraints for other elements.
6511 
6512 You can also use MCPDSetEC() function which allows you to specify
6513 arbitrary set of equality constraints in one call.
6514 
6515 These functions (MCPDSetEC and MCPDAddEC) interact as follows:
6516 * there is internal matrix of equality constraints which is stored in the
6517  MCPD solver
6518 * MCPDSetEC() replaces this matrix by another one (SET)
6519 * MCPDAddEC() modifies one element of this matrix and leaves other ones
6520  unchanged (ADD)
6521 * thus MCPDAddEC() call preserves all modifications done by previous
6522  calls, while MCPDSetEC() completely discards all changes done to the
6523  equality constraints.
6524 
6525 INPUT PARAMETERS:
6526  S - solver
6527  I - row index of element being constrained
6528  J - column index of element being constrained
6529  C - value (constraint for P[I,J]). Can be either NAN (no
6530  constraint) or finite value from [0,1].
6531 
6532 NOTES:
6533 
6534 1. infinite values of C will lead to exception being thrown. Values less
6535 than 0.0 or greater than 1.0 will lead to error code being returned after
6536 call to MCPDSolve().
6537 
6538  -- ALGLIB --
6539  Copyright 23.05.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
6540 *************************************************************************/
6541 void mcpdaddec(const mcpdstate &s, const ae_int_t i, const ae_int_t j, const double c, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
6542 
6543 
6544 /*************************************************************************
6545 This function is used to add bound constraints on the elements of the
6546 transition matrix P.
6547 
6548 MCPD solver has four types of constraints which can be placed on P:
6549 * user-specified equality constraints (optional)
6550 * user-specified bound constraints (optional)
6551 * user-specified general linear constraints (optional)
6552 * basic constraints (always present):
6553  * non-negativity: P[i,j]>=0
6554  * consistency: every column of P sums to 1.0
6555 
6556 Final constraints which are passed to the underlying optimizer are
6557 calculated as intersection of all present constraints. For example, you
6558 may specify boundary constraint on P[0,0] and equality one:
6559  0.1<=P[0,0]<=0.9
6560  P[0,0]=0.5
6561 Such combination of constraints will be silently reduced to their
6562 intersection, which is P[0,0]=0.5.
6563 
6564 This function can be used to place bound constraints on arbitrary
6565 subset of elements of P. Set of constraints is specified by BndL/BndU
6566 matrices, which may contain arbitrary combination of finite numbers or
6567 infinities (like -INF<x<=0.5 or 0.1<=x<+INF).
6568 
6569 You can also use MCPDAddBC() function which allows to ADD bound constraint
6570 for one element of P without changing constraints for other elements.
6571 
6572 These functions (MCPDSetBC and MCPDAddBC) interact as follows:
6573 * there is internal matrix of bound constraints which is stored in the
6574  MCPD solver
6575 * MCPDSetBC() replaces this matrix by another one (SET)
6576 * MCPDAddBC() modifies one element of this matrix and leaves other ones
6577  unchanged (ADD)
6578 * thus MCPDAddBC() call preserves all modifications done by previous
6579  calls, while MCPDSetBC() completely discards all changes done to the
6580  equality constraints.
6581 
6582 INPUT PARAMETERS:
6583  S - solver
6584  BndL - lower bounds constraints, array[N,N]. Elements of BndL can
6585  be finite numbers or -INF.
6586  BndU - upper bounds constraints, array[N,N]. Elements of BndU can
6587  be finite numbers or +INF.
6588 
6589  -- ALGLIB --
6590  Copyright 23.05.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
6591 *************************************************************************/
6592 void mcpdsetbc(const mcpdstate &s, const real_2d_array &bndl, const real_2d_array &bndu, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
6593 
6594 
6595 /*************************************************************************
6596 This function is used to add bound constraints on the elements of the
6597 transition matrix P.
6598 
6599 MCPD solver has four types of constraints which can be placed on P:
6600 * user-specified equality constraints (optional)
6601 * user-specified bound constraints (optional)
6602 * user-specified general linear constraints (optional)
6603 * basic constraints (always present):
6604  * non-negativity: P[i,j]>=0
6605  * consistency: every column of P sums to 1.0
6606 
6607 Final constraints which are passed to the underlying optimizer are
6608 calculated as intersection of all present constraints. For example, you
6609 may specify boundary constraint on P[0,0] and equality one:
6610  0.1<=P[0,0]<=0.9
6611  P[0,0]=0.5
6612 Such combination of constraints will be silently reduced to their
6613 intersection, which is P[0,0]=0.5.
6614 
6615 This function can be used to ADD bound constraint for one element of P
6616 without changing constraints for other elements.
6617 
6618 You can also use MCPDSetBC() function which allows to place bound
6619 constraints on arbitrary subset of elements of P. Set of constraints is
6620 specified by BndL/BndU matrices, which may contain arbitrary combination
6621 of finite numbers or infinities (like -INF<x<=0.5 or 0.1<=x<+INF).
6622 
6623 These functions (MCPDSetBC and MCPDAddBC) interact as follows:
6624 * there is internal matrix of bound constraints which is stored in the
6625  MCPD solver
6626 * MCPDSetBC() replaces this matrix by another one (SET)
6627 * MCPDAddBC() modifies one element of this matrix and leaves other ones
6628  unchanged (ADD)
6629 * thus MCPDAddBC() call preserves all modifications done by previous
6630  calls, while MCPDSetBC() completely discards all changes done to the
6631  equality constraints.
6632 
6633 INPUT PARAMETERS:
6634  S - solver
6635  I - row index of element being constrained
6636  J - column index of element being constrained
6637  BndL - lower bound
6638  BndU - upper bound
6639 
6640  -- ALGLIB --
6641  Copyright 23.05.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
6642 *************************************************************************/
6643 void mcpdaddbc(const mcpdstate &s, const ae_int_t i, const ae_int_t j, const double bndl, const double bndu, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
6644 
6645 
6646 /*************************************************************************
6647 This function is used to set linear equality/inequality constraints on the
6648 elements of the transition matrix P.
6649 
6650 This function can be used to set one or several general linear constraints
6651 on the elements of P. Two types of constraints are supported:
6652 * equality constraints
6653 * inequality constraints (both less-or-equal and greater-or-equal)
6654 
6655 Coefficients of constraints are specified by matrix C (one of the
6656 parameters). One row of C corresponds to one constraint. Because
6657 transition matrix P has N*N elements, we need N*N columns to store all
6658 coefficients (they are stored row by row), and one more column to store
6659 right part - hence C has N*N+1 columns. Constraint kind is stored in the
6660 CT array.
6661 
6662 Thus, I-th linear constraint is
6663  P[0,0]*C[I,0] + P[0,1]*C[I,1] + .. + P[0,N-1]*C[I,N-1] +
6664  + P[1,0]*C[I,N] + P[1,1]*C[I,N+1] + ... +
6665  + P[N-1,N-1]*C[I,N*N-1] ?=? C[I,N*N]
6666 where ?=? can be either "=" (CT[i]=0), "<=" (CT[i]<0) or ">=" (CT[i]>0).
6667 
6668 Your constraint may involve only some subset of P (less than N*N elements).
6669 For example it can be something like
6670  P[0,0] + P[0,1] = 0.5
6671 In this case you still should pass matrix with N*N+1 columns, but all its
6672 elements (except for C[0,0], C[0,1] and C[0,N*N-1]) will be zero.
6673 
6674 INPUT PARAMETERS:
6675  S - solver
6676  C - array[K,N*N+1] - coefficients of constraints
6677  (see above for complete description)
6678  CT - array[K] - constraint types
6679  (see above for complete description)
6680  K - number of equality/inequality constraints, K>=0:
6681  * if given, only leading K elements of C/CT are used
6682  * if not given, automatically determined from sizes of C/CT
6683 
6684  -- ALGLIB --
6685  Copyright 23.05.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
6686 *************************************************************************/
6687 void mcpdsetlc(const mcpdstate &s, const real_2d_array &c, const integer_1d_array &ct, const ae_int_t k, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
6688 void mcpdsetlc(const mcpdstate &s, const real_2d_array &c, const integer_1d_array &ct, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
6689 
6690 
6691 /*************************************************************************
6692 This function allows to tune amount of Tikhonov regularization being
6693 applied to your problem.
6694 
6695 By default, regularizing term is equal to r*||P-prior_P||^2, where r is a
6696 small non-zero value, P is transition matrix, prior_P is identity matrix,
6697 ||X||^2 is a sum of squared elements of X.
6698 
6699 This function allows you to change coefficient r. You can also change
6700 prior values with MCPDSetPrior() function.
6701 
6702 INPUT PARAMETERS:
6703  S - solver
6704  V - regularization coefficient, finite non-negative value. It
6705  is not recommended to specify zero value unless you are
6706  pretty sure that you want it.
6707 
6708  -- ALGLIB --
6709  Copyright 23.05.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
6710 *************************************************************************/
6711 void mcpdsettikhonovregularizer(const mcpdstate &s, const double v, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
6712 
6713 
6714 /*************************************************************************
6715 This function allows to set prior values used for regularization of your
6716 problem.
6717 
6718 By default, regularizing term is equal to r*||P-prior_P||^2, where r is a
6719 small non-zero value, P is transition matrix, prior_P is identity matrix,
6720 ||X||^2 is a sum of squared elements of X.
6721 
6722 This function allows you to change prior values prior_P. You can also
6723 change r with MCPDSetTikhonovRegularizer() function.
6724 
6725 INPUT PARAMETERS:
6726  S - solver
6727  PP - array[N,N], matrix of prior values:
6728  1. elements must be real numbers from [0,1]
6729  2. columns must sum to 1.0.
6730  First property is checked (exception is thrown otherwise),
6731  while second one is not checked/enforced.
6732 
6733  -- ALGLIB --
6734  Copyright 23.05.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
6735 *************************************************************************/
6736 void mcpdsetprior(const mcpdstate &s, const real_2d_array &pp, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
6737 
6738 
6739 /*************************************************************************
6740 This function is used to change prediction weights
6741 
6742 MCPD solver scales prediction errors as follows
6743  Error(P) = ||W*(y-P*x)||^2
6744 where
6745  x is a system state at time t
6746  y is a system state at time t+1
6747  P is a transition matrix
6748  W is a diagonal scaling matrix
6749 
6750 By default, weights are chosen in order to minimize relative prediction
6751 error instead of absolute one. For example, if one component of state is
6752 about 0.5 in magnitude and another one is about 0.05, then algorithm will
6753 make corresponding weights equal to 2.0 and 20.0.
6754 
6755 INPUT PARAMETERS:
6756  S - solver
6757  PW - array[N], weights:
6758  * must be non-negative values (exception will be thrown otherwise)
6759  * zero values will be replaced by automatically chosen values
6760 
6761  -- ALGLIB --
6762  Copyright 23.05.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
6763 *************************************************************************/
6764 void mcpdsetpredictionweights(const mcpdstate &s, const real_1d_array &pw, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
6765 
6766 
6767 /*************************************************************************
6768 This function is used to start solution of the MCPD problem.
6769 
6770 After return from this function, you can use MCPDResults() to get solution
6771 and completion code.
6772 
6773  -- ALGLIB --
6774  Copyright 23.05.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
6775 *************************************************************************/
6776 void mcpdsolve(const mcpdstate &s, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
6777 
6778 
6779 /*************************************************************************
6780 MCPD results
6781 
6782 INPUT PARAMETERS:
6783  State - algorithm state
6784 
6785 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
6786  P - array[N,N], transition matrix
6787  Rep - optimization report. You should check Rep.TerminationType
6788  in order to distinguish successful termination from
6789  unsuccessful one. Speaking short, positive values denote
6790  success, negative ones are failures.
6791  More information about fields of this structure can be
6792  found in the comments on MCPDReport datatype.
6793 
6794 
6795  -- ALGLIB --
6796  Copyright 23.05.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
6797 *************************************************************************/
6798 void mcpdresults(const mcpdstate &s, real_2d_array &p, mcpdreport &rep, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
6799 #endif
6800 
6801 #if defined(AE_COMPILE_MLPE) || !defined(AE_PARTIAL_BUILD)
6802 /*************************************************************************
6803 This function serializes data structure to string.
6804 
6805 Important properties of s_out:
6806 * it contains alphanumeric characters, dots, underscores, minus signs
6807 * these symbols are grouped into words, which are separated by spaces
6808  and Windows-style (CR+LF) newlines
6809 * although serializer uses spaces and CR+LF as separators, you can
6810  replace any separator character by arbitrary combination of spaces,
6811  tabs, Windows or Unix newlines. It allows flexible reformatting of
6812  the string in case you want to include it into text or XML file.
6813  But you should not insert separators into the middle of the "words"
6814  nor you should change case of letters.
6815 * s_out can be freely moved between 32-bit and 64-bit systems, little
6816  and big endian machines, and so on. You can serialize structure on
6817  32-bit machine and unserialize it on 64-bit one (or vice versa), or
6818  serialize it on SPARC and unserialize on x86. You can also
6819  serialize it in C++ version of ALGLIB and unserialize in C# one,
6820  and vice versa.
6821 *************************************************************************/
6822 void mlpeserialize(mlpensemble &obj, std::string &s_out);
6823 
6824 
6825 /*************************************************************************
6826 This function unserializes data structure from string.
6827 *************************************************************************/
6828 void mlpeunserialize(const std::string &s_in, mlpensemble &obj);
6829 
6830 
6831 
6832 
6833 /*************************************************************************
6834 This function serializes data structure to C++ stream.
6835 
6836 Data stream generated by this function is same as string representation
6837 generated by string version of serializer - alphanumeric characters,
6838 dots, underscores, minus signs, which are grouped into words separated by
6839 spaces and CR+LF.
6840 
6841 We recommend you to read comments on string version of serializer to find
6842 out more about serialization of AlGLIB objects.
6843 *************************************************************************/
6844 void mlpeserialize(mlpensemble &obj, std::ostream &s_out);
6845 
6846 
6847 /*************************************************************************
6848 This function unserializes data structure from stream.
6849 *************************************************************************/
6850 void mlpeunserialize(const std::istream &s_in, mlpensemble &obj);
6851

6987 
6988 /*************************************************************************
6989 Return normalization type (whether ensemble is SOFTMAX-normalized or not).
6990 
6991  -- ALGLIB --
6992  Copyright 17.02.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
6993 *************************************************************************/
6994 bool mlpeissoftmax(const mlpensemble &ensemble, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
6995 
6996 
6997 /*************************************************************************
6998 Procesing
6999 
7000 INPUT PARAMETERS:
7001  Ensemble- neural networks ensemble
7002  X - input vector, array[0..NIn-1].
7003  Y - (possibly) preallocated buffer; if size of Y is less than
7004  NOut, it will be reallocated. If it is large enough, it
7005  is NOT reallocated, so we can save some time on reallocation.
7006 
7007 
7008 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
7009  Y - result. Regression estimate when solving regression task,
7010  vector of posterior probabilities for classification task.
7011 
7012  -- ALGLIB --
7013  Copyright 17.02.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
7014 *************************************************************************/
7015 void mlpeprocess(const mlpensemble &ensemble, const real_1d_array &x, real_1d_array &y, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
7016 
7017 
7018 /*************************************************************************
7019 'interactive' variant of MLPEProcess for languages like Python which
7020 support constructs like "Y = MLPEProcess(LM,X)" and interactive mode of the
7021 interpreter
7022 
7023 This function allocates new array on each call, so it is significantly
7024 slower than its 'non-interactive' counterpart, but it is more convenient
7025 when you call it from command line.
7026 
7027  -- ALGLIB --
7028  Copyright 17.02.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
7029 *************************************************************************/
7030 void mlpeprocessi(const mlpensemble &ensemble, const real_1d_array &x, real_1d_array &y, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
7031 
7032 
7033 /*************************************************************************
7034 Relative classification error on the test set
7035 
7036 INPUT PARAMETERS:
7037  Ensemble- ensemble
7038  XY - test set
7039  NPoints - test set size
7040 
7041 RESULT:
7042  percent of incorrectly classified cases.
7043  Works both for classifier betwork and for regression networks which
7044 are used as classifiers.
7045 
7046  -- ALGLIB --
7047  Copyright 17.02.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
7048 *************************************************************************/
7049 double mlperelclserror(const mlpensemble &ensemble, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
7050 
7051 
7052 /*************************************************************************
7053 Average cross-entropy (in bits per element) on the test set
7054 
7055 INPUT PARAMETERS:
7056  Ensemble- ensemble
7057  XY - test set
7058  NPoints - test set size
7059 
7060 RESULT:
7061  CrossEntropy/(NPoints*LN(2)).
7062  Zero if ensemble solves regression task.
7063 
7064  -- ALGLIB --
7065  Copyright 17.02.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
7066 *************************************************************************/
7067 double mlpeavgce(const mlpensemble &ensemble, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
7068 
7069 
7070 /*************************************************************************
7071 RMS error on the test set
7072 
7073 INPUT PARAMETERS:
7074  Ensemble- ensemble
7075  XY - test set
7076  NPoints - test set size
7077 
7078 RESULT:
7079  root mean square error.
7080  Its meaning for regression task is obvious. As for classification task
7081 RMS error means error when estimating posterior probabilities.
7082 
7083  -- ALGLIB --
7084  Copyright 17.02.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
7085 *************************************************************************/
7086 double mlpermserror(const mlpensemble &ensemble, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
7087 
7088 
7089 /*************************************************************************
7090 Average error on the test set
7091 
7092 INPUT PARAMETERS:
7093  Ensemble- ensemble
7094  XY - test set
7095  NPoints - test set size
7096 
7097 RESULT:
7098  Its meaning for regression task is obvious. As for classification task
7099 it means average error when estimating posterior probabilities.
7100 
7101  -- ALGLIB --
7102  Copyright 17.02.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
7103 *************************************************************************/
7104 double mlpeavgerror(const mlpensemble &ensemble, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
7105 
7106 
7107 /*************************************************************************
7108 Average relative error on the test set
7109 
7110 INPUT PARAMETERS:
7111  Ensemble- ensemble
7112  XY - test set
7113  NPoints - test set size
7114 
7115 RESULT:
7116  Its meaning for regression task is obvious. As for classification task
7117 it means average relative error when estimating posterior probabilities.
7118 
7119  -- ALGLIB --
7120  Copyright 17.02.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
7121 *************************************************************************/
7122 double mlpeavgrelerror(const mlpensemble &ensemble, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
7123 #endif
7124 
7125 #if defined(AE_COMPILE_MLPTRAIN) || !defined(AE_PARTIAL_BUILD)
7126 /*************************************************************************
7127 Neural network training using modified Levenberg-Marquardt with exact
7128 Hessian calculation and regularization. Subroutine trains neural network
7129 with restarts from random positions. Algorithm is well suited for small
7130 and medium scale problems (hundreds of weights).
7131 
7132 INPUT PARAMETERS:
7133  Network - neural network with initialized geometry
7134  XY - training set
7135  NPoints - training set size
7136  Decay - weight decay constant, >=0.001
7137  Decay term 'Decay*||Weights||^2' is added to error
7138  function.
7139  If you don't know what Decay to choose, use 0.001.
7140  Restarts - number of restarts from random position, >0.
7141  If you don't know what Restarts to choose, use 2.
7142 
7143 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
7144  Network - trained neural network.
7145  Info - return code:
7146  * -9, if internal matrix inverse subroutine failed
7147  * -2, if there is a point with class number
7148  outside of [0..NOut-1].
7149  * -1, if wrong parameters specified
7150  (NPoints<0, Restarts<1).
7151  * 2, if task has been solved.
7152  Rep - training report
7153 
7154  -- ALGLIB --
7155  Copyright 10.03.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
7156 *************************************************************************/
7157 void mlptrainlm(const multilayerperceptron &network, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints, const double decay, const ae_int_t restarts, ae_int_t &info, mlpreport &rep, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
7158 
7159 
7160 /*************************************************************************
7161 Neural network training using L-BFGS algorithm with regularization.
7162 Subroutine trains neural network with restarts from random positions.
7163 Algorithm is well suited for problems of any dimensionality (memory
7164 requirements and step complexity are linear by weights number).
7165 
7166 INPUT PARAMETERS:
7167  Network - neural network with initialized geometry
7168  XY - training set
7169  NPoints - training set size
7170  Decay - weight decay constant, >=0.001
7171  Decay term 'Decay*||Weights||^2' is added to error
7172  function.
7173  If you don't know what Decay to choose, use 0.001.
7174  Restarts - number of restarts from random position, >0.
7175  If you don't know what Restarts to choose, use 2.
7176  WStep - stopping criterion. Algorithm stops if step size is
7177  less than WStep. Recommended value - 0.01. Zero step
7178  size means stopping after MaxIts iterations.
7179  MaxIts - stopping criterion. Algorithm stops after MaxIts
7180  iterations (NOT gradient calculations). Zero MaxIts
7181  means stopping when step is sufficiently small.
7182 
7183 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
7184  Network - trained neural network.
7185  Info - return code:
7186  * -8, if both WStep=0 and MaxIts=0
7187  * -2, if there is a point with class number
7188  outside of [0..NOut-1].
7189  * -1, if wrong parameters specified
7190  (NPoints<0, Restarts<1).
7191  * 2, if task has been solved.
7192  Rep - training report
7193 
7194  -- ALGLIB --
7195  Copyright 09.12.2007 by Bochkanov Sergey
7196 *************************************************************************/
7197 void mlptrainlbfgs(const multilayerperceptron &network, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints, const double decay, const ae_int_t restarts, const double wstep, const ae_int_t maxits, ae_int_t &info, mlpreport &rep, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
7198 
7199 
7200 /*************************************************************************
7201 Neural network training using early stopping (base algorithm - L-BFGS with
7202 regularization).
7203 
7204 INPUT PARAMETERS:
7205  Network - neural network with initialized geometry
7206  TrnXY - training set
7207  TrnSize - training set size, TrnSize>0
7208  ValXY - validation set
7209  ValSize - validation set size, ValSize>0
7210  Decay - weight decay constant, >=0.001
7211  Decay term 'Decay*||Weights||^2' is added to error
7212  function.
7213  If you don't know what Decay to choose, use 0.001.
7214  Restarts - number of restarts, either:
7215  * strictly positive number - algorithm make specified
7216  number of restarts from random position.
7217  * -1, in which case algorithm makes exactly one run
7218  from the initial state of the network (no randomization).
7219  If you don't know what Restarts to choose, choose one
7220  one the following:
7221  * -1 (deterministic start)
7222  * +1 (one random restart)
7223  * +5 (moderate amount of random restarts)
7224 
7225 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
7226  Network - trained neural network.
7227  Info - return code:
7228  * -2, if there is a point with class number
7229  outside of [0..NOut-1].
7230  * -1, if wrong parameters specified
7231  (NPoints<0, Restarts<1, ...).
7232  * 2, task has been solved, stopping criterion met -
7233  sufficiently small step size. Not expected (we
7234  use EARLY stopping) but possible and not an
7235  error.
7236  * 6, task has been solved, stopping criterion met -
7237  increasing of validation set error.
7238  Rep - training report
7239 
7240 NOTE:
7241 
7242 Algorithm stops if validation set error increases for a long enough or
7243 step size is small enought (there are task where validation set may
7244 decrease for eternity). In any case solution returned corresponds to the
7245 minimum of validation set error.
7246 
7247  -- ALGLIB --
7248  Copyright 10.03.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
7249 *************************************************************************/
7250 void mlptraines(const multilayerperceptron &network, const real_2d_array &trnxy, const ae_int_t trnsize, const real_2d_array &valxy, const ae_int_t valsize, const double decay, const ae_int_t restarts, ae_int_t &info, mlpreport &rep, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
7251 
7252 
7253 /*************************************************************************
7254 Cross-validation estimate of generalization error.
7255 
7256 Base algorithm - L-BFGS.
7257 
7258 INPUT PARAMETERS:
7259  Network - neural network with initialized geometry. Network is
7260  not changed during cross-validation - it is used only
7261  as a representative of its architecture.
7262  XY - training set.
7263  SSize - training set size
7264  Decay - weight decay, same as in MLPTrainLBFGS
7265  Restarts - number of restarts, >0.
7266  restarts are counted for each partition separately, so
7267  total number of restarts will be Restarts*FoldsCount.
7268  WStep - stopping criterion, same as in MLPTrainLBFGS
7269  MaxIts - stopping criterion, same as in MLPTrainLBFGS
7270  FoldsCount - number of folds in k-fold cross-validation,
7271  2<=FoldsCount<=SSize.
7272  recommended value: 10.
7273 
7274 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
7275  Info - return code, same as in MLPTrainLBFGS
7276  Rep - report, same as in MLPTrainLM/MLPTrainLBFGS
7277  CVRep - generalization error estimates
7278 
7279  -- ALGLIB --
7280  Copyright 09.12.2007 by Bochkanov Sergey
7281 *************************************************************************/
7282 void mlpkfoldcvlbfgs(const multilayerperceptron &network, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints, const double decay, const ae_int_t restarts, const double wstep, const ae_int_t maxits, const ae_int_t foldscount, ae_int_t &info, mlpreport &rep, mlpcvreport &cvrep, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
7283 
7284 
7285 /*************************************************************************
7286 Cross-validation estimate of generalization error.
7287 
7288 Base algorithm - Levenberg-Marquardt.
7289 
7290 INPUT PARAMETERS:
7291  Network - neural network with initialized geometry. Network is
7292  not changed during cross-validation - it is used only
7293  as a representative of its architecture.
7294  XY - training set.
7295  SSize - training set size
7296  Decay - weight decay, same as in MLPTrainLBFGS
7297  Restarts - number of restarts, >0.
7298  restarts are counted for each partition separately, so
7299  total number of restarts will be Restarts*FoldsCount.
7300  FoldsCount - number of folds in k-fold cross-validation,
7301  2<=FoldsCount<=SSize.
7302  recommended value: 10.
7303 
7304 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
7305  Info - return code, same as in MLPTrainLBFGS
7306  Rep - report, same as in MLPTrainLM/MLPTrainLBFGS
7307  CVRep - generalization error estimates
7308 
7309  -- ALGLIB --
7310  Copyright 09.12.2007 by Bochkanov Sergey
7311 *************************************************************************/
7312 void mlpkfoldcvlm(const multilayerperceptron &network, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints, const double decay, const ae_int_t restarts, const ae_int_t foldscount, ae_int_t &info, mlpreport &rep, mlpcvreport &cvrep, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
7313 
7314 
7315 /*************************************************************************
7316 This function estimates generalization error using cross-validation on the
7317 current dataset with current training settings.
7318 
7319  ! COMMERCIAL EDITION OF ALGLIB:
7320  !
7321  ! Commercial Edition of ALGLIB includes following important improvements
7322  ! of this function:
7323  ! * high-performance native backend with same C# interface (C# version)
7324  ! * multithreading support (C++ and C# versions)
7325  !
7326  ! We recommend you to read 'Working with commercial version' section of
7327  ! ALGLIB Reference Manual in order to find out how to use performance-
7328  ! related features provided by commercial edition of ALGLIB.
7329 
7330 INPUT PARAMETERS:
7331  S - trainer object
7332  Network - neural network. It must have same number of inputs and
7333  output/classes as was specified during creation of the
7334  trainer object. Network is not changed during cross-
7335  validation and is not trained - it is used only as
7336  representative of its architecture. I.e., we estimate
7337  generalization properties of ARCHITECTURE, not some
7338  specific network.
7339  NRestarts - number of restarts, >=0:
7340  * NRestarts>0 means that for each cross-validation
7341  round specified number of random restarts is
7342  performed, with best network being chosen after
7343  training.
7344  * NRestarts=0 is same as NRestarts=1
7345  FoldsCount - number of folds in k-fold cross-validation:
7346  * 2<=FoldsCount<=size of dataset
7347  * recommended value: 10.
7348  * values larger than dataset size will be silently
7349  truncated down to dataset size
7350 
7351 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
7352  Rep - structure which contains cross-validation estimates:
7353  * Rep.RelCLSError - fraction of misclassified cases.
7354  * Rep.AvgCE - acerage cross-entropy
7355  * Rep.RMSError - root-mean-square error
7356  * Rep.AvgError - average error
7357  * Rep.AvgRelError - average relative error
7358 
7359 NOTE: when no dataset was specified with MLPSetDataset/SetSparseDataset(),
7360  or subset with only one point was given, zeros are returned as
7361  estimates.
7362 
7363 NOTE: this method performs FoldsCount cross-validation rounds, each one
7364  with NRestarts random starts. Thus, FoldsCount*NRestarts networks
7365  are trained in total.
7366 
7367 NOTE: Rep.RelCLSError/Rep.AvgCE are zero on regression problems.
7368 
7369 NOTE: on classification problems Rep.RMSError/Rep.AvgError/Rep.AvgRelError
7370  contain errors in prediction of posterior probabilities.
7371 
7372  -- ALGLIB --
7373  Copyright 23.07.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
7374 *************************************************************************/
7375 void mlpkfoldcv(const mlptrainer &s, const multilayerperceptron &network, const ae_int_t nrestarts, const ae_int_t foldscount, mlpreport &rep, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
7376 
7377 
7378 /*************************************************************************
7379 Creation of the network trainer object for regression networks
7380 
7381 INPUT PARAMETERS:
7382  NIn - number of inputs, NIn>=1
7383  NOut - number of outputs, NOut>=1
7384 
7385 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
7386  S - neural network trainer object.
7387  This structure can be used to train any regression
7388  network with NIn inputs and NOut outputs.
7389 
7390  -- ALGLIB --
7391  Copyright 23.07.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
7392 *************************************************************************/
7393 void mlpcreatetrainer(const ae_int_t nin, const ae_int_t nout, mlptrainer &s, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
7394 
7395 
7396 /*************************************************************************
7397 Creation of the network trainer object for classification networks
7398 
7399 INPUT PARAMETERS:
7400  NIn - number of inputs, NIn>=1
7401  NClasses - number of classes, NClasses>=2
7402 
7403 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
7404  S - neural network trainer object.
7405  This structure can be used to train any classification
7406  network with NIn inputs and NOut outputs.
7407 
7408  -- ALGLIB --
7409  Copyright 23.07.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
7410 *************************************************************************/
7411 void mlpcreatetrainercls(const ae_int_t nin, const ae_int_t nclasses, mlptrainer &s, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
7412 
7413 
7414 /*************************************************************************
7415 This function sets "current dataset" of the trainer object to one passed
7416 by user.
7417 
7418 INPUT PARAMETERS:
7419  S - trainer object
7420  XY - training set, see below for information on the
7421  training set format. This function checks correctness
7422  of the dataset (no NANs/INFs, class numbers are
7423  correct) and throws exception when incorrect dataset
7424  is passed.
7425  NPoints - points count, >=0.
7426 
7427 DATASET FORMAT:
7428 
7429 This function uses two different dataset formats - one for regression
7430 networks, another one for classification networks.
7431 
7432 For regression networks with NIn inputs and NOut outputs following dataset
7433 format is used:
7434 * dataset is given by NPoints*(NIn+NOut) matrix
7435 * each row corresponds to one example
7436 * first NIn columns are inputs, next NOut columns are outputs
7437 
7438 For classification networks with NIn inputs and NClasses clases following
7439 datasetformat is used:
7440 * dataset is given by NPoints*(NIn+1) matrix
7441 * each row corresponds to one example
7442 * first NIn columns are inputs, last column stores class number (from 0 to
7443  NClasses-1).
7444 
7445  -- ALGLIB --
7446  Copyright 23.07.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
7447 *************************************************************************/
7448 void mlpsetdataset(const mlptrainer &s, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
7449 
7450 
7451 /*************************************************************************
7452 This function sets "current dataset" of the trainer object to one passed
7453 by user (sparse matrix is used to store dataset).
7454 
7455 INPUT PARAMETERS:
7456  S - trainer object
7457  XY - training set, see below for information on the
7458  training set format. This function checks correctness
7459  of the dataset (no NANs/INFs, class numbers are
7460  correct) and throws exception when incorrect dataset
7461  is passed. Any sparse storage format can be used:
7462  Hash-table, CRS...
7463  NPoints - points count, >=0
7464 
7465 DATASET FORMAT:
7466 
7467 This function uses two different dataset formats - one for regression
7468 networks, another one for classification networks.
7469 
7470 For regression networks with NIn inputs and NOut outputs following dataset
7471 format is used:
7472 * dataset is given by NPoints*(NIn+NOut) matrix
7473 * each row corresponds to one example
7474 * first NIn columns are inputs, next NOut columns are outputs
7475 
7476 For classification networks with NIn inputs and NClasses clases following
7477 datasetformat is used:
7478 * dataset is given by NPoints*(NIn+1) matrix
7479 * each row corresponds to one example
7480 * first NIn columns are inputs, last column stores class number (from 0 to
7481  NClasses-1).
7482 
7483  -- ALGLIB --
7484  Copyright 23.07.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
7485 *************************************************************************/
7486 void mlpsetsparsedataset(const mlptrainer &s, const sparsematrix &xy, const ae_int_t npoints, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
7487 
7488 
7489 /*************************************************************************
7490 This function sets weight decay coefficient which is used for training.
7491 
7492 INPUT PARAMETERS:
7493  S - trainer object
7494  Decay - weight decay coefficient, >=0. Weight decay term
7495  'Decay*||Weights||^2' is added to error function. If
7496  you don't know what Decay to choose, use 1.0E-3.
7497  Weight decay can be set to zero, in this case network
7498  is trained without weight decay.
7499 
7500 NOTE: by default network uses some small nonzero value for weight decay.
7501 
7502  -- ALGLIB --
7503  Copyright 23.07.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
7504 *************************************************************************/
7505 void mlpsetdecay(const mlptrainer &s, const double decay, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
7506 
7507 
7508 /*************************************************************************
7509 This function sets stopping criteria for the optimizer.
7510 
7511 INPUT PARAMETERS:
7512  S - trainer object
7513  WStep - stopping criterion. Algorithm stops if step size is
7514  less than WStep. Recommended value - 0.01. Zero step
7515  size means stopping after MaxIts iterations.
7516  WStep>=0.
7517  MaxIts - stopping criterion. Algorithm stops after MaxIts
7518  epochs (full passes over entire dataset). Zero MaxIts
7519  means stopping when step is sufficiently small.
7520  MaxIts>=0.
7521 
7522 NOTE: by default, WStep=0.005 and MaxIts=0 are used. These values are also
7523  used when MLPSetCond() is called with WStep=0 and MaxIts=0.
7524 
7525 NOTE: these stopping criteria are used for all kinds of neural training -
7526  from "conventional" networks to early stopping ensembles. When used
7527  for "conventional" networks, they are used as the only stopping
7528  criteria. When combined with early stopping, they used as ADDITIONAL
7529  stopping criteria which can terminate early stopping algorithm.
7530 
7531  -- ALGLIB --
7532  Copyright 23.07.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
7533 *************************************************************************/
7534 void mlpsetcond(const mlptrainer &s, const double wstep, const ae_int_t maxits, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
7535 
7536 
7537 /*************************************************************************
7538 This function sets training algorithm: batch training using L-BFGS will be
7539 used.
7540 
7541 This algorithm:
7542 * the most robust for small-scale problems, but may be too slow for large
7543  scale ones.
7544 * perfoms full pass through the dataset before performing step
7545 * uses conditions specified by MLPSetCond() for stopping
7546 * is default one used by trainer object
7547 
7548 INPUT PARAMETERS:
7549  S - trainer object
7550 
7551  -- ALGLIB --
7552  Copyright 23.07.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
7553 *************************************************************************/
7554 void mlpsetalgobatch(const mlptrainer &s, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
7555 
7556 
7557 /*************************************************************************
7558 This function trains neural network passed to this function, using current
7559 dataset (one which was passed to MLPSetDataset() or MLPSetSparseDataset())
7560 and current training settings. Training from NRestarts random starting
7561 positions is performed, best network is chosen.
7562 
7563 Training is performed using current training algorithm.
7564 
7565  ! COMMERCIAL EDITION OF ALGLIB:
7566  !
7567  ! Commercial Edition of ALGLIB includes following important improvements
7568  ! of this function:
7569  ! * high-performance native backend with same C# interface (C# version)
7570  ! * multithreading support (C++ and C# versions)
7571  !
7572  ! We recommend you to read 'Working with commercial version' section of
7573  ! ALGLIB Reference Manual in order to find out how to use performance-
7574  ! related features provided by commercial edition of ALGLIB.
7575 
7576 INPUT PARAMETERS:
7577  S - trainer object
7578  Network - neural network. It must have same number of inputs and
7579  output/classes as was specified during creation of the
7580  trainer object.
7581  NRestarts - number of restarts, >=0:
7582  * NRestarts>0 means that specified number of random
7583  restarts are performed, best network is chosen after
7584  training
7585  * NRestarts=0 means that current state of the network
7586  is used for training.
7587 
7588 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
7589  Network - trained network
7590 
7591 NOTE: when no dataset was specified with MLPSetDataset/SetSparseDataset(),
7592  network is filled by zero values. Same behavior for functions
7593  MLPStartTraining and MLPContinueTraining.
7594 
7595 NOTE: this method uses sum-of-squares error function for training.
7596 
7597  -- ALGLIB --
7598  Copyright 23.07.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
7599 *************************************************************************/
7600 void mlptrainnetwork(const mlptrainer &s, const multilayerperceptron &network, const ae_int_t nrestarts, mlpreport &rep, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
7601 
7602 
7603 /*************************************************************************
7604 IMPORTANT: this is an "expert" version of the MLPTrain() function. We do
7605  not recommend you to use it unless you are pretty sure that you
7606  need ability to monitor training progress.
7607 
7608 This function performs step-by-step training of the neural network. Here
7609 "step-by-step" means that training starts with MLPStartTraining() call,
7610 and then user subsequently calls MLPContinueTraining() to perform one more
7611 iteration of the training.
7612 
7613 After call to this function trainer object remembers network and is ready
7614 to train it. However, no training is performed until first call to
7615 MLPContinueTraining() function. Subsequent calls to MLPContinueTraining()
7616 will advance training progress one iteration further.
7617 
7618 EXAMPLE:
7619  >
7620  > ...initialize network and trainer object....
7621  >
7622  > MLPStartTraining(Trainer, Network, True)
7623  > while MLPContinueTraining(Trainer, Network) do
7624  > ...visualize training progress...
7625  >
7626 
7627 INPUT PARAMETERS:
7628  S - trainer object
7629  Network - neural network. It must have same number of inputs and
7630  output/classes as was specified during creation of the
7631  trainer object.
7632  RandomStart - randomize network before training or not:
7633  * True means that network is randomized and its
7634  initial state (one which was passed to the trainer
7635  object) is lost.
7636  * False means that training is started from the
7637  current state of the network
7638 
7639 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
7640  Network - neural network which is ready to training (weights are
7641  initialized, preprocessor is initialized using current
7642  training set)
7643 
7644 NOTE: this method uses sum-of-squares error function for training.
7645 
7646 NOTE: it is expected that trainer object settings are NOT changed during
7647  step-by-step training, i.e. no one changes stopping criteria or
7648  training set during training. It is possible and there is no defense
7649  against such actions, but algorithm behavior in such cases is
7650  undefined and can be unpredictable.
7651 
7652  -- ALGLIB --
7653  Copyright 23.07.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
7654 *************************************************************************/
7655 void mlpstarttraining(const mlptrainer &s, const multilayerperceptron &network, const bool randomstart, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
7656 
7657 
7658 /*************************************************************************
7659 IMPORTANT: this is an "expert" version of the MLPTrain() function. We do
7660  not recommend you to use it unless you are pretty sure that you
7661  need ability to monitor training progress.
7662 
7663  ! COMMERCIAL EDITION OF ALGLIB:
7664  !
7665  ! Commercial Edition of ALGLIB includes following important improvements
7666  ! of this function:
7667  ! * high-performance native backend with same C# interface (C# version)
7668  ! * multithreading support (C++ and C# versions)
7669  !
7670  ! We recommend you to read 'Working with commercial version' section of
7671  ! ALGLIB Reference Manual in order to find out how to use performance-
7672  ! related features provided by commercial edition of ALGLIB.
7673 
7674 This function performs step-by-step training of the neural network. Here
7675 "step-by-step" means that training starts with MLPStartTraining() call,
7676 and then user subsequently calls MLPContinueTraining() to perform one more
7677 iteration of the training.
7678 
7679 This function performs one more iteration of the training and returns
7680 either True (training continues) or False (training stopped). In case True
7681 was returned, Network weights are updated according to the current state
7682 of the optimization progress. In case False was returned, no additional
7683 updates is performed (previous update of the network weights moved us to
7684 the final point, and no additional updates is needed).
7685 
7686 EXAMPLE:
7687  >
7688  > [initialize network and trainer object]
7689  >
7690  > MLPStartTraining(Trainer, Network, True)
7691  > while MLPContinueTraining(Trainer, Network) do
7692  > [visualize training progress]
7693  >
7694 
7695 INPUT PARAMETERS:
7696  S - trainer object
7697  Network - neural network structure, which is used to store
7698  current state of the training process.
7699 
7700 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
7701  Network - weights of the neural network are rewritten by the
7702  current approximation.
7703 
7704 NOTE: this method uses sum-of-squares error function for training.
7705 
7706 NOTE: it is expected that trainer object settings are NOT changed during
7707  step-by-step training, i.e. no one changes stopping criteria or
7708  training set during training. It is possible and there is no defense
7709  against such actions, but algorithm behavior in such cases is
7710  undefined and can be unpredictable.
7711 
7712 NOTE: It is expected that Network is the same one which was passed to
7713  MLPStartTraining() function. However, THIS function checks only
7714  following:
