7715  * that number of network inputs is consistent with trainer object
7716  settings
7717  * that number of network outputs/classes is consistent with trainer
7718  object settings
7719  * that number of network weights is the same as number of weights in
7720  the network passed to MLPStartTraining() function
7721  Exception is thrown when these conditions are violated.
7722 
7723  It is also expected that you do not change state of the network on
7724  your own - the only party who has right to change network during its
7725  training is a trainer object. Any attempt to interfere with trainer
7726  may lead to unpredictable results.
7727 
7728 
7729  -- ALGLIB --
7730  Copyright 23.07.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
7731 *************************************************************************/
7732 bool mlpcontinuetraining(const mlptrainer &s, const multilayerperceptron &network, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
7733 
7734 
7735 /*************************************************************************
7736 Training neural networks ensemble using bootstrap aggregating (bagging).
7737 Modified Levenberg-Marquardt algorithm is used as base training method.
7738 
7739 INPUT PARAMETERS:
7740  Ensemble - model with initialized geometry
7741  XY - training set
7742  NPoints - training set size
7743  Decay - weight decay coefficient, >=0.001
7744  Restarts - restarts, >0.
7745 
7746 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
7747  Ensemble - trained model
7748  Info - return code:
7749  * -2, if there is a point with class number
7750  outside of [0..NClasses-1].
7751  * -1, if incorrect parameters was passed
7752  (NPoints<0, Restarts<1).
7753  * 2, if task has been solved.
7754  Rep - training report.
7755  OOBErrors - out-of-bag generalization error estimate
7756 
7757  -- ALGLIB --
7758  Copyright 17.02.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
7759 *************************************************************************/
7760 void mlpebagginglm(const mlpensemble &ensemble, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints, const double decay, const ae_int_t restarts, ae_int_t &info, mlpreport &rep, mlpcvreport &ooberrors, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
7761 
7762 
7763 /*************************************************************************
7764 Training neural networks ensemble using bootstrap aggregating (bagging).
7765 L-BFGS algorithm is used as base training method.
7766 
7767 INPUT PARAMETERS:
7768  Ensemble - model with initialized geometry
7769  XY - training set
7770  NPoints - training set size
7771  Decay - weight decay coefficient, >=0.001
7772  Restarts - restarts, >0.
7773  WStep - stopping criterion, same as in MLPTrainLBFGS
7774  MaxIts - stopping criterion, same as in MLPTrainLBFGS
7775 
7776 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
7777  Ensemble - trained model
7778  Info - return code:
7779  * -8, if both WStep=0 and MaxIts=0
7780  * -2, if there is a point with class number
7781  outside of [0..NClasses-1].
7782  * -1, if incorrect parameters was passed
7783  (NPoints<0, Restarts<1).
7784  * 2, if task has been solved.
7785  Rep - training report.
7786  OOBErrors - out-of-bag generalization error estimate
7787 
7788  -- ALGLIB --
7789  Copyright 17.02.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
7790 *************************************************************************/
7791 void mlpebagginglbfgs(const mlpensemble &ensemble, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints, const double decay, const ae_int_t restarts, const double wstep, const ae_int_t maxits, ae_int_t &info, mlpreport &rep, mlpcvreport &ooberrors, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
7792 
7793 
7794 /*************************************************************************
7795 Training neural networks ensemble using early stopping.
7796 
7797 INPUT PARAMETERS:
7798  Ensemble - model with initialized geometry
7799  XY - training set
7800  NPoints - training set size
7801  Decay - weight decay coefficient, >=0.001
7802  Restarts - restarts, >0.
7803 
7804 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
7805  Ensemble - trained model
7806  Info - return code:
7807  * -2, if there is a point with class number
7808  outside of [0..NClasses-1].
7809  * -1, if incorrect parameters was passed
7810  (NPoints<0, Restarts<1).
7811  * 6, if task has been solved.
7812  Rep - training report.
7813  OOBErrors - out-of-bag generalization error estimate
7814 
7815  -- ALGLIB --
7816  Copyright 10.03.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
7817 *************************************************************************/
7818 void mlpetraines(const mlpensemble &ensemble, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints, const double decay, const ae_int_t restarts, ae_int_t &info, mlpreport &rep, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
7819 
7820 
7821 /*************************************************************************
7822 This function trains neural network ensemble passed to this function using
7823 current dataset and early stopping training algorithm. Each early stopping
7824 round performs NRestarts random restarts (thus, EnsembleSize*NRestarts
7825 training rounds is performed in total).
7826 
7827  ! COMMERCIAL EDITION OF ALGLIB:
7828  !
7829  ! Commercial Edition of ALGLIB includes following important improvements
7830  ! of this function:
7831  ! * high-performance native backend with same C# interface (C# version)
7832  ! * multithreading support (C++ and C# versions)
7833  !
7834  ! We recommend you to read 'Working with commercial version' section of
7835  ! ALGLIB Reference Manual in order to find out how to use performance-
7836  ! related features provided by commercial edition of ALGLIB.
7837 
7838 INPUT PARAMETERS:
7839  S - trainer object;
7840  Ensemble - neural network ensemble. It must have same number of
7841  inputs and outputs/classes as was specified during
7842  creation of the trainer object.
7843  NRestarts - number of restarts, >=0:
7844  * NRestarts>0 means that specified number of random
7845  restarts are performed during each ES round;
7846  * NRestarts=0 is silently replaced by 1.
7847 
7848 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
7849  Ensemble - trained ensemble;
7850  Rep - it contains all type of errors.
7851 
7852 NOTE: this training method uses BOTH early stopping and weight decay! So,
7853  you should select weight decay before starting training just as you
7854  select it before training "conventional" networks.
7855 
7856 NOTE: when no dataset was specified with MLPSetDataset/SetSparseDataset(),
7857  or single-point dataset was passed, ensemble is filled by zero
7858  values.
7859 
7860 NOTE: this method uses sum-of-squares error function for training.
7861 
7862  -- ALGLIB --
7863  Copyright 22.08.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
7864 *************************************************************************/
7865 void mlptrainensemblees(const mlptrainer &s, const mlpensemble &ensemble, const ae_int_t nrestarts, mlpreport &rep, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
7866 #endif
7867 
7868 #if defined(AE_COMPILE_CLUSTERING) || !defined(AE_PARTIAL_BUILD)
7869 /*************************************************************************
7870 This function initializes clusterizer object. Newly initialized object is
7871 empty, i.e. it does not contain dataset. You should use it as follows:
7872 1. creation
7873 2. dataset is added with ClusterizerSetPoints()
7874 3. additional parameters are set
7875 3. clusterization is performed with one of the clustering functions
7876 
7877  -- ALGLIB --
7878  Copyright 10.07.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
7879 *************************************************************************/
7880 void clusterizercreate(clusterizerstate &s, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
7881 
7882 
7883 /*************************************************************************
7884 This function adds dataset to the clusterizer structure.
7885 
7886 This function overrides all previous calls of ClusterizerSetPoints() or
7887 ClusterizerSetDistances().
7888 
7889 INPUT PARAMETERS:
7890  S - clusterizer state, initialized by ClusterizerCreate()
7891  XY - array[NPoints,NFeatures], dataset
7892  NPoints - number of points, >=0
7893  NFeatures- number of features, >=1
7894  DistType- distance function:
7895  * 0 Chebyshev distance (L-inf norm)
7896  * 1 city block distance (L1 norm)
7897  * 2 Euclidean distance (L2 norm), non-squared
7898  * 10 Pearson correlation:
7899  dist(a,b) = 1-corr(a,b)
7900  * 11 Absolute Pearson correlation:
7901  dist(a,b) = 1-|corr(a,b)|
7902  * 12 Uncentered Pearson correlation (cosine of the angle):
7903  dist(a,b) = a'*b/(|a|*|b|)
7904  * 13 Absolute uncentered Pearson correlation
7905  dist(a,b) = |a'*b|/(|a|*|b|)
7906  * 20 Spearman rank correlation:
7907  dist(a,b) = 1-rankcorr(a,b)
7908  * 21 Absolute Spearman rank correlation
7909  dist(a,b) = 1-|rankcorr(a,b)|
7910 
7911 NOTE 1: different distance functions have different performance penalty:
7912  * Euclidean or Pearson correlation distances are the fastest ones
7913  * Spearman correlation distance function is a bit slower
7914  * city block and Chebyshev distances are order of magnitude slower
7915 
7916  The reason behing difference in performance is that correlation-based
7917  distance functions are computed using optimized linear algebra kernels,
7918  while Chebyshev and city block distance functions are computed using
7919  simple nested loops with two branches at each iteration.
7920 
7921 NOTE 2: different clustering algorithms have different limitations:
7922  * agglomerative hierarchical clustering algorithms may be used with
7923  any kind of distance metric
7924  * k-means++ clustering algorithm may be used only with Euclidean
7925  distance function
7926  Thus, list of specific clustering algorithms you may use depends
7927  on distance function you specify when you set your dataset.
7928 
7929  -- ALGLIB --
7930  Copyright 10.07.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
7931 *************************************************************************/
7932 void clusterizersetpoints(const clusterizerstate &s, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints, const ae_int_t nfeatures, const ae_int_t disttype, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
7933 void clusterizersetpoints(const clusterizerstate &s, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t disttype, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
7934 
7935 
7936 /*************************************************************************
7937 This function adds dataset given by distance matrix to the clusterizer
7938 structure. It is important that dataset is not given explicitly - only
7939 distance matrix is given.
7940 
7941 This function overrides all previous calls of ClusterizerSetPoints() or
7942 ClusterizerSetDistances().
7943 
7944 INPUT PARAMETERS:
7945  S - clusterizer state, initialized by ClusterizerCreate()
7946  D - array[NPoints,NPoints], distance matrix given by its upper
7947  or lower triangle (main diagonal is ignored because its
7948  entries are expected to be zero).
7949  NPoints - number of points
7950  IsUpper - whether upper or lower triangle of D is given.
7951 
7952 NOTE 1: different clustering algorithms have different limitations:
7953  * agglomerative hierarchical clustering algorithms may be used with
7954  any kind of distance metric, including one which is given by
7955  distance matrix
7956  * k-means++ clustering algorithm may be used only with Euclidean
7957  distance function and explicitly given points - it can not be
7958  used with dataset given by distance matrix
7959  Thus, if you call this function, you will be unable to use k-means
7960  clustering algorithm to process your problem.
7961 
7962  -- ALGLIB --
7963  Copyright 10.07.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
7964 *************************************************************************/
7965 void clusterizersetdistances(const clusterizerstate &s, const real_2d_array &d, const ae_int_t npoints, const bool isupper, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
7966 void clusterizersetdistances(const clusterizerstate &s, const real_2d_array &d, const bool isupper, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
7967 
7968 
7969 /*************************************************************************
7970 This function sets agglomerative hierarchical clustering algorithm
7971 
7972 INPUT PARAMETERS:
7973  S - clusterizer state, initialized by ClusterizerCreate()
7974  Algo - algorithm type:
7975  * 0 complete linkage (default algorithm)
7976  * 1 single linkage
7977  * 2 unweighted average linkage
7978  * 3 weighted average linkage
7979  * 4 Ward's method
7980 
7981 NOTE: Ward's method works correctly only with Euclidean distance, that's
7982  why algorithm will return negative termination code (failure) for
7983  any other distance type.
7984 
7985  It is possible, however, to use this method with user-supplied
7986  distance matrix. It is your responsibility to pass one which was
7987  calculated with Euclidean distance function.
7988 
7989  -- ALGLIB --
7990  Copyright 10.07.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
7991 *************************************************************************/
7992 void clusterizersetahcalgo(const clusterizerstate &s, const ae_int_t algo, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
7993 
7994 
7995 /*************************************************************************
7996 This function sets k-means properties: number of restarts and maximum
7997 number of iterations per one run.
7998 
7999 INPUT PARAMETERS:
8000  S - clusterizer state, initialized by ClusterizerCreate()
8001  Restarts- restarts count, >=1.
8002  k-means++ algorithm performs several restarts and chooses
8003  best set of centers (one with minimum squared distance).
8004  MaxIts - maximum number of k-means iterations performed during one
8005  run. >=0, zero value means that algorithm performs unlimited
8006  number of iterations.
8007 
8008  -- ALGLIB --
8009  Copyright 10.07.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
8010 *************************************************************************/
8011 void clusterizersetkmeanslimits(const clusterizerstate &s, const ae_int_t restarts, const ae_int_t maxits, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
8012 
8013 
8014 /*************************************************************************
8015 This function sets k-means initialization algorithm. Several different
8016 algorithms can be chosen, including k-means++.
8017 
8018 INPUT PARAMETERS:
8019  S - clusterizer state, initialized by ClusterizerCreate()
8020  InitAlgo- initialization algorithm:
8021  * 0 automatic selection ( different versions of ALGLIB
8022  may select different algorithms)
8023  * 1 random initialization
8024  * 2 k-means++ initialization (best quality of initial
8025  centers, but long non-parallelizable initialization
8026  phase with bad cache locality)
8027  * 3 "fast-greedy" algorithm with efficient, easy to
8028  parallelize initialization. Quality of initial centers
8029  is somewhat worse than that of k-means++. This
8030  algorithm is a default one in the current version of
8031  ALGLIB.
8032  *-1 "debug" algorithm which always selects first K rows
8033  of dataset; this algorithm is used for debug purposes
8034  only. Do not use it in the industrial code!
8035 
8036  -- ALGLIB --
8037  Copyright 21.01.2015 by Bochkanov Sergey
8038 *************************************************************************/
8039 void clusterizersetkmeansinit(const clusterizerstate &s, const ae_int_t initalgo, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
8040 
8041 
8042 /*************************************************************************
8043 This function sets seed which is used to initialize internal RNG. By
8044 default, deterministic seed is used - same for each run of clusterizer. If
8045 you specify non-deterministic seed value, then some algorithms which
8046 depend on random initialization (in current version: k-means) may return
8047 slightly different results after each run.
8048 
8049 INPUT PARAMETERS:
8050  S - clusterizer state, initialized by ClusterizerCreate()
8051  Seed - seed:
8052  * positive values = use deterministic seed for each run of
8053  algorithms which depend on random initialization
8054  * zero or negative values = use non-deterministic seed
8055 
8056  -- ALGLIB --
8057  Copyright 08.06.2017 by Bochkanov Sergey
8058 *************************************************************************/
8059 void clusterizersetseed(const clusterizerstate &s, const ae_int_t seed, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
8060 
8061 
8062 /*************************************************************************
8063 This function performs agglomerative hierarchical clustering
8064 
8065  ! COMMERCIAL EDITION OF ALGLIB:
8066  !
8067  ! Commercial Edition of ALGLIB includes following important improvements
8068  ! of this function:
8069  ! * high-performance native backend with same C# interface (C# version)
8070  ! * multithreading support (C++ and C# versions)
8071  ! * hardware vendor (Intel) implementations of linear algebra primitives
8072  ! (C++ and C# versions, x86/x64 platform)
8073  !
8074  ! We recommend you to read 'Working with commercial version' section of
8075  ! ALGLIB Reference Manual in order to find out how to use performance-
8076  ! related features provided by commercial edition of ALGLIB.
8077 
8078 NOTE: Agglomerative hierarchical clustering algorithm has two phases:
8079  distance matrix calculation and clustering itself. Only first phase
8080  (distance matrix calculation) is accelerated by Intel MKL and
8081  multithreading. Thus, acceleration is significant only for medium or
8082  high-dimensional problems.
8083 
8084  Although activating multithreading gives some speedup over single-
8085  threaded execution, you should not expect nearly-linear scaling
8086  with respect to cores count.
8087 
8088 INPUT PARAMETERS:
8089  S - clusterizer state, initialized by ClusterizerCreate()
8090 
8091 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
8092  Rep - clustering results; see description of AHCReport
8093  structure for more information.
8094 
8095 NOTE 1: hierarchical clustering algorithms require large amounts of memory.
8096  In particular, this implementation needs sizeof(double)*NPoints^2
8097  bytes, which are used to store distance matrix. In case we work
8098  with user-supplied matrix, this amount is multiplied by 2 (we have
8099  to store original matrix and to work with its copy).
8100 
8101  For example, problem with 10000 points would require 800M of RAM,
8102  even when working in a 1-dimensional space.
8103 
8104  -- ALGLIB --
8105  Copyright 10.07.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
8106 *************************************************************************/
8107 void clusterizerrunahc(const clusterizerstate &s, ahcreport &rep, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
8108 
8109 
8110 /*************************************************************************
8111 This function performs clustering by k-means++ algorithm.
8112 
8113 You may change algorithm properties by calling:
8114 * ClusterizerSetKMeansLimits() to change number of restarts or iterations
8115 * ClusterizerSetKMeansInit() to change initialization algorithm
8116 
8117 By default, one restart and unlimited number of iterations are used.
8118 Initialization algorithm is chosen automatically.
8119 
8120  ! COMMERCIAL EDITION OF ALGLIB:
8121  !
8122  ! Commercial Edition of ALGLIB includes following important improvements
8123  ! of this function:
8124  ! * high-performance native backend with same C# interface (C# version)
8125  ! * multithreading support (C++ and C# versions)
8126  ! * hardware vendor (Intel) implementations of linear algebra primitives
8127  ! (C++ and C# versions, x86/x64 platform)
8128  !
8129  ! We recommend you to read 'Working with commercial version' section of
8130  ! ALGLIB Reference Manual in order to find out how to use performance-
8131  ! related features provided by commercial edition of ALGLIB.
8132 
8133 NOTE: k-means clustering algorithm has two phases: selection of initial
8134  centers and clustering itself. ALGLIB parallelizes both phases.
8135  Parallel version is optimized for the following scenario: medium or
8136  high-dimensional problem (8 or more dimensions) with large number of
8137  points and clusters. However, some speed-up can be obtained even
8138  when assumptions above are violated.
8139 
8140 INPUT PARAMETERS:
8141  S - clusterizer state, initialized by ClusterizerCreate()
8142  K - number of clusters, K>=0.
8143  K can be zero only when algorithm is called for empty
8144  dataset, in this case completion code is set to
8145  success (+1).
8146  If K=0 and dataset size is non-zero, we can not
8147  meaningfully assign points to some center (there are no
8148  centers because K=0) and return -3 as completion code
8149  (failure).
8150 
8151 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
8152  Rep - clustering results; see description of KMeansReport
8153  structure for more information.
8154 
8155 NOTE 1: k-means clustering can be performed only for datasets with
8156  Euclidean distance function. Algorithm will return negative
8157  completion code in Rep.TerminationType in case dataset was added
8158  to clusterizer with DistType other than Euclidean (or dataset was
8159  specified by distance matrix instead of explicitly given points).
8160 
8161 NOTE 2: by default, k-means uses non-deterministic seed to initialize RNG
8162  which is used to select initial centers. As result, each run of
8163  algorithm may return different values. If you need deterministic
8164  behavior, use ClusterizerSetSeed() function.
8165 
8166  -- ALGLIB --
8167  Copyright 10.07.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
8168 *************************************************************************/
8169 void clusterizerrunkmeans(const clusterizerstate &s, const ae_int_t k, kmeansreport &rep, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
8170 
8171 
8172 /*************************************************************************
8173 This function returns distance matrix for dataset
8174 
8175  ! COMMERCIAL EDITION OF ALGLIB:
8176  !
8177  ! Commercial Edition of ALGLIB includes following important improvements
8178  ! of this function:
8179  ! * high-performance native backend with same C# interface (C# version)
8180  ! * multithreading support (C++ and C# versions)
8181  ! * hardware vendor (Intel) implementations of linear algebra primitives
8182  ! (C++ and C# versions, x86/x64 platform)
8183  !
8184  ! We recommend you to read 'Working with commercial version' section of
8185  ! ALGLIB Reference Manual in order to find out how to use performance-
8186  ! related features provided by commercial edition of ALGLIB.
8187 
8188 INPUT PARAMETERS:
8189  XY - array[NPoints,NFeatures], dataset
8190  NPoints - number of points, >=0
8191  NFeatures- number of features, >=1
8192  DistType- distance function:
8193  * 0 Chebyshev distance (L-inf norm)
8194  * 1 city block distance (L1 norm)
8195  * 2 Euclidean distance (L2 norm, non-squared)
8196  * 10 Pearson correlation:
8197  dist(a,b) = 1-corr(a,b)
8198  * 11 Absolute Pearson correlation:
8199  dist(a,b) = 1-|corr(a,b)|
8200  * 12 Uncentered Pearson correlation (cosine of the angle):
8201  dist(a,b) = a'*b/(|a|*|b|)
8202  * 13 Absolute uncentered Pearson correlation
8203  dist(a,b) = |a'*b|/(|a|*|b|)
8204  * 20 Spearman rank correlation:
8205  dist(a,b) = 1-rankcorr(a,b)
8206  * 21 Absolute Spearman rank correlation
8207  dist(a,b) = 1-|rankcorr(a,b)|
8208 
8209 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
8210  D - array[NPoints,NPoints], distance matrix
8211  (full matrix is returned, with lower and upper triangles)
8212 
8213 NOTE: different distance functions have different performance penalty:
8214  * Euclidean or Pearson correlation distances are the fastest ones
8215  * Spearman correlation distance function is a bit slower
8216  * city block and Chebyshev distances are order of magnitude slower
8217 
8218  The reason behing difference in performance is that correlation-based
8219  distance functions are computed using optimized linear algebra kernels,
8220  while Chebyshev and city block distance functions are computed using
8221  simple nested loops with two branches at each iteration.
8222 
8223  -- ALGLIB --
8224  Copyright 10.07.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
8225 *************************************************************************/
8226 void clusterizergetdistances(const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints, const ae_int_t nfeatures, const ae_int_t disttype, real_2d_array &d, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
8227 
8228 
8229 /*************************************************************************
8230 This function takes as input clusterization report Rep, desired clusters
8231 count K, and builds top K clusters from hierarchical clusterization tree.
8232 It returns assignment of points to clusters (array of cluster indexes).
8233 
8234 INPUT PARAMETERS:
8235  Rep - report from ClusterizerRunAHC() performed on XY
8236  K - desired number of clusters, 1<=K<=NPoints.
8237  K can be zero only when NPoints=0.
8238 
8239 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
8240  CIdx - array[NPoints], I-th element contains cluster index (from
8241  0 to K-1) for I-th point of the dataset.
8242  CZ - array[K]. This array allows to convert cluster indexes
8243  returned by this function to indexes used by Rep.Z. J-th
8244  cluster returned by this function corresponds to CZ[J]-th
8245  cluster stored in Rep.Z/PZ/PM.
8246  It is guaranteed that CZ[I]<CZ[I+1].
8247 
8248 NOTE: K clusters built by this subroutine are assumed to have no hierarchy.
8249  Although they were obtained by manipulation with top K nodes of
8250  dendrogram (i.e. hierarchical decomposition of dataset), this
8251  function does not return information about hierarchy. Each of the
8252  clusters stand on its own.
8253 
8254 NOTE: Cluster indexes returned by this function does not correspond to
8255  indexes returned in Rep.Z/PZ/PM. Either you work with hierarchical
8256  representation of the dataset (dendrogram), or you work with "flat"
8257  representation returned by this function. Each of representations
8258  has its own clusters indexing system (former uses [0, 2*NPoints-2]),
8259  while latter uses [0..K-1]), although it is possible to perform
8260  conversion from one system to another by means of CZ array, returned
8261  by this function, which allows you to convert indexes stored in CIdx
8262  to the numeration system used by Rep.Z.
8263 
8264 NOTE: this subroutine is optimized for moderate values of K. Say, for K=5
8265  it will perform many times faster than for K=100. Its worst-case
8266  performance is O(N*K), although in average case it perform better
8267  (up to O(N*log(K))).
8268 
8269  -- ALGLIB --
8270  Copyright 10.07.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
8271 *************************************************************************/
8272 void clusterizergetkclusters(const ahcreport &rep, const ae_int_t k, integer_1d_array &cidx, integer_1d_array &cz, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
8273 
8274 
8275 /*************************************************************************
8276 This function accepts AHC report Rep, desired minimum intercluster
8277 distance and returns top clusters from hierarchical clusterization tree
8278 which are separated by distance R or HIGHER.
8279 
8280 It returns assignment of points to clusters (array of cluster indexes).
8281 
8282 There is one more function with similar name - ClusterizerSeparatedByCorr,
8283 which returns clusters with intercluster correlation equal to R or LOWER
8284 (note: higher for distance, lower for correlation).
8285 
8286 INPUT PARAMETERS:
8287  Rep - report from ClusterizerRunAHC() performed on XY
8288  R - desired minimum intercluster distance, R>=0
8289 
8290 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
8291  K - number of clusters, 1<=K<=NPoints
8292  CIdx - array[NPoints], I-th element contains cluster index (from
8293  0 to K-1) for I-th point of the dataset.
8294  CZ - array[K]. This array allows to convert cluster indexes
8295  returned by this function to indexes used by Rep.Z. J-th
8296  cluster returned by this function corresponds to CZ[J]-th
8297  cluster stored in Rep.Z/PZ/PM.
8298  It is guaranteed that CZ[I]<CZ[I+1].
8299 
8300 NOTE: K clusters built by this subroutine are assumed to have no hierarchy.
8301  Although they were obtained by manipulation with top K nodes of
8302  dendrogram (i.e. hierarchical decomposition of dataset), this
8303  function does not return information about hierarchy. Each of the
8304  clusters stand on its own.
8305 
8306 NOTE: Cluster indexes returned by this function does not correspond to
8307  indexes returned in Rep.Z/PZ/PM. Either you work with hierarchical
8308  representation of the dataset (dendrogram), or you work with "flat"
8309  representation returned by this function. Each of representations
8310  has its own clusters indexing system (former uses [0, 2*NPoints-2]),
8311  while latter uses [0..K-1]), although it is possible to perform
8312  conversion from one system to another by means of CZ array, returned
8313  by this function, which allows you to convert indexes stored in CIdx
8314  to the numeration system used by Rep.Z.
8315 
8316 NOTE: this subroutine is optimized for moderate values of K. Say, for K=5
8317  it will perform many times faster than for K=100. Its worst-case
8318  performance is O(N*K), although in average case it perform better
8319  (up to O(N*log(K))).
8320 
8321  -- ALGLIB --
8322  Copyright 10.07.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
8323 *************************************************************************/
8324 void clusterizerseparatedbydist(const ahcreport &rep, const double r, ae_int_t &k, integer_1d_array &cidx, integer_1d_array &cz, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
8325 
8326 
8327 /*************************************************************************
8328 This function accepts AHC report Rep, desired maximum intercluster
8329 correlation and returns top clusters from hierarchical clusterization tree
8330 which are separated by correlation R or LOWER.
8331 
8332 It returns assignment of points to clusters (array of cluster indexes).
8333 
8334 There is one more function with similar name - ClusterizerSeparatedByDist,
8335 which returns clusters with intercluster distance equal to R or HIGHER
8336 (note: higher for distance, lower for correlation).
8337 
8338 INPUT PARAMETERS:
8339  Rep - report from ClusterizerRunAHC() performed on XY
8340  R - desired maximum intercluster correlation, -1<=R<=+1
8341 
8342 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
8343  K - number of clusters, 1<=K<=NPoints
8344  CIdx - array[NPoints], I-th element contains cluster index (from
8345  0 to K-1) for I-th point of the dataset.
8346  CZ - array[K]. This array allows to convert cluster indexes
8347  returned by this function to indexes used by Rep.Z. J-th
8348  cluster returned by this function corresponds to CZ[J]-th
8349  cluster stored in Rep.Z/PZ/PM.
8350  It is guaranteed that CZ[I]<CZ[I+1].
8351 
8352 NOTE: K clusters built by this subroutine are assumed to have no hierarchy.
8353  Although they were obtained by manipulation with top K nodes of
8354  dendrogram (i.e. hierarchical decomposition of dataset), this
8355  function does not return information about hierarchy. Each of the
8356  clusters stand on its own.
8357 
8358 NOTE: Cluster indexes returned by this function does not correspond to
8359  indexes returned in Rep.Z/PZ/PM. Either you work with hierarchical
8360  representation of the dataset (dendrogram), or you work with "flat"
8361  representation returned by this function. Each of representations
8362  has its own clusters indexing system (former uses [0, 2*NPoints-2]),
8363  while latter uses [0..K-1]), although it is possible to perform
8364  conversion from one system to another by means of CZ array, returned
8365  by this function, which allows you to convert indexes stored in CIdx
8366  to the numeration system used by Rep.Z.
8367 
8368 NOTE: this subroutine is optimized for moderate values of K. Say, for K=5
8369  it will perform many times faster than for K=100. Its worst-case
8370  performance is O(N*K), although in average case it perform better
8371  (up to O(N*log(K))).
8372 
8373  -- ALGLIB --
8374  Copyright 10.07.2012 by Bochkanov Sergey
8375 *************************************************************************/
8376 void clusterizerseparatedbycorr(const ahcreport &rep, const double r, ae_int_t &k, integer_1d_array &cidx, integer_1d_array &cz, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
8377 #endif
8378 
8379 #if defined(AE_COMPILE_DFOREST) || !defined(AE_PARTIAL_BUILD)
8380 /*************************************************************************
8381 This function serializes data structure to string.
8382 
8383 Important properties of s_out:
8384 * it contains alphanumeric characters, dots, underscores, minus signs
8385 * these symbols are grouped into words, which are separated by spaces
8386  and Windows-style (CR+LF) newlines
8387 * although serializer uses spaces and CR+LF as separators, you can
8388  replace any separator character by arbitrary combination of spaces,
8389  tabs, Windows or Unix newlines. It allows flexible reformatting of
8390  the string in case you want to include it into text or XML file.
8391  But you should not insert separators into the middle of the "words"
8392  nor you should change case of letters.
8393 * s_out can be freely moved between 32-bit and 64-bit systems, little
8394  and big endian machines, and so on. You can serialize structure on
8395  32-bit machine and unserialize it on 64-bit one (or vice versa), or
8396  serialize it on SPARC and unserialize on x86. You can also
8397  serialize it in C++ version of ALGLIB and unserialize in C# one,
8398  and vice versa.
8399 *************************************************************************/
8400 void dfserialize(decisionforest &obj, std::string &s_out);
8401 
8402 
8403 /*************************************************************************
8404 This function unserializes data structure from string.
8405 *************************************************************************/
8406 void dfunserialize(const std::string &s_in, decisionforest &obj);
8407 
8408 
8409 
8410 
8411 /*************************************************************************
8412 This function serializes data structure to C++ stream.
8413 
8414 Data stream generated by this function is same as string representation
8415 generated by string version of serializer - alphanumeric characters,
8416 dots, underscores, minus signs, which are grouped into words separated by
8417 spaces and CR+LF.
8418 
8419 We recommend you to read comments on string version of serializer to find
8420 out more about serialization of AlGLIB objects.
8421 *************************************************************************/
8422 void dfserialize(decisionforest &obj, std::ostream &s_out);
8423 
8424 
8425 /*************************************************************************
8426 This function unserializes data structure from stream.
8427 *************************************************************************/
8428 void dfunserialize(const std::istream &s_in, decisionforest &obj);
8429 
8430 
8431 /*************************************************************************
8432 This subroutine creates DecisionForestBuilder object which is used to
8433 train random forests.
8434 
8435 By default, new builder stores empty dataset and some reasonable default
8436 settings. At the very least, you should specify dataset prior to building
8437 decision forest. You can also tweak settings of the forest construction
8438 algorithm (recommended, although default setting should work well).
8439 
8440 Following actions are mandatory:
8441 * calling dfbuildersetdataset() to specify dataset
8442 * calling dfbuilderbuildrandomforest() to build random forest using current
8443  dataset and default settings
8444 
8445 Additionally, you may call:
8446 * dfbuildersetrndvars() or dfbuildersetrndvarsratio() to specify number of
8447  variables randomly chosen for each split
8448 * dfbuildersetsubsampleratio() to specify fraction of the dataset randomly
8449  subsampled to build each tree
8450 * dfbuildersetseed() to control random seed chosen for tree construction
8451 
8452 INPUT PARAMETERS:
8453  none
8454 
8455 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
8456  S - decision forest builder
8457 
8458  -- ALGLIB --
8459  Copyright 21.05.2018 by Bochkanov Sergey
8460 *************************************************************************/
8461 void dfbuildercreate(decisionforestbuilder &s, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
8462 
8463 
8464 /*************************************************************************
8465 This subroutine adds dense dataset to the internal storage of the builder
8466 object. Specifying your dataset in the dense format means that the dense
8467 version of the forest construction algorithm will be invoked.
8468 
8469 INPUT PARAMETERS:
8470  S - decision forest builder object
8471  XY - array[NPoints,NVars+1] (minimum size; actual size can
8472  be larger, only leading part is used anyway), dataset:
8473  * first NVars elements of each row store values of the
8474  independent variables
8475  * last column store class number (in 0...NClasses-1)
8476  or real value of the dependent variable
8477  NPoints - number of rows in the dataset, NPoints>=1
8478  NVars - number of independent variables, NVars>=1
8479  NClasses - indicates type of the problem being solved:
8480  * NClasses>=2 means that classification problem is
8481  solved (last column of the dataset stores class
8482  number)
8483  * NClasses=1 means that regression problem is solved
8484  (last column of the dataset stores variable value)
8485 
8486 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
8487  S - decision forest builder
8488 
8489  -- ALGLIB --
8490  Copyright 21.05.2018 by Bochkanov Sergey
8491 *************************************************************************/
8492 void dfbuildersetdataset(const decisionforestbuilder &s, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints, const ae_int_t nvars, const ae_int_t nclasses, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
8493 
8494 
8495 /*************************************************************************
8496 This function sets number of variables (in [1,NVars] range) used by random
8497 forest construction algorithm.
8498 
8499 The default option is to use roughly sqrt(NVars) variables.
8500 
8501 INPUT PARAMETERS:
8502  S - decision forest builder object
8503  RndVars - number of randomly selected variables; values outside
8504  of [1,NVars] range are silently clipped.
8505 
8506 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
8507  S - decision forest builder
8508 
8509  -- ALGLIB --
8510  Copyright 21.05.2018 by Bochkanov Sergey
8511 *************************************************************************/
8512 void dfbuildersetrndvars(const decisionforestbuilder &s, const ae_int_t rndvars, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
8513 
8514 
8515 /*************************************************************************
8516 This function sets number of variables used by random forest construction
8517 algorithm as a fraction of total variable count (0,1) range.
8518 
8519 The default option is to use roughly sqrt(NVars) variables.
8520 
8521 INPUT PARAMETERS:
8522  S - decision forest builder object
8523  F - round(NVars*F) variables are selected
8524 
8525 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
8526  S - decision forest builder
8527 
8528  -- ALGLIB --
8529  Copyright 21.05.2018 by Bochkanov Sergey
8530 *************************************************************************/
8531 void dfbuildersetrndvarsratio(const decisionforestbuilder &s, const double f, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
8532 
8533 
8534 /*************************************************************************
8535 This function tells random forest builder to automatically choose number
8536 of variables used by random forest construction algorithm. Roughly
8537 sqrt(NVars) variables will be used.
8538 
8539 INPUT PARAMETERS:
8540  S - decision forest builder object
8541 
8542 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
8543  S - decision forest builder
8544 
8545  -- ALGLIB --
8546  Copyright 21.05.2018 by Bochkanov Sergey
8547 *************************************************************************/
8548 void dfbuildersetrndvarsauto(const decisionforestbuilder &s, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
8549 
8550 
8551 /*************************************************************************
8552 This function sets size of dataset subsample generated the random forest
8553 construction algorithm. Size is specified as a fraction of total dataset
8554 size.
8555 
8556 The default option is to use 50% of the dataset for training, 50% for the
8557 OOB estimates. You can decrease fraction F down to 10%, 1% or even below
8558 in order to reduce overfitting.
8559 
8560 INPUT PARAMETERS:
8561  S - decision forest builder object
8562  F - fraction of the dataset to use, in (0,1] range. Values
8563  outside of this range will be silently clipped. At
8564  least one element is always selected for the training
8565  set.
8566 
8567 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
8568  S - decision forest builder
8569 
8570  -- ALGLIB --
8571  Copyright 21.05.2018 by Bochkanov Sergey
8572 *************************************************************************/
8573 void dfbuildersetsubsampleratio(const decisionforestbuilder &s, const double f, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
8574 
8575 
8576 /*************************************************************************
8577 This function sets seed used by internal RNG for random subsampling and
8578 random selection of variable subsets.
8579 
8580 By default, random seed is used, i.e. every time you build random forest,
8581 we seed generator with new value obtained from system-wide RNG. Thus,
8582 decision forest builder returns non-deterministic results. You can change
8583 such behavior by specyfing fixed positive seed value.
8584 
8585 INPUT PARAMETERS:
8586  S - decision forest builder object
8587  SeedVal - seed value:
8588  * positive values are used for seeding RNG with fixed
8589  seed, i.e. subsequent runs on same data will return
8590  same random forests
8591  * non-positive seed means that random seed is used
8592  for every run of builder, i.e. subsequent runs on
8593  same datasets will return slightly different random
8594  forests
8595 
8596 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
8597  S - decision forest builder, see
8598 
8599  -- ALGLIB --
8600  Copyright 21.05.2018 by Bochkanov Sergey
8601 *************************************************************************/
8602 void dfbuildersetseed(const decisionforestbuilder &s, const ae_int_t seedval, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
8603 
8604 
8605 /*************************************************************************
8606 This function sets random decision forest construction algorithm.
8607 
8608 As for now, only one random forest construction algorithm is supported -
8609 a dense "baseline" RDF algorithm.
8610 
8611 INPUT PARAMETERS:
8612  S - decision forest builder object
8613  AlgoType - algorithm type:
8614  * 0 = baseline dense RDF
8615 
8616 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
8617  S - decision forest builder, see
8618 
8619  -- ALGLIB --
8620  Copyright 21.05.2018 by Bochkanov Sergey
8621 *************************************************************************/
8622 void dfbuildersetrdfalgo(const decisionforestbuilder &s, const ae_int_t algotype, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
8623 
8624 
8625 /*************************************************************************
8626 This function sets split selection algorithm used by random forests
8627 classifier. You may choose several algorithms, with different speed and
8628 quality of the results.
8629 
8630 INPUT PARAMETERS:
8631  S - decision forest builder object
8632  SplitStrength- split type:
8633  * 0 = split at the random position, fastest one
8634  * 1 = split at the middle of the range
8635  * 2 = strong split at the best point of the range (default)
8636 
8637 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
8638  S - decision forest builder, see
8639 
8640  -- ALGLIB --
8641  Copyright 21.05.2018 by Bochkanov Sergey
8642 *************************************************************************/
8643 void dfbuildersetrdfsplitstrength(const decisionforestbuilder &s, const ae_int_t splitstrength, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
8644 
8645 
8646 /*************************************************************************
8647 This function is used to peek into random forest construction process from
8648 other thread and get current progress indicator. It returns value in [0,1].
8649 
8650 INPUT PARAMETERS:
8651  S - decision forest builder object used to build random
8652  forest in some other thread
8653 
8654 RESULT:
8655  progress value, in [0,1]
8656 
8657  -- ALGLIB --
8658  Copyright 21.05.2018 by Bochkanov Sergey
8659 *************************************************************************/
8660 double dfbuildergetprogress(const decisionforestbuilder &s, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
8661 
8662 
8663 /*************************************************************************
8664 This subroutine builds random forest according to current settings, using
8665 dataset internally stored in the builder object. Dense algorithm is used.
8666 
8667 NOTE: this function uses dense algorithm for forest construction
8668  independently from the dataset format (dense or sparse).
8669 
8670 Default settings are used by the algorithm; you can tweak them with the
8671 help of the following functions:
8672 * dfbuildersetrfactor() - to control a fraction of the dataset used for
8673  subsampling
8674 * dfbuildersetrandomvars() - to control number of variables randomly chosen
8675  for decision rule creation
8676 
8677  ! COMMERCIAL EDITION OF ALGLIB:
8678  !
8679  ! Commercial Edition of ALGLIB includes following important improvements
8680  ! of this function:
8681  ! * high-performance native backend with same C# interface (C# version)
8682  ! * multithreading support (C++ and C# versions)
8683  !
8684  ! We recommend you to read 'Working with commercial version' section of
8685  ! ALGLIB Reference Manual in order to find out how to use performance-
8686  ! related features provided by commercial edition of ALGLIB.
8687 
8688 INPUT PARAMETERS:
8689  S - decision forest builder object
8690  NTrees - NTrees>=1, number of trees to train
8691 
8692 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
8693  DF - decision forest
8694  Rep - report
8695 
8696  -- ALGLIB --
8697  Copyright 21.05.2018 by Bochkanov Sergey
8698 *************************************************************************/
8699 void dfbuilderbuildrandomforest(const decisionforestbuilder &s, const ae_int_t ntrees, decisionforest &df, dfreport &rep, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
8700 
8701 
8702 /*************************************************************************
8703 Procesing
8704 
8705 INPUT PARAMETERS:
8706  DF - decision forest model
8707  X - input vector, array[0..NVars-1].
8708 
8709 OUTPUT PARAMETERS:
8710  Y - result. Regression estimate when solving regression task,
8711  vector of posterior probabilities for classification task.
8712 
8713 See also DFProcessI.
8714 
8715  -- ALGLIB --
8716  Copyright 16.02.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
8717 *************************************************************************/
8718 void dfprocess(const decisionforest &df, const real_1d_array &x, real_1d_array &y, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
8719 
8720 
8721 /*************************************************************************
8722 'interactive' variant of DFProcess for languages like Python which support
8723 constructs like "Y = DFProcessI(DF,X)" and interactive mode of interpreter
8724 
8725 This function allocates new array on each call, so it is significantly
8726 slower than its 'non-interactive' counterpart, but it is more convenient
8727 when you call it from command line.
8728 
8729  -- ALGLIB --
8730  Copyright 28.02.2010 by Bochkanov Sergey
8731 *************************************************************************/
8732 void dfprocessi(const decisionforest &df, const real_1d_array &x, real_1d_array &y, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
8733 
8734 
8735 /*************************************************************************
8736 Relative classification error on the test set
8737 
8738 INPUT PARAMETERS:
8739  DF - decision forest model
8740  XY - test set
8741  NPoints - test set size
8742 
8743 RESULT:
8744  percent of incorrectly classified cases.
8745  Zero if model solves regression task.
8746 
8747  -- ALGLIB --
8748  Copyright 16.02.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
8749 *************************************************************************/
8750 double dfrelclserror(const decisionforest &df, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
8751 
8752 
8753 /*************************************************************************
8754 Average cross-entropy (in bits per element) on the test set
8755 
8756 INPUT PARAMETERS:
8757  DF - decision forest model
8758  XY - test set
8759  NPoints - test set size
8760 
8761 RESULT:
8762  CrossEntropy/(NPoints*LN(2)).
8763  Zero if model solves regression task.
8764 
8765  -- ALGLIB --
8766  Copyright 16.02.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
8767 *************************************************************************/
8768 double dfavgce(const decisionforest &df, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
8769 
8770 
8771 /*************************************************************************
8772 RMS error on the test set
8773 
8774 INPUT PARAMETERS:
8775  DF - decision forest model
8776  XY - test set
8777  NPoints - test set size
8778 
8779 RESULT:
8780  root mean square error.
8781  Its meaning for regression task is obvious. As for
8782  classification task, RMS error means error when estimating posterior
8783  probabilities.
8784 
8785  -- ALGLIB --
8786  Copyright 16.02.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
8787 *************************************************************************/
8788 double dfrmserror(const decisionforest &df, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
8789 
8790 
8791 /*************************************************************************
8792 Average error on the test set
8793 
8794 INPUT PARAMETERS:
8795  DF - decision forest model
8796  XY - test set
8797  NPoints - test set size
8798 
8799 RESULT:
8800  Its meaning for regression task is obvious. As for
8801  classification task, it means average error when estimating posterior
8802  probabilities.
8803 
8804  -- ALGLIB --
8805  Copyright 16.02.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
8806 *************************************************************************/
8807 double dfavgerror(const decisionforest &df, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
8808 
8809 
8810 /*************************************************************************
8811 Average relative error on the test set
8812 
8813 INPUT PARAMETERS:
8814  DF - decision forest model
8815  XY - test set
8816  NPoints - test set size
8817 
8818 RESULT:
8819  Its meaning for regression task is obvious. As for
8820  classification task, it means average relative error when estimating
8821  posterior probability of belonging to the correct class.
8822 
8823  -- ALGLIB --
8824  Copyright 16.02.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
8825 *************************************************************************/
8826 double dfavgrelerror(const decisionforest &df, const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
8827 
8828 
8829 /*************************************************************************
8830 This subroutine builds random decision forest.
8831 
8832 --------- DEPRECATED VERSION! USE DECISION FOREST BUILDER OBJECT ---------
8833 
8834  -- ALGLIB --
8835  Copyright 19.02.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
8836 *************************************************************************/
8837 void dfbuildrandomdecisionforest(const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints, const ae_int_t nvars, const ae_int_t nclasses, const ae_int_t ntrees, const double r, ae_int_t &info, decisionforest &df, dfreport &rep, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
8838 
8839 
8840 /*************************************************************************
8841 This subroutine builds random decision forest.
8842 
8843 --------- DEPRECATED VERSION! USE DECISION FOREST BUILDER OBJECT ---------
8844 
8845  -- ALGLIB --
8846  Copyright 19.02.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
8847 *************************************************************************/
8848 void dfbuildrandomdecisionforestx1(const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints, const ae_int_t nvars, const ae_int_t nclasses, const ae_int_t ntrees, const ae_int_t nrndvars, const double r, ae_int_t &info, decisionforest &df, dfreport &rep, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
8849 #endif
8850 
8851 #if defined(AE_COMPILE_DATACOMP) || !defined(AE_PARTIAL_BUILD)
8852 /*************************************************************************
8853 k-means++ clusterization.
8854 Backward compatibility function, we recommend to use CLUSTERING subpackage
8855 as better replacement.
8856 
8857  -- ALGLIB --
8858  Copyright 21.03.2009 by Bochkanov Sergey
8859 *************************************************************************/
8860 void kmeansgenerate(const real_2d_array &xy, const ae_int_t npoints, const ae_int_t nvars, const ae_int_t k, const ae_int_t restarts, ae_int_t &info, real_2d_array &c, integer_1d_array &xyc, const xparams _xparams = alglib::xdefault);
8861 #endif
8862 }
